name: Abert's Squirrel
region: Southwestern US and northern Mexico (Colorado, Utah, Arizona, New Mexico, extending to Chihuahua and Durango)
habitat: Mature ponderosa pine forests
description: Easily identified by its distinctive ear tufts extending 2-3 cm upward, this tassel-eared squirrel can consume seeds from up to 75 ponderosa pine cones in a single day and shows remarkable dietary flexibility by safely consuming mushrooms that are deadly to humans.

name: Agile Kangaroo Rat
region: Southern California
habitat: Shrubby areas with lighter soils
description: A nimble desert hopper that evolved alongside Ord's kangaroo rat from a common ancestor, preferring shrubby terrain where it outcompetes its close relative Stephens's kangaroo rat through superior habitat selection.

name: Alabama Beach Mouse
region: Alabama Gulf Coast
habitat: Coastal sand dunes with sea oats and beach grass
description: This tiny nocturnal mouse weighs less than a penny but plays a crucial role in coastal ecosystem health—its burrowing and seed-dispersal activities help stabilize sand dunes that protect the Alabama shoreline from storms and erosion.

name: Alaska Marmot
region: Brooks Range and northern Alaska
habitat: Alpine tundra, rocky mountain slopes and scree fields near lakes
description: This stocky rodent hibernates for up to eight months annually, dropping its body temperature to near freezing while its heart rate plummets—a survival strategy so extreme it awakens only every three to four weeks to urinate. Despite their remote Arctic habitat, Alaska marmots live in colonies of up to 50, using coordinated sentry duty to warn of golden eagles and grizzly bears.

name: Alaska Tiny Shrew
region: Central and southwestern Alaska
habitat: Near rivers
description: A diminutive shrew with tricolored gray fur that was only recognized as its own species in 1997, having previously been mistaken for the Eurasian least shrew. This tiny inhabitant of Alaskan rivers is rarely encountered and remains one of North America's least-known mammals.

name: Alaskan Hare
region: Western Alaska and Alaska Peninsula
habitat: Open tundra, rocky and brushy areas
description: One of the largest hares in the world, weighing up to 15.9 pounds with massive 7.9-inch hind feet that allow it to bound effortlessly through snow. Its ears shrink in winter and turn black-tipped as its entire coat transforms from brown to pure white for arctic camouflage.

name: Allegheny Woodrat
region: Appalachian Mountains from Pennsylvania to Alabama
habitat: Rocky outcrops, cliffs, caves, and talus slopes in deciduous and mixed pine-oak forests
description: A curious collector known as the 'pack rat' for hoarding bottle caps, coins, and bones alongside food—this furred-tailed rodent weighs nearly a pound and relies on stored acorn caches to survive harsh winters when its home range shrinks from 16 acres to just 1.6.

name: Allen's Big-eared Bat
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, California, Nevada, New Mexico, Utah, Colorado) and Mexico
habitat: Mountainous regions at high elevations (1,100-2,500 m typical)
description: This tiny 8-16 gram bat is the only species in North America known to emit long, constant frequency-frequency modulated echolocation calls, allowing it to pluck stationary insects from surfaces with remarkable precision using its elongated ears and highly maneuverable hovering flight.

name: Allen's Chipmunk
region: Western US (California, Oregon, Nevada)
habitat: Old-growth coniferous forests and Sierra Nevada mountains
description: This arboreal chipmunk nests as high as 88 feet above ground and is the only chipmunk species that collects and stores the seeds it eats, along with fungi that comprise up to 99% of its diet in virgin forests.

name: Alpine Chipmunk
region: High Sierra Nevada, California
habitat: Alpine zone at high elevations
description: This diminutive alpine dweller weighs a mere 27-45 grams yet survives at elevations up to 12,800 feet, hibernating for five months and frequently awakening to snack during winter's harshest months.

name: American Badger
region: Western, central, and northeastern United States; northern Mexico; south-central Canada to southwestern British Columbia
habitat: Open grasslands, prairies, and grassland meadows with sandy loam soil
description: A stocky digger with 5 cm foreclaws and a distinctive white facial stripe, known for hunting cooperatively with coyotes to increase prey capture rates by 33%—a partnership that benefits both predators through complementary hunting styles.

name: American Beaver
region: Continental US, Canada, southern Alaska, northern Mexico
habitat: Lakes, streams, rivers, and wetlands in boreal and temperate forests
description: An aquatic engineer capable of constructing dams over half a mile long and staying submerged for up to 15 minutes, this rodent nearly drove itself to extinction through relentless trapping but has made a remarkable comeback across North America.

name: American Bison
region: Continental US, Canada, Mexico; historically from Alaska to Gulf of Mexico
habitat: Open grasslands, prairies, plains, sagebrush, and mountain valleys
description: The heaviest land animal in North America, capable of running 65–70 km/h despite weighing up to 1,179 kg, and once numbered 60 million before being hunted down to just 541 animals by 1889.

name: American Black Bear
region: Throughout North America: Eastern US, Appalachian Mountains, Northern Midwest, Rocky Mountains, West Coast, Alaska, and Canada
habitat: Forested areas with thick understory vegetation and accessible terrain; also mountainous regions and swampy woodlands
description: A remarkably intelligent omnivore capable of opening screw-top jars and learning color discrimination faster than chimpanzees, with a sense of smell seven times more sensitive than a domestic dog's. Despite their name, these bears display stunning color variation from jet black to cinnamon and even white, and the largest wild specimen ever recorded weighed an estimated 1,100 pounds.

name: American Ermine
region: Most of North America south to northern New Mexico and Virginia; absent from southeastern US, Great Plains, most of Alaska, and Arctic Canada
habitat: Dense forests, hollow logs, burrows, and man-made structures
description: A lightning-fast predator that kills prey by biting at the base of the skull, this nimble weasel can pursue rodents into spaces larger predators cannot reach. Recently recognized as a distinct species in 2021 after being mistaken for its Old World cousin for nearly 200 years.

name: American Hog-nosed Skunk
region: Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, and south through Central America
habitat: Rocky canyons, desert scrub, mesquite grasslands, and thorn woodland
description: One of the world's largest skunks, reaching up to 2.7 feet long, with a distinctive single white stripe from head to tail and a pig-like snout adapted for rooting through soil and rocks in search of insects. Possesses powerfully built forearms and extremely long claws that rival badgers in digging prowess.

name: American Marten
region: Canada, Alaska, northern US (Great Lakes, Northeast, Pacific Northwest)
habitat: Coniferous and mixed forests, including old-growth and young forests
description: A slender weasel with luxuriant fur prized by the fur trade, capable of traveling 7-9 miles overnight and dispersing seeds over distances greater than half a mile while consuming roughly three voles per day.

name: American Mink
region: Most of North America from Alaska through Canada and continental US, excluding arid Southwest
habitat: Semiaquatic environments near water—rivers, coastal areas, marshes, and wetlands with dense cover
description: A streamlined aquatic hunter that can hold its breath for up to 60 seconds while diving to depths of 10 feet, and possesses anal glands producing a scent so potent it reportedly caused a naturalist to experience nausea—surpassing even skunk odor in unbearability.

name: American Pika
region: Western North American mountains, from British Columbia and Alberta to Oregon, California, and New Mexico
habitat: Alpine talus fields and boulder fields at or above the tree line
description: This tiny alpine herbivore weighs only 170 grams but makes up to 100 trips per day hauling vegetation to winter haypiles—and can die in just six hours if exposed to temperatures above 77.9°F, making it a living thermometer for climate change in western mountains.

name: American Pygmy Shrew
region: Northern Alaska, Canada, and northern United States south through the Appalachian Mountains
habitat: Boreal coniferous and deciduous forests, moist soils and leaf litter
description: North America's smallest mammal, this hyperactive shrew must eat three times its body weight every single day—capturing prey every 15 to 30 minutes or face certain death within an hour of fasting.

name: American Red Squirrel
region: Canada, Alaska, Rocky Mountains, Northern Eastern US
habitat: Coniferous forests and mixed woodlands
description: A pint-sized hoarder that can accumulate cone scales in middens up to 40 feet across, these territorial squirrels defend their cache year-round and mate with 4 to 16 partners in a single day during breeding season.

name: Anastasia Island Beach Mouse
region: Southeastern US (Florida)
habitat: Sandy coastal dunes
description: This pale-colored rodent has evolved to blend seamlessly into Florida's sandy dunes, weighing less than half an ounce while constructing elaborate burrows complete with escape tunnels for emergency getaways. Its nightly seed-gathering ritual and monogamous lifestyle make it one of North America's most vulnerable and specialized beach dwellers.

name: Antelope Jackrabbit
region: Southern Arizona and Northwestern Mexico
habitat: Desert shrubland with grassy ground cover and mesquite
description: A desert sprinter with ears reaching 6 inches long, this large hare can reproduce up to four times yearly and has adapted to thrive in more humid desert conditions than its black-tailed cousin. Its white-tipped ears help it radiate excess heat while hunting through mesquite thickets at twilight.

name: Arctic Fox
region: Alaska, northern Canada, Arctic archipelago
habitat: Arctic tundra, pack ice, boreal forests
description: An arctic specialist with fur so insulating it's the best of any mammal, capable of hearing lemmings burrowing 4-5 inches beneath snow and punching through to catch them. One tracked individual crossed 1,512 km of polar ice in just 21 days, averaging 46 km per day.

name: Arctic Ground Squirrel
region: Arctic Alaska, Northern Canada, Siberia
habitat: Arctic tundra, mountain slopes, river flats, sandy soil burrows
description: This Arctic hibernator can reduce its body temperature to −3°C (27°F) and slow its heart rate to one beat per minute, with blood that remains liquid while frozen—a phenomenon scientists hope could revolutionize organ transplant preservation. During hibernation from August to April, its brain connections dissolve only to mysteriously regrow upon waking.

name: Arctic Shrew
region: Northern Canada and northern United States (North Dakota, South Dakota, Wisconsin, Michigan, Minnesota)
habitat: Wetlands, marshes, swamps, and areas near bodies of water
description: This tricolored shrew is so aggressive that two placed together in a cage will result in one's death within days, despite showing no visible wounds. With a metabolism requiring it to eat constantly, it devours its body weight in insects daily.

name: Arctic Wolf
region: Canadian Arctic Archipelago (Queen Elizabeth Islands)
habitat: High Arctic tundra north of treeline
description: Inhabiting the frozen expanses of Canada's northernmost islands, this wolf displays remarkable curiosity toward humans due to limited contact, sometimes approaching researchers with cautious interest. Primarily hunts muskoxen and Arctic hares across landscapes where winter darkness lasts 24 hours straight.

name: Arizona Cotton Rat
region: Southern and central Arizona, southwestern New Mexico, western Mexico
habitat: Riparian areas, grasslands, and semidesert near rivers and streams
description: Once thought to be the same species as the hispid cotton rat until genetic analysis proved otherwise in 1970, this bristly-furred rodent weighs up to 300 grams and thrives in dense grassy vegetation near water sources throughout the arid Southwest.

name: Arizona Gray Squirrel
region: Eastern Arizona, northern Mexico
habitat: Mountain canyons and riparian forests at mid-elevations
description: More closely related to fox squirrels despite its gray appearance, this canyon dweller sports a distinctive red and black striped tail and breeds only when flower blooms provide enough energy to sustain the costly demands of reproduction.

name: Arizona Myotis
region: Southwestern United States and central Mexico
habitat: Variable elevations from sea level to mountain forests up to 9,206 feet
description: A cryptic nocturnal hunter with glossy cinnamon-brown fur, this tiny bat measures just 3.8 inches long yet ranges across elevations from sea level to nearly two miles high. Its specific name means 'hidden or concealed'—a fitting name for a bat so small it was only formally described in 1909.

name: Arizona Pocket Mouse
region: Sonoran Desert (Arizona)
habitat: Sonoran Desert scrubland
description: A nocturnal desert specialist that stuffs seeds into oversized cheek pouches and ferries them back to underground burrows for storage. Its smooth, thinly-furred tail and tan-to-orange coloring provide perfect camouflage in the harsh Arizona landscape.

name: Arizona Woodrat
region: Southwestern US and Mexico
habitat: Rocky desert terrain and scrubland
description: A nocturnal pack rat that constructs elaborate nests from twigs, cactus spines, and found objects to defend against predators and the harsh desert climate. Despite their solitary nature, Arizona woodrats play a crucial role in their ecosystem as seed dispersers across the arid Southwest.

name: Atlantic Spotted Dolphin
region: Atlantic Coast, Florida to Cape Cod
habitat: Warm temperate and tropical Atlantic waters
description: A highly social dolphin that transforms dramatically with age, shifting from plain gray-white calves to adults covered head-to-tail in dense spots. These cooperative hunters can dive to depths of 200 feet and remain submerged for up to 10 minutes while pursuing squid and small fish.

name: Atlantic White-sided Dolphin
region: Northeastern US (Cape Cod, continental shelf waters), Newfoundland
habitat: Cool temperate ocean waters, continental shelf areas around 100m depth
description: A distinctively marked oceanic dolphin distinguished by white to pale yellow patches behind its dorsal fin, known for cooperative hunting and breaching more frequently in larger groups of up to several hundred individuals.

name: Attwater's Pocket Gopher
region: Texas Coastal Bend
habitat: Coastal grasslands and prairies
description: A burrowing rodent named after English naturalist Henry Philemon Attwater, this underground specialist uses its powerful claws to excavate extensive tunnel networks through the Texas coastal landscape in search of roots and tubers.

name: Bailey's Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern US (California, Arizona, New Mexico) and Northwestern Mexico
habitat: Desert shrublands and arid regions
description: This nocturnal desert dweller is the only animal on Earth capable of digesting the toxic wax found in jojoba nuts, allowing it to feast on seeds that poison nearly every other mammal. A master hoarder, it carries seeds in fur-lined cheek pouches back to its burrow, keeping them perfectly dry.

name: Baird's Beaked Whale
region: Alaska, US West Coast to California
habitat: Deep ocean waters (1,000-3,000m depth)
description: The second-largest toothed whale on Earth, bearing battle scars from intense conflicts with rivals over a pair of formidable lower-jaw teeth. Known to live up to 84 years in the frigid depths of the North Pacific.

name: Baird's Pocket Gopher
region: Eastern Texas, Western Louisiana, Eastern Oklahoma, Southwestern Arkansas
habitat: Underground burrows in Gulf Coastal Plains with sandy or loamy soil
description: A cylindrical burrower that constructs complex tunnel systems up to 180 cm long while foraging underground, using specialized cheek pouches to transport food back to its elaborate winter chambers complete with nesting areas and food storage.

name: Baird's Shrew
region: Northwest Oregon
habitat: Moist conifer forests
description: A tiny forest dweller weighing just 0.27 ounces on average, this shrew must eat nearly constantly to fuel its hyperactive metabolism, consuming insects, worms, snails, and spiders with relentless energy.

name: Baja Pocket Mouse
region: Southern California, Baja California, Gulf of California islands
habitat: Arid scrublands and desert regions
description: A diminutive desert dweller with specialized cheek pouches for carrying seeds across the arid southwestern landscape. One subspecies, the Montserrat Island pocket mouse, vanished from existence in 1975.

name: Banner-tailed Kangaroo Rat
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico, Texas) and Mexico
habitat: Desert grassland with scattered shrubs
description: A nocturnal hopper with a distinctive black-and-white banner tail that constructs elaborate burrow systems with 3-meter mounds, accumulating massive seed caches in underground chambers and emerging only at dusk to forage for two hours before returning home.

name: Barbary Sheep
region: Southwestern United States
habitat: Arid rocky mountains and canyons
description: An exceptionally agile climber capable of executing standing jumps exceeding 7 feet, this North African invader has adapted to the rocky canyons of the American Southwest with remarkable success. Equipped with distinctive curved horns reaching 30 inches and a shaggy throat mane, it can obtain all necessary water from food alone.

name: Barren Ground Shrew
region: Northern Canada and Alaska
habitat: Tundra meadows and thickets north of the tree line
description: A diminutive tundra resident weighing just 4 grams, this shrew hunts insects and invertebrates across the Arctic with relentless energy. Its name comes from the Inuit word 'ugyunak,' honoring the indigenous peoples who share its frozen habitat.

name: Barren-ground Caribou
region: Northern Alaska, Canadian Arctic (Nunavut, Northwest Territories), Greenland
habitat: Arctic tundra and taiga (subarctic coniferous forests)
description: A tireless arctic wanderer that migrates up to 1,200 km per season across frozen terrain, with both males and females sporting impressive antlers and specialized nasal passages that warm frigid air before it reaches the lungs.

name: Beach Vole
region: Muskeget Island, Massachusetts
habitat: Open coastal areas with beach grass and poison ivy
description: Found exclusively on a tiny 0.87 km² island off Nantucket, this vole is notably larger than its mainland cousins and exhibits island gigantism, with males reaching up to 215 mm in length. Once hunted to extinction on the island by feral cats in 1891, it was successfully reintroduced in 1893 and remains one of North America's most geographically isolated rodents.

name: Bearded Seal
region: Arctic Alaska, Canadian Arctic, Greenland
habitat: Arctic and subarctic coastal waters, shallow ice floes
description: Arctic's largest northern seal, weighing up to 660 pounds with distinctive whiskers that curl elegantly when dry. Capable of producing otherworldly underwater vocalizations audible from over 30 kilometers away, using complex trills and moans to court mates and establish territory.

name: Beech Marten
region: Wisconsin (Milwaukee area, Kettle Moraine State Forest)
habitat: Wooded uplands, forest edges, and urban buildings
description: A nimble climber that creeps through buildings with polecat-like movements and can foot-load twice that of its pine marten cousin, making it uniquely adapted to solid ground. Infamous for chewing through electrical transformers—this agile marten famously shut down the Large Hadron Collider not once, but twice in 2016.

name: Belding's Ground Squirrel
region: Northwestern US (Oregon, Washington, California, Idaho, Nevada, Utah)
habitat: Alpine and subalpine meadows, sagebrush flats
description: These industrious rodents spend up to 40% of their summer eating to build fat reserves for hibernation, then recognize their relatives by comparing scents from specialized glands. Females produce piercing alarm calls to warn kin of predators while remaining silent when fleeing from terrestrial threats.

name: Beluga
region: Arctic and sub-Arctic waters around Alaska, Canada, and Greenland
habitat: Arctic Ocean, ice-covered seas, river estuaries
description: An exclusively white cetacean that can dive deeper than 700 meters and produce echolocation calls up to 120 kHz, earning it the nickname 'sea canary' for its remarkably vocal nature and ability to mimic human speech patterns.

name: Beringian Brown Lemming
region: Alaska and Yukon
habitat: Arctic tundra and subarctic regions
description: A small rodent that straddles two continents across the Bering Sea, inhabiting the same ancient landmass of Beringia that once connected Asia and North America before the land sank beneath the waves.

name: Bezoar Ibex
region: Southwestern US (New Mexico)
habitat: Rocky mountain terrain and cliffs
description: An introduced wild goat boasting the longest horns relative to body weight of any animal, with twisted horns exceeding 4.5 feet on males weighing just 130 pounds. Its dramatic black stripe darkens during mating season, making this Persian native one of North America's most imposing climbers.

name: Big Brown Bat
region: Throughout North America from Alaska and Canada to Colombia and Venezuela
habitat: Urban, suburban, and rural areas; caves, mines, buildings, and tree cavities
description: A nocturnal insect-hunting specialist that can consume up to 600,000 cucumber beetles per year from a single colony, making it invaluable to farmers across North America. Unlike most bat species, this one shows surprising resistance to white-nose syndrome and has actually increased in population since the fungal disease arrived.

name: Big-eared Kangaroo Rat
region: Central California (San Benito and Monterey counties)
habitat: Chaparral
description: Distinguished by its unusually large ears relative to body size, this tiny rodent uses its oversized auditory organs to detect predators and navigate the chaparral scrublands of central California. Despite its small stature, it can leap several feet in a single bound using powerful hind legs.

name: Big-eared Woodrat
region: Western California and northern Baja California, Sierra Nevada mountains
habitat: Oak and chaparral forests, sage scrub with dense understory vegetation
description: A nocturnal tree-dweller with distinctively large mobile ears and eyes, this specialist herbivore subsists almost entirely on oak leaves—comprising over 85% of its diet—allowing it to thrive on food sources other rodents avoid due to high tannin content.

name: Bighorn Sheep
region: Western North America from southwestern Canada to Mexico; Rocky Mountains and Sierra Nevada
habitat: Alpine meadows, grassy mountain slopes, rocky cliffs and bluffs in mountainous and desert regions
description: Massive curved horns weighing up to 14 kg (30 lb)—as much as all the bones in the male's body combined—make this mountain dweller a formidable presence. Males employ at least three different mating strategies and can headbutt competitors with such force that their horns frequently show battle damage.

name: Black-eared Mouse
region: Mountainous regions of southern Arizona and central Mexico
habitat: Coniferous forests and mixed grasslands at high elevation (8,500-9,500 ft)
description: This tiny nocturnal mouse possesses a remarkable tolerance for bitter toxins, allowing it to consume large quantities of monarch butterflies that would poison other predators. Despite measuring just 5.5 to 7.1 inches, it actively defends its territory from competing species.

name: Black-footed Ferret
region: Central and Western US, Canada, Mexico
habitat: Prairie grasslands with prairie dog colonies
description: A nocturnal prairie hunter where up to 90% of its diet consists of prairie dogs, relying so completely on these colonies that a single female and her litter require 400-1,400 prairie dogs annually to survive. Once declared extinct in 1979, this species was brought back from the brink through captive breeding, with over 200 wild individuals now thriving across multiple reintroduction sites.

name: Black-tailed Jackrabbit
region: Western US and Mexico, expanding eastward across Great Plains
habitat: Mixed shrub-grassland, desert scrub, and prairie
description: Fleet-footed desert dweller capable of 2–10 mile diurnal movements between shrub cover and open foraging grounds, with mothers abandoning their fully-furred, mobile young immediately after birth to fend for themselves.

name: Black-tailed Prairie Dog
region: Great Plains, US-Canada border to US-Mexico border
habitat: Shortgrass and mixed-grass prairie, sagebrush steppe
description: These highly social rodents form massive underground cities with sophisticated vocal communication systems that can describe specific predators, their size, and approach speed. A single prairie dog town in Texas once covered 25,000 square miles and contained 400 million individuals.

name: Blackbuck
region: Texas (Edwards Plateau)
habitat: Grassy plains and lightly forested areas with water sources
description: This Indian antelope's males sport magnificent corkscrew horns reaching up to 30 inches long and can sprint at 50 mph across open grasslands. Introduced to Texas in 1932, it became the state's most populous exotic animal by 1988.

name: Blainville's Beaked Whale
region: Hawaii, Gulf of Mexico, Western North Atlantic
habitat: Deep offshore waters, tropical and warm ocean regions
description: A deep-diving cetacean with bones so extraordinarily dense they're harder than any other measured in nature, capable of plunging to depths of 4,600 feet and holding its breath for up to 68 minutes while hunting squid in near-total darkness.

name: Blue Whale
region: Eastern North Pacific coast (California to Alaska), North Atlantic (New England to Greenland)
habitat: Open ocean, pelagic waters near polar feeding grounds and tropical breeding grounds
description: The largest animal ever known to exist, reaching lengths of nearly 100 feet and weights up to 199 tonnes—yet sustains itself almost entirely on tiny krill, consuming up to 4 tons per day through dramatic lunge-feeding attacks that engulf 220 metric tons of water in a single gulp.

name: Bobcat
region: Southern Canada through continental US to Mexico
habitat: Woodlands, swamps, deserts, forest edges, urban areas with suitable cover
description: A supremely adaptable ambush predator with a distinctive bobbed tail, capable of taking prey up to eight times its own weight and moving 3-11 kilometers per night along habitual hunting routes.

name: Botta's Pocket Gopher
region: Western North America from California to Texas
habitat: Woodlands, chaparral, scrubland, and agricultural areas
description: A tireless underground miner that can excavate up to 28 tons of soil per hectare annually, spending 90% of its life in burrows and reaching depths of up to 5 feet. Its teeth are specially adapted for digging, allowing it to thrive in soils ranging from loose sand to packed clay.

name: Bowhead Whale
region: Arctic Alaska, Bering Sea
habitat: Arctic and subarctic ice-covered waters
description: An Arctic giant with a massive triangular skull used to shatter through 60 cm of ice, boasting the longest baleen plates of any whale at up to 4 meters and a lifespan exceeding 200 years—making it Earth's longest-living mammal.

name: Brown Bear
region: Alaska, Western Canada, Northwestern US (Rockies and Great Plains)
habitat: Semiopen country with scattered vegetation, northern temperate forests, from sea level to high mountain elevations
description: One of North America's largest carnivores with strength estimated at 2.5 to 5 times that of a human, recognizable by the distinctive muscular hump on its shoulders used for powerful digging. Can weigh up to 600 kg and inhabits the broadest range of habitats of any living bear species.

name: Brown Rat
region: Continental US, particularly urban areas and near ports
habitat: Urban environments, sewers, burrows, buildings, and areas near human habitation
description: A highly adaptable rodent capable of producing up to five litters per year with a gestation period of just 21 days, allowing populations to grow from 2 to 15,000 individuals in a single year. Possesses exceptional cognitive abilities and can see ultraviolet light that humans cannot perceive.

name: Brush Mouse
region: Western US and Mexico, from California to Colorado and Texas
habitat: Mountainous shrublands and chaparral above 2,000 meters
description: A nimble nocturnal climber with a distinctive brush-tipped tail, capable of foraging in trees and shrubs up to 10 feet high while maintaining home ranges as small as 0.12 hectares. Females can reach sexual maturity in just 5-9 weeks and produce up to six litters per year under ideal conditions.

name: Brush Rabbit
region: Pacific Coast from Oregon to Baja California
habitat: Dense bramble thickets and chaparral vegetation
description: A tiny cottontail weighing less than two pounds that rarely ventures beyond its brushy hideaway, relying on zig-zag sprints and low-branch climbing to evade predators. One of the least fecund rabbits in its genus, producing only about 15 young per year despite living in constant danger.

name: Bryant's Woodrat
region: Southwestern United States and Mexico
habitat: Arid and semi-arid regions, rocky areas
description: A skilled pack rat that constructs elaborate nests from twigs, cactus spines, and other desert debris, often hoarding shiny objects in hidden chambers throughout its territory.

name: Bushy-tailed Woodrat
region: Western North America from arctic Canada to northern Arizona and New Mexico
habitat: Rocky areas including cliffs, canyons, and talus slopes; also adapts to abandoned buildings and mines
description: A compulsive collector with an irresistible attraction to shiny objects, this bushy-tailed climber will abandon whatever it's carrying for a coin or spoon. With a tail that comprises half its 11-18 inch body length, it's the largest and most cold-tolerant woodrat species, capable of surviving from sea level to 14,000 feet.

name: Cactus Mouse
region: Southwestern United States and northern Mexico
habitat: Desert, steppe, and arid mountain foothills
description: A nocturnal desert dweller with oversized ears and a nearly hairless tail that can be longer than its own body. Capable of entering torpor within 30 minutes of food deprivation to survive harsh arid environments.

name: California Chipmunk
region: Southern California and Baja California
habitat: Chaparral and scrubland
description: A nimble burrower of California's chaparral, this small rodent darts through scrubland with remarkable agility despite weighing less than an ounce. Known for its striped back and cheek pouches, it stashes seeds and nuts for survival through lean seasons.

name: California Grizzly Bear
region: California (historically)
habitat: Diverse climates including grasslands, forests, coastal regions, and mountains
description: Once California's apex predator, this massive bear weighed up to 2,200 pounds with claws reaching 3.5 inches long and could sprint at 35 mph—but was hunted to extinction in less than 75 years after the Gold Rush began. The last confirmed sighting was in 1924, making it one of North America's most tragic wildlife losses.

name: California Ground Squirrel
region: Western US (Oregon, California, Washington, northwestern Nevada) and Baja California Peninsula
habitat: Burrows in gardens, parks, and open areas with ornamental plants
description: This cunning burrower has evolved extraordinary defenses against rattlesnakes, including the ability to super-heat its tail and wave it to signal danger—a tactic that successfully deters snake attacks in 67% of encounters. Some populations have even developed partial resistance to rattlesnake venom as adults.

name: California Kangaroo Rat
region: Northern California and southern Oregon
habitat: Grasslands and foothills from Sierra Nevada to Cascade Mountains
description: This 312mm rodent possesses a distinctive white-tipped tail with black stripes and is so well-adapted to harsh environments that it thrives where few humans dare to venture. Unlike common rats, it never scavenges human food and carries no dangerous pathogens, making it an ideal neighbor in inhospitable terrain.

name: California Mouse
region: Northwestern Mexico, Central to Southern California
habitat: Coastal sage scrub, semi-arboreal areas with ground nesting sites
description: Unlike nearly all other rodents, this monogamous mouse forms lasting pair bonds and features males that actively help raise their young. With a tail longer than its head and body combined, it can produce up to six litters annually despite averaging only two pups per litter.

name: California Pocket Mouse
region: California and Northern Baja California
habitat: Chaparral and woodlands
description: A nocturnal seed hoarder equipped with external cheek pouches, this tiny rodent weighs less than an ounce yet stores seeds across its territory. Despite being widespread across central and southern California, its habitat continues to shrink due to climate change and urban development.

name: California Red Tree Mouse
region: Northwest California
habitat: Old-growth Douglas-fir forests
description: A rare arboreal rodent that spends its entire life in the canopy of old-growth Douglas-fir forests, building elaborate nests high above the forest floor where few other mammals venture.

name: California Sea Lion
region: Western North America, Alaska to Mexico
habitat: Coastal rocky and sandy beaches, marinas, and wharves
description: An intelligent marine predator capable of diving to depths of 899 feet and staying submerged for nearly 10 minutes, this barrel-chested pinnipeds can be trained to perform complex military tasks and even recognize musical rhythms—a feat once thought unique to humans and vocal mimicry birds.

name: California Vole
region: California and southwestern Oregon
habitat: Grasslands, coastal marshes, and upland savannah
description: A prolific breeder capable of producing up to 10 offspring per litter and reaching sexual maturity in as little as three weeks, allowing populations to explode rapidly. Despite living less than a year on average, this humble rodent serves as a crucial food source for hawks, owls, weasels, and coyotes across the West.

name: Camas Pocket Gopher
region: Willamette Valley, northwestern Oregon
habitat: Clay-rich grasslands, shrublands, and agricultural fields
description: The largest of its genus, this underground burrower uses prominent buck teeth to excavate tunnels exceeding 240 meters in hard clay soil, and constructs unique vertical chimney mounds for ventilation using Bernoulli's principle.

name: Canada Lynx
region: Alaska, Canada, Pacific Northwest, Rocky Mountains, Northern Great Lakes, Northern New England
habitat: Dense boreal forests
description: A forest ghost with snowshoe paws that can spread 10 cm wide, allowing it to move effortlessly across snow where heavier predators sink—a specialized hunter so dependent on snowshoe hares that its population fluctuates in perfect sync with theirs every 8-11 years.

name: Canyon Mouse
region: Western United States and Northern Mexico
habitat: Arid, rocky desert with minimal vegetation
description: A nocturnal desert dweller that nests among rocks and relies on rocky substrate rather than plants for survival, females can produce up to 20 offspring per year across multiple spring and summer litters.

name: Cape Hare
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Not applicable to US
description: This species is native to Africa, Arabia, and India—not found in the United States or North America.

name: Caribbean Monk Seal
region: Caribbean waters, Gulf of Mexico, Western Atlantic
habitat: Warm subtropical and tropical waters; sandy beaches on isolated islands and atolls
description: A docile, curious seal weighing up to 600 pounds that tragically became the first monk seal driven to extinction, hunted relentlessly for its oil-rich blubber until the last confirmed sighting in 1952.

name: Caribou
region: Alaska, northern Canada, and historically the contiguous US from Maine to Washington
habitat: Arctic tundra, subarctic tundra, boreal forests, and mountainous regions
description: The only deer species where females regularly grow antlers, this circumpolar wanderer undertakes some of the longest land migrations in North America—up to 3,100 miles annually—and can survive temperatures dropping below -50°F by warming air through an enlarged nasal cavity before it reaches the lungs.

name: Cascade Golden-mantled Ground Squirrel
region: Cascade Mountains of Washington and British Columbia
habitat: Mountain forests and meadows
description: Born ectothermic but rapidly developing internal heat regulation, this ground squirrel covers an impressive 5 kilometers daily—traveling at a maximum aerobic speed of 3.63 m/s to outrun predators. Its distinctive alarm calls are so unique they can be identified with 100% accuracy, making this the largest of its three-species genus unmistakable to fellow squirrels.

name: Cave Myotis
region: Southwest Kansas and Mexico
habitat: Caves, mines, and buildings
description: A moth-hunting insectivore that can venture farther from its roost than related bat species, using superior wing design to forage up to two hours after sunset. Known for gathering in massive hibernating colonies of over 1,000 individuals clinging to cave ceilings.

name: Chihuahuan Grasshopper Mouse
region: Southwestern New Mexico, West Texas, North-central Mexico
habitat: Semiarid prairie and scrub
description: A pint-sized predator that hunts scorpions and other invertebrates with remarkable fearlessness, demonstrating that size is no obstacle to becoming a formidable desert hunter.

name: Chihuahuan Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern US (Texas, New Mexico) and Mexico
habitat: Desert scrubland with sandy soil
description: A nocturnal desert dweller weighing just 15-23 grams that constructs elaborate multi-chambered burrows with numerous hidden exits. This seed-hoarding rodent can enter torpor during winter months and was only recognized as a distinct species in 1996 through DNA analysis.

name: Chisel-toothed Kangaroo Rat
region: Great Basin and High Desert (Nevada, Utah, California, Oregon, Arizona, Idaho)
habitat: Arid desert shrubland with saltbush, gravelly soils at moderate to high elevations
description: This tiny desert specialist has evolved chisel-shaped incisors to scrape salt crystals off toxic saltbush leaves, then stores up to 250 grams of leaves in its burrows and obtains all its water from the vegetation—a unique survival strategy among kangaroo rats.

name: Chital
region: Hawaii, Texas, and isolated populations in California
habitat: Open grasslands and deciduous forests
description: An introduced Asian deer species sporting a coat of white spots and a distinctive dark stripe down its back, capable of leaping and clearing fences nearly 5 feet high. Males grow antlers up to 3 feet long and can reach 240 pounds, but have become so numerous in Hawaii that they now outnumber the human population by a factor of 10-to-1.

name: Choctawhatchee Beach Mouse
region: Southeastern US (Florida to Tennessee)
habitat: Beaches and sandy fields
description: A nocturnal seed-eater that perfectly matches its environment, turning white on sandy beaches and darker inland. Despite weighing only 8-19 grams, this tiny mouse digs its own burrows and can reproduce within 30 days of birth.

name: Cinereus Shrew
region: Alaska, Canada, and northern United States south to Maryland and the Appalachians
habitat: Humid areas with dense vegetation, woodland, grasslands, and tundra
description: North America's most widespread shrew, this tiny mammal weighs only 5 grams yet must consume three times its body weight daily to survive, eating almost constantly to avoid starvation within hours. Its metabolism is so extreme that it produces high-frequency pulses and can live only up to two years in the wild.

name: Cliff Chipmunk
region: Western US (Arizona to Colorado) and Mexico
habitat: Cliff walls and boulder fields in pinyon-juniper woodlands
description: A gravity-defying acrobat that scales sheer cliff faces with ease, this tiny 2.5-ounce rodent forgoes body fat storage and instead meticulously hoards food for winter survival. Remarkably long-lived for its size, it can reach over 12 years of age.

name: Clymene Dolphin
region: Gulf of Mexico, Atlantic coast from New Jersey to southern Morocco
habitat: Deep oceanic waters over 330 feet, tropical and temperate Atlantic waters
description: The only confirmed hybrid species of marine mammal, born from spinner dolphins and striped dolphins millions of years ago. This sleek 6.6-foot deep-water hunter produces complex vocalizations across a 6–19 kHz range and occasionally spins when breaching, though never with the acrobatic flair of its spinner dolphin ancestors.

name: Coast Mole
region: Pacific coast from British Columbia to Northern California
habitat: Forested and open areas with moist soils, including deciduous and conifer forests
description: This burrowing mammal uses a specialized sensory organ called Eimer's organ to hunt earthworms in total darkness, detecting prey with such precision that it can distinguish between individual food items underground. Capable of increased oxygen storage and modified hemoglobin that functions even in the cold, oxygen-depleted tunnels where it spends most of its life.

name: Cockrum's Gray Shrew
region: Southeastern Arizona to central Sonora, Mexico
habitat: Desert shrub with mesquite, agave, cholla, and oakbrush
description: Weighing as little as a penny, this insectivorous desert dweller is Arizona's first new mammal species in over 25 years, distinguished by its reddish-pink nose, tail, and feet.

name: Collared Peccary
region: Southwestern United States
habitat: Desert scrublands, tropical dry forests, and suburban areas
description: A stocky desert dweller weighing up to 60 pounds with razor-sharp tusks that point downward and a distinctive pale collar marking. Despite their pig-like appearance, these adaptable omnivores have colonized cities from Phoenix to Tucson, foraging through gardens and release a pungent musk when threatened.

name: Collared Pika
region: Central and southern Alaska, Yukon, northern British Columbia, western Northwest Territories
habitat: Alpine boulder fields and talus sites
description: This tiny 160-gram alpine specialist makes thousands of foraging trips during July and August to stockpile vegetation under rocks, relying entirely on these 'haypiles' to survive brutal winters without hibernating. The only pika species found in North America's far north, it communicates with sharp territorial calls and has evolved a distinctly broad skull to distinguish itself from its southern cousin.

name: Colorado Chipmunk
region: Colorado, Utah, Arizona, New Mexico
habitat: Coniferous forests and montane woodlands at high elevation
description: The largest chipmunk of the Colorado Front Range, this tiny rodent can weigh up to 62 grams yet fiercely defends its territory with vocalizations and caches enough seeds and berries to survive harsh mountain winters above 4,900 feet in elevation.

name: Columbia Plateau Pocket Mouse
region: Great Basin, Pacific Northwest, and adjacent western US from British Columbia to Arizona
habitat: Arid shrublands, sagebrush steppes, and pinyon-juniper woodlands
description: A master seed hoarder that requires 870 to 1,000 seeds daily and can locate buried caches from underground using mysterious sensory abilities. This nocturnal rodent enters torpor during harsh seasons to conserve energy, slowing its metabolism to mere kilocalories per day.

name: Columbian Ground Squirrel
region: Rocky Mountains and high plains from Alberta and British Columbia south through Montana, Idaho, Washington, and Oregon
habitat: Alpine and subalpine meadows, grasslands, and mountain slopes at 700–8,000 feet elevation
description: This burrowing rodent hibernates for 8–9 months per year and emerges emaciated in spring, with mothers' milk increasing calcium concentration by 134% to fuel their young before the first hibernation. Known for greeting each other with kissing behavior and spending more time standing at attention than any other above-ground activity.

name: Columbian White-tailed Deer
region: Pacific Northwest (Oregon and Washington)
habitat: Riparian areas and brushy woodlots near the Columbia River
description: Once hunted to near extinction, this river-dwelling deer has made a remarkable recovery from fewer than 2,500 individuals in the 1980s to over 6,000 today. Unlike most white-tailed deer, females don't breed until 18 months of age and typically raise only a single fawn.

name: Common Bottlenose Dolphin
region: Atlantic and Pacific coasts of North America
habitat: Temperate and tropical oceans, coastal waters, bays, harbors
description: A highly intelligent marine mammal with a brain larger than humans', capable of echolocation at frequencies up to 120 kHz to navigate and hunt. These social dolphins communicate with individual signature whistles and can consume 10-20% of their body weight daily while diving deep into the ocean.

name: Common Minke Whale
region: Alaska, Pacific Northwest, Atlantic Coast, Gulf of St. Lawrence
habitat: Open ocean and coastal waters
description: The smallest rorqual whale, once ignored by whalers for its meager 150-300 kg calves but now a primary whaling target. Despite measuring up to 35 feet long, these baleen whales consume tons of fish using just 230-360 pairs of creamy-white baleen plates.

name: Common Squirrel Monkey
region: Florida (introduced populations)
habitat: Tropical rainforests, mangroves, and marshlands; middle canopy
description: A diminutive primate with exceptional agility, these monkeys produce genetically-encoded vocalizations identical to their wild counterparts regardless of isolation or deafness from birth. Troops of up to 500 individuals have been documented in undisturbed forests, communicating through specialized calls including caws, bawls, and shrieks.

name: Cotton Mouse
region: Southeastern United States
habitat: Hardwood forests, swamps, and woodland edges
description: A skilled architect that incorporates raw cotton into its nests, this small rodent survives wildfires by retreating into underground refuges where larger mouse species cannot follow. Despite weighing less than two ounces, it can produce up to four litters yearly with up to seven pups each.

name: Coues' Rice Rat
region: Southernmost Texas through Mexico and Central America
habitat: Marshes and wet habitats, also drier forests and shrublands
description: An excellent swimmer and diver despite its modest 43-82 gram frame, this semiaquatic rat builds suspended nests in reeds and can both climb vegetation and navigate water with remarkable agility. A year-round breeder, females produce litters of four young after just 21-28 days of pregnancy.

name: Cougar
region: Western North America, Florida, and isolated eastern populations
habitat: Mountains, deserts, forests, and various terrain types
description: North America's largest native cat, weighing up to 80 kg and capable of traveling vast distances in search of prey—one Connecticut cougar reportedly trekked 1,500 miles from South Dakota before being struck by an SUV. A master ambush predator that can remain motionless for hours before striking with lethal precision.

name: Coulee Chipmunk
region: Central Washington (Channeled Scablands)
habitat: Scablands and arid shrublands
description: A cryptic chipmunk species once mistaken for its close relatives, distinguished by its distinctly grayer coloration and ability to coexist in the same habitat as multiple other chipmunk species.

name: Coyote
region: Throughout North America from Canada to Central America; expanding eastward
habitat: Open plains, arid regions, deserts, and urban areas
description: A highly adaptable canine weighing 8-20 kg that has colonized nearly every North American environment, from deserts to cities. Known for its characteristic howl and remarkable intelligence, it sometimes mates with wolves to produce "coywolf" hybrids that demonstrate complex genetic admixture.

name: Coypu
region: Southeastern US, spreading northward; Louisiana, Chesapeake Bay, Atlantic Coast
habitat: Freshwater and brackish marshes, wetlands, riverbanks
description: A prolific South American rodent weighing up to 17 kg that consumes 25% of its body weight daily and can produce three litters within a single year. Highly destructive to wetlands, each individual can cause severe habitat degradation that converts marshes to open water.

name: Crawford's Gray Shrew
region: Southwestern US and northern Mexico
habitat: Desert scrubland and pack rat houses
description: One of the world's smallest mammals, weighing merely 3-5 grams with a heart rate of 1,000 beats per minute. This nocturnal desert dweller must consume up to 75% of its body weight daily and can starve to death within hours without food.

name: Creeping Vole
region: Pacific Northwest (British Columbia, Washington, Oregon, northern California)
habitat: Coniferous forests, woodlands, grasslands, and chaparral from sea level to 7,900 feet
description: The smallest vole in its range, weighing just 19 grams—barely more than a penny—yet capable of producing four to five litters per year with gestation lasting only 23 days. Uniquely, males possess an unusual sex chromosome system where the Y chromosome has been lost entirely.

name: Cuvier's Beaked Whale
region: Pacific and Atlantic coasts, Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean
habitat: Deep offshore pelagic waters (deeper than 1,000 ft)
description: Champion deep-diver of the mammal world, plunging to nearly 10,000 feet below the surface and remaining underwater for up to 3.7 hours while hunting squid and deep-sea fish in total darkness.

name: Dall Sheep
region: Alaska, Yukon, Northwest Territories, northern British Columbia
habitat: Alpine tundra, mountain meadows, steep rocky slopes
description: These arctic mountain climbers sport massive curling horns that grow in distinctive rings, allowing scientists to determine their exact age—much like counting tree rings. Dall sheep can lose up to 40% of their body weight during brutal winters, yet are known to butt gray wolves off cliff faces to survive.

name: Dall's Porpoise
region: Pacific coast from California to Alaska and Bering Sea
habitat: Cold ocean waters, offshore and coastal depths
description: The largest porpoise species, reaching up to 7.5 feet long and capable of diving to depths of 94 meters. Known for its distinctive 'rooster tail' spray created by rapid surface swimming and its playful behavior of bow-riding boats and larger whales.

name: Dark Kangaroo Mouse
region: Western US (Oregon, California, Nevada, Idaho, Utah)
habitat: Loose sand and gravels in Upper Sonoran life zone
description: This tiny hopper weighs just 13 grams but stores fat in its tail like a camel, growing it thick before winter hibernation and thin again in spring—a unique adaptation among North American small mammals. Perfectly adapted to desert life, it never needs to drink water, instead extracting all moisture from seeds it carries in cheek pouches back to its burrow.

name: Dark-nosed Small-footed Myotis
region: Western and central North America, from British Columbia to central Mexico and Oklahoma
habitat: Caves, mines, and rocky crevices in diverse terrain
description: A tiny nocturnal hunter with a distinctive dark nose, this bat has an impressively wide range spanning three countries despite being uncommon throughout its habitat. Using echolocation to catch insects mid-flight, it roosts in caves and mines across one of North America's most extensive bat territories.

name: Delmarva Fox Squirrel
region: Eastern Shore of Maryland and Virginia, historically Delmarva Peninsula
habitat: Mature hardwood and pine forests with open understory
description: Once hunted to near extinction with only 10% of its population remaining, this frosty silver squirrel has made a remarkable comeback through dedicated reintroduction efforts. A nimble tree-dweller reaching up to 30 inches in length, it can survive on acorns, hickory nuts, and pine cones found only in forest habitats with open space to forage.

name: Desert Bighorn Sheep
region: Southwestern US and northwestern Mexico
habitat: Desert mountains and rocky terrain in arid regions
description: A master climber of steep desert rock faces thanks to uniquely concave elastic hooves, capable of going weeks or even months without water by losing up to 30% of body weight and surviving on moisture from food and temporary rain pools. Older rams grow spiraling horns exceeding three feet in length that can weigh more than 30 pounds.

name: Desert Cottontail
region: Western US from Montana to Texas, Mexico
habitat: Desert grasslands, scrubland, pinyon-juniper forest
description: A swift desert dweller capable of hopping at over 30 mph in zigzag patterns to escape predators, with oversized ears making up 14% of its body that double as heat-regulation radiators. Despite producing multiple litters yearly, few kits survive to adulthood due to relentless pressure from nearly every desert carnivore.

name: Desert Kangaroo Rat
region: Southwestern US deserts (Death Valley, Great Basin, Mojave, Sonoran)
habitat: Sandy desert dunes with sparse vegetation
description: A master of desert survival, this nimble rodent can go 2-3 weeks without drinking water by extracting moisture from seeds and its own metabolism. When threatened by snakes, it fearlessly drums its feet and kicks sand to warn predators it's aware of their presence.

name: Desert Pocket Gopher
region: Southwest US (Texas, New Mexico) and northern Mexico (Chihuahua)
habitat: Sandy riverbanks and loose soil near the Rio Grande Valley and irrigation canals
description: A powerful burrower with massive clawed forelimbs, this rodent causes more soil disturbance than other gopher species and can reshape desert landscapes through its relentless digging. Found only in a narrow strip along the Rio Grande, its isolated populations make it one of North America's most geographically restricted pocket gophers.

name: Desert Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern US and northern Mexico
habitat: Arid desert with sparse vegetation, sandy washes, and desert scrub
description: A nocturnal desert dweller that can chew through hard-crusted soil to burrow and stores seeds in hidden caches throughout its territory. Despite living in harsh, arid environments, this tiny mouse survives on seeds alone and requires no additional water beyond its food.

name: Desert Red Bat
region: Western North America and Central America
habitat: Tree foliage in forests; hibernates under dead leaves
description: Unlike most bats that bear only one pup per season, this insectivore can give birth to as many as four pups at once, requiring four nipples instead of the typical two. Its red coat provides perfect camouflage among dead leaves during hibernation.

name: Desert Woodrat
region: Western US and Mexico (Oregon to California, Baja California)
habitat: Desert scrub, sagebrush, rocky slopes with cacti and yucca
description: A nocturnal pack rat that constructs elaborate fortress-like homes with up to six entrances and eight internal chambers, reinforced with jumping cholla joints for protection against predators. Uniquely capable of subsisting on creosote bushes and prickly pear cacti while maintaining water balance in harsh desert environments.

name: Douglas Squirrel
region: Pacific Northwest to central California
habitat: Coniferous forests, old-growth and mature second-growth
description: A vocal forest dweller that accumulates massive cone-scale middens up to several meters across through generations of feeding, earning the Native American name 'Pillillooeet' from its characteristic alarm call. Weighing just 150-300 grams, it nonetheless claims territorial dominance over 10,000 square meters of forest during winter months.

name: Dulzura Kangaroo Rat
region: Southern California, Colorado Desert, and northwestern Mexico (Baja California)
habitat: Sandy and gravelly soils in semi-desert, dry grassland, scrub, and coastal chaparral
description: A nocturnal hopper that can reach densities of up to 45 animals per hectare, propelling itself exclusively on powerful hind legs while using its long tail as a stabilizer. This seed-hoarder stuffs its cheek pouches with food and can live in burrows with multiple hidden entrances, emerging only a few hours each night.

name: Dusky-footed Woodrat
region: Pacific coast from Oregon to northern Baja California
habitat: Chaparral, juniper and mixed coniferous forests, near streams
description: A nocturnal packrat that constructs elaborate domed dens reaching several feet in height, often strategically placing California bay leaves around their nests to control flea infestations using toxic terpenes. These social architects build sprawling "communities" of dozens of interconnected nests and have been observed specializing their diets based on local vegetation, with groups just one kilometer apart preferring entirely different food sources.

name: Dwarf Shrew
region: Mountain regions of the southwestern and central US (Arizona, Colorado, Montana, Nebraska, New Mexico, South Dakota, Utah, Wyoming)
habitat: Alpine tundra, subalpine coniferous forests, and rocky mountain slopes
description: Weighing less than a penny at just 1.8 to 3.2 grams, this is one of North America's tiniest shrews—so elusive that only 18 were documented between 1895 and 1966, leading scientists to believe it was nearly extinct before a single study suddenly netted 24 individuals in pitfall traps.

name: Dwarf Sperm Whale
region: Pacific and Atlantic coasts (British Columbia to Chile; Virginia to Brazil)
habitat: Continental shelves and slopes in temperate and tropical oceans
description: A master of stealth, this tiny whale ejects a 100-square-meter cloud of red-brown fluid when startled—like an underwater squid. With only 14 to 24 teeth and a blunt snout perfectly adapted for suction feeding, it hunts deep-sea squid at depths over 1,500 meters.

name: Eastern Chipmunk
region: Eastern North America and southern Canada
habitat: Deciduous woodlands and urban parks with rocky areas and brush
description: This striped burrower can trill at 130 vibrations per minute and is the only living member of its genus, measuring just 12 inches long but capable of constructing elaborate underground tunnel systems with multiple entrances.

name: Eastern Cottontail
region: Eastern and south-central US, southern Canada, expanding northward
habitat: Open grasslands, meadows, and shrubby areas with escape cover nearby
description: North America's most abundant rabbit species, capable of running up to 18 mph in zigzag patterns to escape predators. Annual survival is just 20%, with most living only 15 months in the wild—but females can produce up to 35 young per year to compensate.

name: Eastern Deer Mouse
region: Eastern North America, east of the Mississippi River
habitat: Forests, woodlands, farmland, and open areas with tree cover or burrows
description: A prolific nocturnal rodent barely 3–4 inches long that can produce up to 14 litters in a single year and is often used in laboratory research due to its cleanliness and easy care. High-elevation populations possess specialized hemoglobin genes that allow them to thrive in environments with chronic oxygen deprivation and freezing temperatures.

name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
region: Eastern and Midwestern US, Southern Canada
habitat: Mature oak-hickory hardwood forests, urban parks and gardens
description: A master hoarder that creates thousands of food caches annually using precise spatial memory, yet forgets enough to accidentally plant entire forests. This acrobat can descend trees head-first by rotating its hind feet backward, and melanistic individuals exhibit 18% reduced heat loss compared to their gray cousins.

name: Eastern Harvest Mouse
region: Southeastern US, from Maryland to Florida and west to Texas and Ohio
habitat: Open grasslands, marshes, wet meadows, and abandoned fields
description: A nocturnal seed-eater with a distinctive bicolored tail and brown pelage marked by a dark lateral stripe, capable of reproducing again just 24 days after giving birth. Despite weighing only 1.2 grams at birth, this tiny rodent has an average lifespan of just 9.5 weeks.

name: Eastern Heather Vole
region: Canada, Great Lakes region
habitat: Coniferous forests with heavy undergrowth, peat bogs, semi-tundra
description: One of the few vertebrates capable of eating toxic sheep laurel bark, playing a crucial ecological role in nutrient recycling. This diminutive rodent weighs barely an ounce yet can survive harsh northern winters by constructing elaborate leaf and twig nests insulated by surrounding snow.

name: Eastern Meadow Vole
region: Eastern Canada and United States, from Labrador to South Carolina
habitat: Moist grasslands and meadows with dense vegetation
description: A prolific rodent capable of producing up to 17 litters in a single year, with one captive female birthing 83 young in twelve months. Despite their abundance, these voles rarely live more than two years in the wild, with mortality rates exceeding 50% in their first month of life.

name: Eastern Pipistrelle
region: Eastern and midwestern US, southern Canada, expanding westward to Colorado and Wyoming
habitat: Tree foliage, beard lichen, mines, and caves near water or forest edges
description: The smallest bat in eastern North America, weighing less than a penny, yet capable of living nearly 15 years and navigating through darkness using ultrasonic echolocation calls that form a distinctive hook-shaped pattern at 42 kHz. Once one of the most common bats in its range, populations have plummeted since 2006 due to white-nose syndrome.

name: Eastern Red Bat
region: Eastern North America, including southern Canada and northeastern Mexico
habitat: Wooded areas and forests; roosts in trees and leaf piles
description: Unlike most bat species that bear only one pup, females of this brick-red species typically birth three offspring at once, with some producing as many as five young. Despite weighing just 7-13 grams, they're swift fliers capable of preying on dozens of agricultural pest species including gypsy moths and tent caterpillars.

name: Eastern Small-footed Myotis
region: Eastern North America from New England to northern Georgia, westward to Arkansas; southern Ontario and Quebec
habitat: Rocky outcrops, cliff faces, and talus slopes in deciduous and coniferous forests
description: Among the smallest bats in eastern North America, weighing only 4-8 grams with an unmistakable dark facial mask and abnormally tiny feet—so small they can squeeze into rock crevices where other bats cannot reach, making them uniquely adapted but extremely vulnerable to disturbance.

name: Eastern Spotted Skunk
region: Eastern United States, southeastern Canada, northeastern Mexico
habitat: Forest edges, upland prairie grasslands, riparian corridors, abandoned farmland
description: This weasel-sized skunk performs a dramatic handstand before spraying, and is the most agile and active of all North American skunks. Weighing less than a pound, it can climb trees and famously straddles eggs to crack them open with its powerful forefeet.

name: Eastern Wolf
region: Great Lakes region (Minnesota, Wisconsin, Michigan), eastern Canada (Ontario, Quebec)
habitat: Boreal and mixed forests, forested areas with white-tailed deer populations
description: A genetically complex predator caught between wolf and coyote ancestry, with Great Lakes populations carrying 25% coyote DNA and Algonquin populations up to 40%—making it a living example of ancient hybridization that occurred thousands of years ago.

name: Eastern Woodrat
region: Central and Eastern United States, from Florida to New York and west to Colorado
habitat: Woodlands, swamps, grasslands, rocky bluffs, and coastal plains
description: A prolific pack rat that constructs elaborate multi-chambered dens up to 13 feet long and hoards enormous food caches—some containing up to 36 liters of plant material—to survive winters without hibernating. Known for its exceptionally long tail and compulsive collecting of both food and nonfood items, earning it the nickname 'trade rat.'

name: Eden's Whale
region: Not found in US/North America
habitat: Tropical and subtropical ocean waters
description: A sleek ocean giant reaching up to 50 feet long, this baleen whale can dive nearly 1,000 feet deep and employs acrobatic 'trap feeding' techniques to catch schools of small fish and shrimp. Distinguished by three longitudinal ridges on its rostrum, it's often mistaken for its faster cousin, the sei whale.

name: Elliot's Short-tailed Shrew
region: Central US from Iowa and Nebraska south to Texas and Louisiana
habitat: Grasslands, agricultural land, and woodland with heavy vegetation
description: This slate-grey insectivore hunts using echolocation despite its permanently closed eyelids, navigating home ranges of up to 1.36 acres in search of beetles, slugs, and earthworms. A single female can raise up to three litters annually, with young reaching full size in just one month.

name: European Fallow Deer
region: Scattered populations across Texas, Georgia, Illinois, Michigan, Kentucky, Tennessee, California, Pennsylvania
habitat: Mixed woodland and open grassland
description: This European import displays remarkable color variation, from deep black coats to pure white, with some populations producing long-haired variants sporting distinctive ear tufts. Males can exceed 330 pounds and leap up to 16 feet in length when threatened.

name: European Hare
region: Ontario, New York (introduced, limited populations)
habitat: Open fields with scattered brush and mixed farmland
description: A large, powerful-legged hare capable of reaching 70 km/h (43 mph) in open country, with elongated ears and a distinctive grizzled yellow-brown coat. Famous for its frenzied spring mating season—called "March madness"—when normally nocturnal hares engage in dramatic boxing matches and high-speed chases to find mates.

name: European Rabbit
region: Not native to North America; introduced to scattered regions including parts of the western US
habitat: Short grasslands with burrows, hedgerows, and woodland near feeding areas
description: An invasive burrowing rabbit that constructs elaborate underground warrens housing 2-10 individuals, with females being more territorial and skillful diggers than males. In its native Iberian range, this species has become endangered due to myxomatosis and habitat loss, causing the decline of its natural predators like the Iberian lynx.

name: Evening Bat
region: Midwestern and Eastern United States
habitat: Pine forests, riparian zones, open fields, tree cavities, and buildings
description: A diminutive night hunter weighing just 7–15 grams with a voracious appetite, capable of consuming spotted cucumber beetles that comprise up to 25% of its diet in some regions. Despite living only 4–6 years, this small bat compensates with reproductive output unmatched by its longer-lived cousins, often birthing twins.

name: Everglades Short-tailed Shrew
region: Florida
habitat: Everglades wetlands and subtropical forests
description: A venomous shrew found exclusively in Florida's Everglades, capable of delivering a toxic bite through specialized salivary glands—one of the few venomous mammals in North America.

name: False Killer Whale
region: Hawaii, Eastern North Pacific, occasional temperate waters
habitat: Open ocean and deep-water areas, tropical and subtropical regions
description: A deceptive deep-diving predator that can plunge nearly 3,000 feet and hold its breath for up to 18 minutes while hunting. Despite its misleading name, this apex dolphin forms unbreakable social bonds so strong that hundreds strand themselves together on beaches, sometimes with fatal consequences.

name: Fin Whale
region: All US coastal waters, Alaska to Gulf of Mexico
habitat: Open ocean, temperate to polar waters
description: The ocean's greyhound, this sleek cetacean can sustain speeds of 25 mph and burst up to 29 mph despite weighing up to 74 tons. Its asymmetrical coloring and 184-decibel calls are among the lowest-frequency sounds made by any animal on Earth.

name: Fisher
region: Boreal forests across Canada to northern United States; isolated populations in New England, Appalachian Mountains, Sierra Nevada, and Pacific Northwest
habitat: Old-growth boreal and mixed deciduous-conifer forests with continuous overhead cover
description: A forest-dwelling mustelid that hunts in trees with remarkable agility, rotating its hind paws nearly 180° to descend headfirst—one of the few mammals capable of this feat. Despite its misleading name, it rarely eats fish but is one of nature's few reliable predators of porcupines, killing them after 25–30 minutes of repeated biting attacks.

name: Florida Bonneted Bat
region: Southern Florida
habitat: Agricultural areas, longleaf pine forests, residential and school buildings
description: Florida's largest bat species, weighing only 40-65 grams, relies on an exceptionally narrow range in southern Florida where it roosts in tree cavities excavated by woodpeckers or in human structures. One of North America's most critically endangered mammals, with a population so small that individual weather changes could threaten the entire species.

name: Florida Mouse
region: Florida
habitat: Temperate grassland
description: Florida's only endemic rodent genus, this tiny mouse is found nowhere else on Earth and faces extinction as its grassland habitat vanishes to development.

name: Florida Salt Marsh Vole
region: Florida
habitat: High salt marshes near Juncus roemerianus and Distichlis spicata
description: Once widespread across the southeastern United States, this relict vole now survives in a single salt marsh in Florida with fewer than 70 individuals per hectare. A 1992 survey of 1,025 traps caught only a single specimen, making it one of North America's most critically endangered mammals.

name: Fog Shrew
region: Northern California and Oregon coasts
habitat: Moist coastal coniferous forests, chaparral, and marshy areas near creeks
description: The largest shrew on the Pacific Coast, this tiny insectivore weighs barely half an ounce yet hunts centipedes and spiders with surprising ferocity in foggy coastal forests.

name: Fox Squirrel
region: Eastern US, Great Plains, southern Canadian provinces
habitat: Open forest patches with oak, hickory, and pine trees; urban and suburban areas
description: North America's largest tree squirrel, capable of leaping 15 feet horizontally and free-falling 20 feet or more while landing gracefully on tree limbs. Known for their impressive vocabulary of clucking sounds and ability to cache thousands of nuts for winter survival.

name: Franklin's Ground Squirrel
region: Northern Great Plains and Midwest (Alberta to Indiana)
habitat: Tallgrass prairies with dense vegetation
description: An omnivorous ground squirrel that hibernates for eight months a year and can consume prey as large as fully-grown mallards, weighing up to 950 grams by fall despite starting spring at just 370 grams.

name: Fraser's Dolphin
region: Gulf of Mexico, Eastern Pacific (rare)
habitat: Deep tropical ocean waters
description: This deep-diving oceanic hunter feeds 200-500 meters below the surface using echolocation alone, swimming in dramatic high-speed formations numbering up to 1,000 individuals that chop up the water as they porpoise across the ocean.

name: Fresno Kangaroo Rat
region: San Joaquin Valley, California
habitat: Alkaline grasslands, saltbush scrub, and foothill shrublands
description: The smallest kangaroo rat in its genus, this nocturnal rodent is three times less active under moonlight and uses powerful hind limbs to bound across the valley floor like its larger marsupial namesake. Once widespread across the San Joaquin Valley, its range has shrunk to fragmented patches totaling just 20,000 square kilometers due to agricultural development.

name: Fringed Myotis
region: Western US, British Columbia, Mexico
habitat: Desert shrublands, sagebrush-grassland, woodland with Douglas fir and oak
description: A nimble nocturnal hunter with distinctive wire-like hairs fringing its tail membrane that help snare insects in mid-flight. Despite weighing less than a penny, females give birth to pups nearly a quarter their body weight.

name: Fulvous Harvest Mouse
region: Southwestern and South-Central US (Arizona, Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas, Missouri, Arkansas, Mississippi)
habitat: Grassy areas with shrubs, mesquite and pine/grass ecozones
description: A nocturnal master of adaptation, this tiny mouse survives harsh winters by growing thicker fur and torpidly reducing its body temperature during sleep, yet can recover from near-fatal hypothermia within moments of warming up. Builds intricate grass nests barely 3 inches in diameter and lives entirely off the ground in low vegetation.

name: Gambel's Deer Mouse
region: Southern California to Baja California
habitat: Scrublands, chaparral, and coastal sage brush
description: Once thought to be a western subspecies of the eastern deer mouse, genetic studies in 2017 revealed this tiny rodent to be its own distinct species—a taxonomic twist that rewrote mammalian classification. Island populations across the Channel Islands and Baja California's Pacific coast likely belong to this cryptic mouse.

name: Gaspé Shrew
region: Eastern Canada (Quebec and Maritime provinces)
habitat: Wet forests, sphagnum bogs, and marshy areas
description: A diminutive hunter weighing less than half an ounce, this shrew must eat nearly its own body weight in insects and invertebrates daily to survive. With a venomous bite—rare among North American shrews—it subdues prey far larger than itself.

name: Gemsbok
region: Southwestern US (New Mexico deserts)
habitat: Arid grasslands and desert basins
description: An African antelope introduced to New Mexico's deserts, capable of running at 60 km/h and equipped with straight horns averaging 85 cm in length. Thrives without drinking water by extracting moisture from melons and roots, making it dangerously well-adapted to spreading across North American grasslands.

name: Gervais' Beaked Whale
region: Eastern US coast, Atlantic waters
habitat: Deep ocean waters, offshore
description: A deep-diving cetacean that remained virtually unknown to science until 1998 despite frequent strandings; capable of dives lasting around an hour in waters over 1,500 meters deep. Females grow to 17 feet and weigh over 2,600 pounds, making them the largest of all mesoplodont whales.

name: Ghost-faced Bat
region: Southern Texas and Arizona
habitat: Caves, mines, and tunnels in humid, arid, and semi-arid regions below 3000m elevation
description: A peculiar nocturnal hunter with a distinctively 'smashed-in' face due to thick facial muscles and ears that join across its forehead. This heat-loving insectivore maintains an unusually high body temperature and can only survive in cold conditions below 10°C for a few hours before succumbing to hypothermia.

name: Giant Kangaroo Rat
region: Central California (San Joaquin Valley region)
habitat: Dry, sandy grasslands
description: The largest of over 20 kangaroo rat species, this master communicator drums its feet at up to 18 beats per second to warn of danger and attract mates. Once found across vast grasslands, it now survives in less than 2% of its original range.

name: Ginkgo-toothed Beaked Whale
region: Pacific Coast (California), rare vagrant
habitat: Deep tropical and temperate ocean waters
description: A mysterious deep-sea dweller so elusive that fewer than 20 strandings have ever been recorded worldwide. Males are uniquely among beaked whales never observed with battle scars, suggesting they settle disputes without combat.

name: Glacier Bay Water Shrew
region: Alaska
habitat: Near streams and water bodies
description: This tiny water-dwelling shrew can sprint across the surface of water thanks to specialized hairs on its feet, and relies on trapped air in its water-resistant fur to bob back to the surface after diving for aquatic prey.

name: Golden Mouse
region: Southeastern US, from Missouri to Virginia south to Texas, Gulf Coast, and Florida
habitat: Thick woodlands, swampy areas, vines, and shrubs with honeysuckle and greenbrier
description: This brilliant golden rodent can produce up to 17 litters in just 18 months, and newborns develop with remarkable speed—able to jump by just 15 days old and achieve independence within three weeks. Known for their prehensile tails and ability to share nests with up to eight other mice, they're one of nature's most social and prolific small mammals.

name: Golden-mantled Ground Squirrel
region: Rocky Mountains and western North America
habitat: Coniferous forests, meadows, and sagebrush with rocky areas
description: Distinguished by its striking reddish mantle across the shoulders and white-bordered black stripes along its back, this squirrel can create burrows up to 100 feet long and stores enough food to sustain itself through hibernation lasting several months.

name: Gray Bat
region: Southeastern US (Alabama, Arkansas, Kentucky, Missouri, Tennessee, and surrounding states)
habitat: Limestone caves near rivers and reservoirs
description: This cave-dependent insectivore congregates in massive colonies—95% of the entire species hibernates in just 15 caves, with nearly a third of all gray bats roosting in a single Alabama cave. Despite weighing only 7–16 grams, it can migrate up to 500 kilometers between summer and winter habitats.

name: Gray Fox
region: North America from southern Canada to northern South America; Pacific States, Great Lakes, and eastern US
habitat: Mixed wooded and agricultural land, deciduous forests, juniper and ponderosa pine forests
description: The only canid capable of climbing trees using its strong hooked claws, scaling vertical trunks up to 60 feet high and descending backwards like a domestic cat. Once the most common fox in eastern North America, it weighs only 8-15 pounds yet thrives in urban environments despite competition from larger predators.

name: Gray Seal
region: Northeastern US (Maine to Massachusetts), extending south to North Carolina
habitat: Coastal waters, rocky islands, and sandy beaches near shore
description: Once hunted to near extinction, these massive seals have made a remarkable comeback and can weigh up to 880 pounds—making them among the largest pinnipeds in the Atlantic. Known for their distinctive hook-shaped noses and surprising intelligence, they've been observed clapping their flippers underwater to communicate and even cannibalizing weaker pups to increase breeding success.

name: Gray Whale
region: Alaska, Western Canada, US West Coast
