habitat: Pacific Ocean coastal waters, arctic feeding grounds, warm breeding lagoons
description: Undertakes the longest migration of any mammal—a grueling 16,000–22,000 km annual round trip between Arctic feeding grounds and Mexican breeding lagoons. Despite their massive 41-ton frames, mothers fiercely defend calves against predators, earning them the fearsome nickname 'devil fish.'

name: Gray Wolf
region: Alaska, Canada, Northern Rockies; historically throughout continental North America
habitat: Forests, tundra, grasslands, mountains, and remote wilderness areas
description: A highly specialized pack hunter with a bite force capable of crushing bone, these apex predators can weigh up to 175 pounds and coordinate hunts that bring down moose weighing over 1,500 pounds by targeting vulnerable individuals with military precision.

name: Gray-collared Chipmunk
region: Arizona and New Mexico
habitat: Mountain coniferous forests, ponderosa pine and spruce-fir forests
description: A skilled climber with a distinctive gray face and collar, this chipmunk caches food in hidden holes and can sustain itself through winter on stored acorns and seeds without fully hibernating. Population density can quadruple from spring to late summer, peaking at 12 individuals per hectare.

name: Gray-footed Chipmunk
region: Southwestern US (New Mexico, West Texas)
habitat: Temperate mountain forests with mixed oak, pine, and fir trees
description: A nimble rock-dweller of the southwestern mountains that stuffs its cheeks with acorns, pine seeds, and insects before retreating into rocky crevices. Young chipmunks reach full size by October after a single annual breeding cycle, with females producing up to four offspring.

name: Gray-tailed Vole
region: Willamette Valley, Oregon and Clark County, Washington
habitat: Agricultural areas, pastures, hayfields, and grasslands
description: A burrowing rodent that constructs elaborate tunnel networks to survive frequent flooding, capable of gathering in groups of 20-30 on fence posts when waters rise. Females can reproduce at just 18 days old, producing an average of 4.5 pups per litter.

name: Greater Long-nosed Bat
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico, Texas) and Central Mexico
habitat: Desert scrub, open woodlands, and caves
description: A nectar-feeding specialist weighing just 0.85 ounces with an elongated snout and extraordinary 24-hour migration between Mexico and the American Southwest, following blooming agave and cacti across the desert.

name: Green Monkey
region: Southern Florida (Broward County)
habitat: Wooded areas, coastal regions
description: An introduced Old World monkey with golden-green fur that communicates using distinct predator-specific alarm calls and can live in groups of up to 80 individuals. Males reach sexual maturity in five years while females mature in just two years.

name: Grizzly Bear
region: Alaska, Western Canada, Northwestern US (Montana, Idaho, Wyoming, Washington)
habitat: Mountain forests, coastal areas, tundra, river valleys
description: One of North America's largest land predators, capable of running 48 km/h (30 mph) and weighing up to 540 kg (1,200 lb) in coastal regions where salmon-rich diets fuel massive growth. Despite being carnivores, they obtain 80-90% of their diet from plants, making them opportunistic omnivores that can kill up to 51% of elk and moose calves born in a single year.

name: Groundhog
region: Eastern United States, Canada, Alaska
habitat: Woodlands, grasslands, open fields, and woodland edges
description: A master excavator capable of removing 640 pounds of soil from a single burrow, this rodent's incisors grow 1.5 millimeters weekly and are worn down at the same rate through constant gnawing. Despite its stocky appearance, it can climb trees and swim with surprising agility when escaping predators.

name: Guadalupe Fur Seal
region: Southern California, western Mexico
habitat: Open ocean and rocky island caves
description: Nearly hunted to extinction by the late 1800s, this seal was rediscovered in a cave and has since recovered to an estimated 34,000-44,000 individuals. Males can weigh over 400 pounds and dive to depths of 250 feet to hunt squid and fish exclusively at night.

name: Gulf Coast Kangaroo Rat
region: Southeastern Texas and coastal islands
habitat: Sandy dunes and sparse mesquite savannah
description: This nocturnal desert dweller uses its oversized cheek pouches to transport seeds back to its burrow, and can be distinguished from similar species by its notably shorter, uncrested tail and coarser fur.

name: Gunnison's Prairie Dog
region: Four Corners region (Arizona, New Mexico, Utah, Colorado)
habitat: High desert grasslands, sagebrush meadows, 6,000–10,000 feet elevation
description: These burrowing rodents possess one of the most advanced natural languages in the animal kingdom, with up to 11 distinct warning calls that can be heard nearly a mile away and last up to 30 minutes. Uniquely among prairie dogs, Gunnison's species has 40 chromosomes instead of 50, making them chromosomally distinct from all other prairie dog species.

name: Haida Ermine
region: Southeast Alaska and Haida Gwaii, British Columbia
habitat: Temperate rainforest
description: A hybrid species that emerged 375,000 years ago when two ermine species became isolated on island glacial refugia and interbred, creating the smallest ermine subspecies in North America with a chocolate-brown summer coat and pure white winter coat despite minimal snow coverage.

name: Hairy-legged Vampire Bat
region: Southern Texas (rare vagrant)
habitat: Tropical and subtropical forests, caves, and mines
description: A blood-feeding bat weighing barely an ounce, it sports 26 teeth—eight more than its common vampire bat cousin—and can share meals with roost mates through regurgitated blood exchanges. Once thought harmless to humans, it has now been documented feeding on human blood and poses a potential rabies transmission risk.

name: Hairy-tailed Mole
region: Eastern Canada and northeastern United States
habitat: Deciduous and coniferous forests, oldfields, and roadsides with dry, loose soils
description: This underground digger weighs merely 55 grams but possesses broad, spade-shaped paws capable of excavating extensive tunnel networks through forest soil. Virtually blind with fur-covered eyes, it relies instead on sensitive whiskers and touch receptors to hunt earthworms and grubs in complete darkness.

name: Hall's Pocket Gopher
region: Western US (Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska)
habitat: Grasslands and prairie regions
description: A genetically distinct burrowing rodent that was long mistaken for other pocket gopher species until chromosomal evidence revealed it as a separate lineage with no gene flow to its closest relatives. Two subspecies inhabit different regions, with the smaller Nebraska population named after renowned mammalogist Eugene Raymond Hall.

name: Harbor Seal
region: Pacific Coast (California to Alaska), Atlantic Coast (Maine to North Carolina)
habitat: Coastal waters, rocky shores, harbors, and estuaries
description: A master diver capable of plunging deeper than 500 meters in search of fish, this seal can double its body weight in just four to six weeks on its mother's fat-rich milk. Once hunted to near extinction in eastern waters, they've made a remarkable comeback and now call places like New York Harbor home.

name: Harbour Porpoise
region: Northern Atlantic coast, Gulf of Maine, Gulf of Saint Lawrence, Alaska, British Columbia, California
habitat: Coastal waters, fjords, bays, estuaries, and river mouths in cooler regions
description: A master hunter of the deep that can consume up to 550 fish per hour at night with a 90% success rate, despite being one of the smallest cetaceans at just 1.4 to 1.9 meters long. These echolocation experts produce rapid clicks between 1,000 and 2,200 hertz to navigate and hunt in coastal waters.

name: Harp Seal
region: Northern Atlantic coast, Arctic waters
habitat: Pack ice in Atlantic and Arctic Oceans
description: This ice-loving seal can dive over 500 meters deep and remain submerged for more than 20 minutes, yet spends nearly half its underwater time resting at the surface to conserve energy. Newborn pups gain over 2.2 kilograms per day on their mother's milk—which reaches 40% fat by weaning—allowing them to triple their weight in just 12 days.

name: Harris's Antelope Squirrel
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico) and Sonora, Mexico
habitat: Sonoran Desert and arid scrubland
description: A heat-defying desert dweller that holds its tail over its back like a parasol and spreads-eagles against the ground to dump excess body heat in the scorching Sonoran Desert. Despite weighing only 4–5 ounces, this pint-sized squirrel maintains a blazing body temperature of 97–107°F and hunts small rodents and carrion alongside its diet of cacti and mesquite beans.

name: Hawaiian Hoary Bat
region: Hawaiian Islands only
habitat: Forests, agricultural fields, pastures, and human-populated areas from sea level to 7,500 feet
description: Hawaii's only native terrestrial mammal, this silver-furred bat hunts using echolocation and can travel up to 12 miles in a single night while snatching insects mid-flight. Mothers typically give birth to twins, which fledge in just 6 to 7 weeks.

name: Hawaiian Monk Seal
region: Hawaiian Islands
habitat: Sandy beaches, volcanic rock, and deep ocean coral beds
description: Hawaii's only native seal, capable of diving deeper than 1,800 feet and holding its breath for up to 20 minutes while hunting octopus and lobster on the seafloor. With fewer than 1,400 individuals remaining, this earless seal has the lowest genetic diversity of all phocid species.

name: Hector's Beaked Whale
region: Not found in North America; Southern Hemisphere only
habitat: Deep ocean waters in cool temperate zones
description: One of the ocean's most elusive cetaceans, this deep-diving whale reaches only 4.2 meters long and has been confirmed sighted in the wild just once. Males bear distinctive flattened triangular teeth and body scars suggesting intense battles with rivals, yet little is known about their behavior or diet in the mysterious depths they inhabit.

name: Heermann's Kangaroo Rat
region: California, from Lake Tahoe to Point Conception
habitat: Coastal plains and ridges with shallow soil, up to 3,000 feet elevation
description: This broad-faced nocturnal rodent spends up to 23 hours per day in underground burrows, emerging only at night to forage for seeds and insects. Capable of hopping up to 30 inches in a single bound using its distinctive tail for balance.

name: Himalayan Tahr
region: New Mexico
habitat: Rocky mountain slopes and alpine terrain
description: An agile mountain climber with specialized hooves featuring rubber-like cores that grip smooth rock like adhesive pads, allowing confident traversal of sheer alpine terrain. Males can weigh up to 161 pounds and sport impressive curved horns reaching 18 inches in length, which they use as battering rams during intense mating season contests.

name: Hispid Cotton Rat
region: Southern US to southern Canada; Arizona to Virginia, Gulf Coast to Nebraska
habitat: Grasslands, prairie, overgrown fields, croplands, and grassy clearings with shrub cover
description: One of North America's most prolific rodents, capable of producing two to several litters per year with females reaching sexual maturity in as little as 30-40 days. Populations can reach densities of over 65 rats per hectare in ideal habitat.

name: Hispid Pocket Mouse
region: Great Plains from North Dakota to central Mexico
habitat: Sandy upland grasslands with sparse vegetation and bare ground patches
description: One of the largest pocket mice, this bristly-furred forager is notable for its mound-building behavior around burrow entrances, similar to pocket gophers but far smaller. Capable of bearing two or more litters per year, it thrives in the sparse, sandy soils of the Great Plains.

name: Hoary Bat
region: Throughout North America from Canada to Guatemala
habitat: Woodland and coniferous forests; hunts over open areas and lakes
description: A tireless nocturnal hunter that can cover an impressive 24 miles in a single foraging flight, migrating thousands of miles between Central America and Canada with pinpoint precision. Its frosted white-tipped fur gives it a distinctive hoary appearance, and it's the largest bat normally found in Canada.

name: Hoary Marmot
region: Northwestern North America, Alaska to Washington/Idaho
habitat: Alpine meadows and rocky terrain above tree line, sea level to 8,200 feet elevation
description: The largest North American ground squirrel, weighing up to 13.5 pounds in autumn—nearly double its spring weight—and famous for its high-pitched warning whistle that alerts entire colonies to danger from up to 36 individuals strong.

name: Hooded Skunk
region: Southwestern United States
habitat: Grasslands, deserts, and mountain foothills near water sources
description: Armed with a potent anal spray composed of seven volatile sulfur compounds, this skunk uses its elongated tail and distinctive white neck ruff as warning signals before unleashing its pungent defense. In Costa Rica populations, these clever foragers have learned to hurl bird eggs between their hind legs to crack them open.

name: Hopi Chipmunk
region: Southwestern US (Colorado, Utah, Arizona)
habitat: Rocky pinyon-juniper forests and canyon country
description: A naturally timid acrobat of the canyon rocks, weighing just 52-62 grams yet capable of navigating sheer cliff faces with incredible sure-footedness. Even when raised in captivity, these chipmunks never become tame, always maintaining their wild wariness as they zip between boulders watching for hawks.

name: House Mouse
region: Throughout continental North America
habitat: Human buildings, agricultural areas, open fields, urban structures
description: A prolific rodent capable of producing 5 to 10 litters per year with an average of 6-8 pups each, allowing populations to explode rapidly in favorable conditions. Can jump vertically up to 45 centimeters despite weighing only 40-45 grams.

name: Hubbs' Beaked Whale
region: Pacific coast of North America, San Diego to Vancouver Island
habitat: Deep ocean waters, intermediate and deep-water masses
description: A deep-diving cetacean distinguished by a striking white cap on its head and extensive scarring across its body. Known from only 31 strandings, this elusive whale hunts squid and deep-sea fish in waters along the Pacific coast using echolocation pulses that remain poorly understood by scientists.

name: Humboldt's Flying Squirrel
region: Pacific Coast (British Columbia to Southern California)
habitat: Coniferous and mixed coniferous forests
description: A strictly nocturnal glider that can traverse between trees with remarkable agility, though it awkwardly stumbles on the ground. Under ultraviolet light, this squirrel's fur glows an eerie pink—a phenomenon whose true purpose remains mysteriously debated among scientists.

name: Humpback Whale
region: Coastal waters from Alaska to California; seasonal migrations along Atlantic coast from New England to the Caribbean
habitat: Ocean waters; migrate between polar feeding grounds and tropical breeding areas
description: This 40-ton leviathan migrates up to 16,000 km annually between polar and tropical waters, using coordinated bubble-net formations with other whales to trap prey. Males produce complex songs lasting up to 7 hours, audible for at least 10 km underwater.

name: Idaho Pocket Gopher
region: Northwestern US (Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, Utah)
habitat: Savannas, shrublands, and grasslands
description: A solitary burrowing rodent weighing less than 3.2 ounces that remains active year-round, excavating and storing soil in its own personal underground tunnel system. Its slender skull and long baculum bone make it distinctly adapted for a subterranean lifestyle.

name: Indian Hog Deer
region: Southern United States (introduced populations in Texas and other states)
habitat: Grassy flood plains, riverine valleys, and open meadows
description: This diminutive deer runs like a hog with its head hung low to slip under forest obstacles rather than leap over them, weighing only 50 kilograms despite its stocky, solidly-built frame. Males display distinctive three-pointed antlers with an unusually acute angle between the brow tine and main beam.

name: Indiana Bat
region: Eastern and Midwestern United States
habitat: Hardwood and hardwood-pine forests; hibernates in caves and mines
description: This tiny insectivore weighs less than a penny but can consume millions of insects in a single night alongside its colony. Capable of living over 20 years, it hibernates in massive clusters of up to 5,215 bats per square meter.

name: Insular Vole
region: Bering Sea islands (Alaska)
habitat: Damp lowlands, mountain slopes, and rye grass-covered beaches
description: Found only on remote Alaskan islands in the Bering Sea, this tiny vole shares its harsh habitat with Arctic foxes and seabirds that hunt it relentlessly. Despite its extremely limited range, it remains one of the least threatened rodents due to its stable island populations.

name: Inyo Shrew
region: Western US (California, Nevada, Utah)
habitat: High-altitude rocky mountains, riparian zones, red fir forests
description: A ferocious insect hunter weighing less than a penny, this pale gray shrew molts twice yearly and remains active throughout winter in alpine regions above 7,500 feet. Despite its diminutive frame of just 3-4 inches, it consumes windblown insects left at the highest elevations where few other mammals dare venture.

name: Island Fox
region: Channel Islands of California
habitat: Island chaparral, temperate forest, and grassland with dense woody shrubs
description: North America's smallest fox species, weighing just 1-2.8 kg with a notably shortened tail containing two fewer vertebrae than its mainland relatives. Once hunted to the brink of extinction by golden eagles and disease, this docile island dweller has made a stunning comeback from a low of just 15 individuals to over 8,700 across the Channel Islands.

name: Jaguar
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico, Texas)
habitat: Tropical and subtropical forests, wetlands, riverine areas
description: The Americas' apex predator employs a lethal bite force of nearly 5,000 Newtons to pierce turtle shells and deliver fatal brain strikes between mammalian prey's ears. Once ranging across 19 million square kilometers, this third-largest cat species has lost over half its historic territory in just 100 years.

name: Jaguarundi
region: Southern Texas (possibly extirpated)
habitat: Open scrublands, thorn scrubs, deciduous forests, and areas with vegetative cover
description: A slender cat twice the size of a house cat that hunts primarily during daylight hours—unusual among its spotted relatives. Despite its small frame of just 3.5–7 kg, it can leap up to 2 meters into the air to snatch birds mid-flight.

name: Japanese Macaque
region: South Texas (introduced population)
habitat: Arid brushland, ranch-style enclosed environments
description: An intelligent primate capable of learning complex behaviors like washing food and seasoning it with seawater, with females establishing dominance hierarchies that can last generations through matrilineal succession.

name: Keen's Myotis
region: Pacific Northwest (British Columbia, Washington, Alaska)
habitat: Coastal forests, urban areas, trees and rock crevices
description: A diminutive nocturnal hunter weighing less than a third of an ounce, this long-eared bat can live over 12 years in the wild—an impressive lifespan for such a tiny creature. Often mistaken for its close relative, it prowls coastal skies for insects with characteristic dark patches marking its shoulders.

name: Key Deer
region: Florida Keys
habitat: Mangroves, pine rocklands, hardwood hammocks, freshwater wetlands
description: The smallest North American deer species, weighing only 25–34 kg, with males and females so unafraid of humans that they frequently wander into residential yards and roadsides—a behavior that results in 125–150 road kills per year, accounting for 70% of annual deaths.

name: Key Largo Woodrat
region: Florida Keys (Key Largo)
habitat: Tropical hardwood hammocks
description: A critically endangered rat found only in a 2,000-acre patch of northern Key Largo, famous for constructing elaborate stick nests up to shoulder height that may be centuries old and reused by successive generations.

name: Killer Whale
region: Alaska, Pacific Northwest (California to Washington), Atlantic waters around Iceland
habitat: Coastal and open ocean waters, preferring higher latitudes
description: The largest oceanic dolphin and apex predator of the sea, capable of hunting prey as massive as blue whales and coordinating sophisticated attacks across family groups spanning four generations. Despite their fearsome reputation, no fatal attacks on humans have ever been documented in the wild.

name: Kit Fox
region: Southwestern US and northern Mexico (Oregon to Texas)
habitat: Arid and semi-arid desert scrub, chaparral, and grasslands
description: One of North America's smallest canids, with oversized ears spanning nearly 4 inches that grant exceptional hearing and heat dissipation abilities. Despite weighing only 1.6-2.7 kg, kit foxes can reach 40 km/h but tire easily, relying instead on cryptic coloration and lightning-quick directional changes to evade predators.

name: Knox Jones's Pocket Gopher
region: Central western Texas and southeastern New Mexico
habitat: Deep sandy soils in arid regions
description: A master burrower with oversized clawed forelimbs, this diminutive rodent weighs less than a deck of cards yet was only recognized as its own species in 1989 after genetic testing proved it distinct from its nearly identical cousin. Its preference for sandy soils over harder earth made it invisible to science for decades.

name: Kodiak Bear
region: Southwest Alaska (Kodiak Archipelago)
habitat: Coastal islands with mixed forests, tundra, mountains, and salmon streams
description: The largest brown bear subspecies and one of only two bears rivaling polar bears in size, with mature males averaging 1,052–1,177 lbs and capable of reaching 1.5 meters tall on all fours. Genetically isolated for 10,000+ years, these apex predators have learned to coexist peacefully in groups of up to 60 bears along salmon streams through complex communication and social structure.

name: Least Chipmunk
region: Western North America from New Mexico to Canada, including Michigan and Wisconsin
habitat: Sagebrush, coniferous woodlands, alpine meadows, and tundra edges
description: The smallest chipmunk species and most widespread across North America, measuring just 6-10 inches long. Survives harsh winters by entering torpor rather than hibernating, waking to munch on cached food stored deep in burrows.

name: Least Weasel
region: Northern US (Great Plains, Northeast, Alaska), Canada
habitat: Fields, open woodland, grasslands, rocky areas
description: Despite weighing as little as 1 ounce, this fierce predator has a bite force stronger than a lion, tiger, or bear relative to body size, and can kill prey five to ten times its own weight.

name: Lesser Long-nosed Bat
region: Southwestern US (California, Arizona, New Mexico) - summer migrants only
habitat: Semi-arid grassland, scrub, and desert with night-blooming cacti
description: A tiny nectar-feeding bat weighing less than an ounce that migrates up to 1,600 kilometers annually, following the seasonal bloom of night-flowering cacti and agaves across Central America.

name: Little Brown Bat
region: Throughout North America from Alaska and Canada to Southern California and Northern Arizona
habitat: Caves, mines, tree hollows, and buildings; forages near water and forest edges
description: Despite weighing less than half an ounce, lactating females consume nearly 85% of their own body weight in insects nightly—enough to fuel a pup that can reach adult size in just three weeks. A master of echolocation, this common bat can emit 20 ultrasonic calls per second to hunt in complete darkness.

name: Little Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, California, Idaho, Nevada, Oregon, Utah), Baja California, and Sonora
habitat: Arid and semiarid grasslands with sagebrush and scrubby vegetation
description: A nocturnal seed-hoarder with an impressively long tail, this tiny rodent became an unlikely space explorer when five of its kind orbited the Moon 75 times aboard Apollo 17 in December 1972, with four surviving the historic journey.

name: Llano Pocket Gopher
region: Central Texas
habitat: Loamy soils suitable for digging
description: A master tunneler that constructs elaborate underground burrow systems with multiple chambers, food caches, and vertical corkscrew tunnels to evade predators. Males reach 18 cm in length and are so genetically distinct from their close relatives that scientists initially needed DNA sequencing to confirm their species status.

name: Lodgepole Chipmunk
region: California Sierra Nevada, Lake Tahoe area
habitat: Subalpine coniferous forests (lodgepole, Jeffrey, and sugar pine)
description: A striped mountain dweller that hibernates for five to six months and disperses fungi crucial to forest survival through its droppings. Despite weighing only 55 grams, it plays an outsized ecological role in maintaining Sierra Nevada ecosystems.

name: Long-beaked Common Dolphin
region: U.S. West Coast, Northwest Atlantic from North Carolina to Newfoundland
habitat: Coastal and offshore ocean waters, continental shelf edges
description: The most abundant cetacean on Earth with a global population of six million, capable of diving to 200 meters and producing signature whistles that act as individual acoustic identities.

name: Long-eared Chipmunk
region: Central and northern Sierra Nevada, California and Nevada
habitat: High-elevation coniferous forests and alpine meadows
description: Sporting the longest ears of any chipmunk species, this bright red-brown rodent displays striking white ear patches and nine alternating dark and pale stripes running down its back. It can weigh up to 105 grams and hibernates for four months each winter in underground burrows.

name: Long-eared Myotis
region: Western Canada, Western US, Baja California
habitat: Semiarid shrublands, shortgrass prairie, subalpine forests, rock crevices
description: This pale brown bat uses its robust molars and specially adapted jaw to crack open beetle carapaces with crushing force. It hunts across diverse elevations from sea level to 9,280 feet, switching between aerial pursuit and ground gleaning with remarkable echolocation precision.

name: Long-finned Pilot Whale
region: Eastern US and Canada coasts, Atlantic
habitat: Deep ocean waters, continental shelves
description: A highly intelligent oceanic dolphin with more neocortical neurons than any mammal studied—nearly twice as many as humans. These social giants reach lengths of 25 feet and form lifelong family units, staying with their mothers even after reaching sexual maturity.

name: Long-legged Myotis
region: Western North America from Alaska to Mexico
habitat: Mountain forests, woodlands, and riparian zones
description: This nimble flyer sports fur extending down its wings to its elbows and knees—a rare feature among myotis bats—and can remain active in temperatures as low as 15°C by entering torpor. Despite weighing just 7.5 grams, it's the second-largest myotis in the western United States.

name: Long-tailed Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, California, Nevada, Utah) and Baja California
habitat: Desert scrubland and arid regions
description: This tiny desert rodent sports an exceptionally long tail relative to its body size, which it uses for balance while navigating rocky desert terrain. Despite its diminutive frame, it's remarkably adapted to arid environments where it forages for seeds and insects.

name: Long-tailed Shrew
region: Atlantic Canada and Northeastern US, Appalachian Mountains south to North Carolina
habitat: Rocky mountain slopes, forest streams, and crevices in deciduous or evergreen forests
description: This tiny shrew uses its tail—comprising 80-90% of its body length—for balance while navigating rocky crevices where it hunts insects and spiders, weighing only 3-8 grams despite being a formidable predator of invertebrates.

name: Long-tailed Vole
region: Western North America from Alaska to the Southwest US
habitat: Alpine meadows, shrubby areas, coniferous forests, and sagebrush habitats near streams
description: This tiny rodent weighing just 1.8 ounces possesses a tail longer than any other vole species, extending more than one-third of its 7-inch body length. Despite their solitary nature, long-tailed voles can raise up to four litters per year and respond to the ultrasonic distress cries of their newborns.

name: Long-tailed Weasel
region: Southern Canada through continental US and Mexico, Central and northern South America
habitat: Open grasslands, meadows, and areas with ground burrows; distributed across varied elevations
description: A fearless micro-predator that hunts animals far larger than itself, this aggressive carnivore kills with surgical precision—a single bite to the head for small prey, or a climbing strike to the neck for rabbits. Its black-tipped tail acts as a decoy, distracting predators while the weasel escapes.

name: Louisiana Black Bear
region: Louisiana, Mississippi, East Texas, Arkansas
habitat: Mississippi River Valley, Atchafalaya River Basin, floodplain forests
description: Once hunted to near extinction, this subspecies has made a remarkable comeback through the restoration of over 600,000 acres of forestland, earning its delisting from the Endangered Species Act in 2016. Known for traveling vast distances, individuals have been spotted far outside traditional bear habitat across Louisiana.

name: Lower Keys Marsh Rabbit
region: Florida Keys
habitat: Salt marshes and freshwater marshes with herbaceous vegetation
description: One of North America's rarest rabbits, with a population of only ~150 individuals confined to a handful of Lower Keys islands. This pocket-sized marsh dweller weighs just 1-1.4 kg and faces imminent extinction from feral cats, rising sea levels, and habitat loss.

name: Margay
region: Locally extinct in Texas; formerly southern US
habitat: Dense tropical and cloud forests
description: A master tree-dwelling acrobat that can rotate its ankles 180 degrees and leap horizontally up to 12 feet while hunting birds and monkeys in the canopy. This diminutive cat is so skilled at mimicking the calls of tamarin infants that it can lure its prey directly to its waiting claws.

name: Marsh Rabbit
region: Eastern and Southern US coastal regions, Virginia to Alabama and Florida Keys
habitat: Freshwater and brackish marshes, swamps, and mangrove wetlands near water
description: A semi-aquatic cottontail that walks on all fours like a cat and can remain submerged in muddy water with only eyes and nose exposed. Despite short hind legs, it's an excellent swimmer and can produce up to 6 litters annually with 15-20 young per year.

name: Marsh Rice Rat
region: Eastern and Southern US, from New Jersey and Kansas to Florida and northeastern Mexico
habitat: Wetlands, swamps, and salt marshes
description: A semiaquatic rodent weighing only 40–80 grams with specialized webbed hind feet and silvery-tipped fur that traps air when swimming to increase buoyancy and reduce heat loss. Despite being preyed upon by barn owls and rarely living more than a year in the wild, this adaptable rice-eater harbors a hantavirus that can infect humans.

name: Marsh Shrew
region: Pacific Northwest coast from British Columbia to northern California
habitat: Wetlands and marshes with dense forest cover near streams and riparian areas
description: This tiny 16 cm mammal can scurry across water for up to 5 seconds by trapping air in its fur, moving like a whirligig beetle with its powerful hind legs and distinctive long snout.

name: Mazama Pocket Gopher
region: Pacific Northwest (Washington, Oregon, Northern California)
habitat: Prairie grasslands with well-drained glacial soil
description: A diminutive burrower capable of turning over 3–7 tons of soil per acre annually, transforming prairie ecosystems and creating homes for countless other species with its powerful claws and tireless digging.

name: Meadow Jumping Mouse
region: Continental US from Atlantic coast to Great Plains, Canada to Alaska south to Georgia, Alabama, Arizona, and New Mexico
habitat: Moist grasslands and meadows with nearby streams, ponds, or marshes; high herbaceous cover with open areas preferred
description: A diminutive rodent with disproportionately large hind feet that can leap 2-3 feet in a single bound—roughly 12 times its body length. Before hibernation, this mouse balloons to 35 grams, nearly doubling its summer weight to survive months of dormancy.

name: Melon-headed Whale
region: Hawaii, occasionally Gulf of Mexico
habitat: Deep tropical and subtropical oceanic waters
description: These highly social cetaceans travel in massive herds of 100–500 individuals, with rare super-pods reaching up to 2,000, and dive to depths exceeding 1,500 feet to hunt squid under cover of darkness. Their triangular head shape and 20–25 pairs of needle-like teeth distinguish them from similar species despite their diminutive 9-foot frame.

name: Merriam's Chipmunk
region: Central and southern California, northern Baja California
habitat: Dry scrublands and chaparral in mountainous areas
description: This diminutive rodent uses a unique courtship ritual where females call for 10-15 minutes to attract males, who respond by leaping around before the entire mating process concludes in just 15 seconds. Armed with 22 teeth perfectly adapted for cracking seeds and nuts, it's a master of rapid-fire reproduction.

name: Merriam's Ground Squirrel
region: Western US (Oregon, Idaho, Nevada)
habitat: Arid sagebrush chaparral and grasslands
description: A cryptic grey squirrel that spends eight months of the year hibernating underground, emerging only in early spring to feed on seeds, roots, and insects before retreating again by August. Can only be reliably distinguished from similar species through genetic testing.

name: Merriam's Kangaroo Rat
region: Southwestern US, Baja California, northern Mexico
habitat: Desert scrub, sagebrush steppe, pinyon-juniper woodland, Joshua tree forests
description: A bipedal desert hopper with kangaroo-like hind feet and a distinctive hair-tufted tail that acts like an arrow's fletching to stabilize its movements. This nocturnal seed-hoarder avoids moonlit nights to escape predators, storing hundreds of seeds in underground chambers and extracting water from its food rather than drinking.

name: Merriam's Pocket Mouse
region: Southwest US and Northeast Mexico
habitat: Shortgrass prairie, desert scrub, and arid shrubland
description: This tiny nocturnal rodent survives up to four years without drinking water, extracting all moisture from seeds stored in its cheek pouches. At temperatures below 50°F, it enters a death-like torpor from which it mysteriously revives when warmed.

name: Merriam's Shrew
region: Western United States and extreme southern British Columbia
habitat: Unknown (limited ecological data available)
description: A tiny insectivore with a metabolism so rapid it must eat constantly throughout the day to survive. One of the smallest mammals in North America, weighing less than a penny.

name: Mexican Fox Squirrel
region: Southeastern Arizona (Chiricahua Mountains)
habitat: Mixed pine-oak and conifer forests, riparian areas with cottonwoods
description: A surprisingly silent tree dweller weighing around 25 ounces, this squirrel forages year-round in forests maintained by natural fire and uses its charcoal tail frosted with white as a striking beacon through the canopy. When startled, it barks and chucks from safe perches rather than fleeing, preferring stealth over speed.

name: Mexican Free-tailed Bat
region: Southern continental US through Mexico and Central America
habitat: Caves and building roosting sites
description: This tiny insectivore holds the record for fastest horizontal flight speed at 160 km/h (99 mph) and flies higher than any other bat, reaching altitudes of 3,300 meters. Colonies numbering up to 20 million individuals roost together, consuming up to 30,000 pounds of insects nightly.

name: Mexican Gray Squirrel
region: Florida Keys
habitat: Tropical trees and palms
description: An introduced species that has become a destructive force in Florida's ecosystems, consuming palm fibers and killing Thrinax radiata palms while nesting in unconventional locations like hurricane debris.

name: Mexican Ground Squirrel
region: Northern Mexico, Texas, Southeastern New Mexico
habitat: Flat, brushy, grassy areas with sandy or gravelly soil
description: A small burrowing rodent with nine distinctive rows of white spots on its back, this ground squirrel has evolved remarkable resistance to western diamondback rattlesnake venom through a specialized antihemorrhagic factor. Each individual maintains multiple burrows with up to five escape tunnels, allowing it to dart away from predators with impressive agility.

name: Mexican Long-tongued Bat
region: Southwestern US (California, Arizona, New Mexico, Texas)
habitat: Semi-arid thorn scrub and mixed oak-conifer forests, caves and abandoned buildings
description: A nectar-feeding specialist with a tongue capable of extending one-third its body length, allowing it to reach deep into blossoms and even raid hummingbird feeders. Northern populations migrate south each winter following flowering plants across Mexico and Central America.

name: Mexican Spiny Pocket Mouse
region: Southern Texas and Mexico
habitat: Dry shrubland and scrubby uplands
description: A nocturnal mouse with a kangaroo-like leap that can cover 5 feet in a single second, armed with stiff spines mixed into its coat for protection. Uniquely dependent on water access, it stores seeds in cheek pouches and raises litters of up to eight young throughout the year.

name: Mexican Vole
region: Southwestern United States and Mexico
habitat: Grasslands and mixed climate types
description: A small but adaptable rodent found across the southwestern deserts and highlands, known for its surprising predatory behavior—documented actively hunting and consuming monarch butterflies despite being primarily herbivorous.

name: Mexican Woodrat
region: Southwest US (Utah, Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, Texas) to Central America
habitat: Highland coniferous forests and rocky areas with crevices and caves
description: A medium-sized pack rat weighing 140-185 grams that thrives in rocky highlands where most rodents cannot survive, using deep crevices and cave systems for shelter. With over 26 historical names now recognized as synonyms, this generalist forager consumes everything from berries and fungi to acorns and foliage.

name: Migratory Woodland Caribou
region: Northern Idaho, northeastern Washington, and extreme northern boreal Canada
habitat: Boreal forests and forest-tundra regions
description: An Arctic wanderer capable of traveling up to 6,000 kilometers in a single year between boreal forests and open tundra. Once numbering in the hundreds of thousands, fewer than 30 individuals now persist in the contiguous United States, making it one of North America's most critically endangered mammals.

name: Mogollon Vole
region: Southwestern United States and Mexico
habitat: Grasslands and adaptable to various climate types
description: A small but voracious rodent that supplements its grass and root diet by hunting monarch butterflies, making it one of the few vole species known to actively prey on insects. Once considered multiple distinct subspecies across the Southwest, genetic research revealed this adaptable vole maintains a single disjunct population.

name: Mohave Ground Squirrel
region: Mojave Desert, California
habitat: Joshua tree woodlands, creosote scrub, and desert scrublands
description: This nine-inch desert dweller enters a hibernation-like estivation state during dry months, with entire local populations vanishing during multi-year droughts—only to rebound when rains return. Males emit a distinctive high-pitched 'peep' alarm call that locals often mistake for a horned lark.

name: Montane Shrew
region: Alaska, Western Canada, Western US (Washington to California, New Mexico)
habitat: Moist meadows, river banks, coniferous and subalpine forests
description: A fierce competitor despite its tiny frame, this shrew molts twice yearly and males bulk up 50% during breeding season to compete for mates. Their robust upper incisors are larger and harder than related species, giving them an edge in the intense resource wars of forest floors.

name: Montane Vole
region: Western US and Canada, mountainous areas
habitat: Alpine meadows, grasslands, and high elevation terrain
description: A prolific breeder capable of raising three to four litters annually, with young reaching sexual maturity in as little as four weeks. So abundant in Idaho that they comprise up to 80% of great horned owl diets.

name: Moose
region: Canada, Alaska, New England, Northern US (Maine, Montana, Idaho, Minnesota, Wisconsin, etc.)
habitat: Boreal and temperate forests, marshes, river banks, areas with deep snow and aquatic vegetation
description: The tallest deer species on Earth, standing over 6 feet at the shoulder and weighing up to 1,500 pounds—capable of diving over 18 feet underwater to feed on aquatic plants and emerging with sealed nostrils thanks to specialized fatty pads in its distinctive oversized snout.

name: Morro Bay Kangaroo Rat
region: Central Coast of California
habitat: Fine sand dunes and coastal scrub
description: A tiny nocturnal hopper weighing just 60-80 grams, this rat's oversized hind legs and long tail let it leap like a miniature kangaroo across California's dunes. Restricted to a mere 2 km stretch of Morro Bay, it stands on the brink of extinction with fewer individuals surviving in the wild than many critically endangered species.

name: Mount Graham Red Squirrel
region: Arizona (Pinaleño Mountains)
habitat: High-elevation spruce-fir and mixed-conifer forests
description: This tiny 8-ounce squirrel was believed extinct until its miraculous rediscovery in the 1970s, and now survives in just the remote peaks of Arizona where it forages for fungi and conifer seeds. Unlike its red squirrel cousins, it lacks the characteristic white-fringed tail and sports rusty orange markings on its grayish-brown fur.

name: Mount Lyell Shrew
region: Sierra Nevada, California
habitat: Sub-alpine riparian areas near fast-running streams
description: A tiny alpine hunter weighing merely 4-5 grams, this shrew relies on its 32 razor-sharp teeth to hunt near mountain streams at elevations between 6,890 and 11,910 feet. Despite its diminutive size, it's a fierce predator adapted to one of California's harshest environments.

name: Mountain Beaver
region: Pacific Northwest and California mountains
habitat: Temperate rainforests and moist coniferous/deciduous forests
description: Despite being called a beaver, this nocturnal burrower is more closely related to squirrels and cannot concentrate urine—forcing it to consume massive amounts of water daily and restricting it to the wettest regions of North America. Known for devastating forest seedlings through bark-stripping and branch-cutting, it harbors the largest flea species on Earth, measuring up to 8 mm long.

name: Mountain Cottontail
region: Western North America, from South Dakota to California, and north to Edmonton
habitat: Intermountain sagebrush areas and grasslands below 6,000 feet elevation
description: An extremely prolific breeder capable of producing 2-5 litters per year with an average of 4-6 kits per litter, making it one of North America's most reproductive cottontails. Known for its distinctive short leaps and ability to climb juniper trees for food and water.

name: Mountain Goat
region: Western North America: Rocky Mountains, Cascades, and alpine areas from Washington through British Columbia and Alaska
habitat: High-altitude alpine and subalpine rocky slopes, typically above treeline and exceeding 13,000 feet elevation
description: An expert climber capable of scaling near-vertical cliff faces and 60-degree slopes with specially adapted hooves and powerful shoulder muscles, this alpine specialist can withstand winter temperatures dropping to −46 °C and winds exceeding 99 mph. With half the world's population residing in British Columbia, it remains one of North America's most sure-footed mountaineers.

name: Mountain Pocket Gopher
region: California and Nevada, particularly the Sierra Nevada
habitat: Mountain meadows, forest floors, and meadow edges
description: A tireless underground engineer that constructs tunnel systems spanning up to 2,000 square feet while rarely surfacing. This 91-gram rodent survives entirely on water extracted from plants and stores roots and bulbs in its elaborate burrow network.

name: Mule Deer
region: Western North America: Great Plains, Rocky Mountains, Southwest, West Coast
habitat: Rocky Mountains, high elevation summer ranges, desert scrubland, mixed forests
description: Named for its oversized ears like a mule's, this western deer can leap with all four feet coming down together in a distinctive bouncing gait called stotting. Bucks shed their antlers each winter and regrow them in a bifurcated fork pattern, migrating up to 150 miles between seasonal ranges.

name: Muskox
region: Arctic Alaska, Canadian Arctic, Greenland
habitat: Arctic tundra and grasslands
description: An Arctic giant wrapped in a coat so thick and insulating it can weigh up to 650 pounds, this shaggy beast uses specialized hemoglobin three times less temperature-sensitive than humans' to thrive in extreme cold. When threatened, the entire herd forms an impenetrable defensive ring around their young.

name: Muskrat
region: Most of Canada and the United States, small part of northern Mexico
habitat: Wetlands, marshes, rivers, lakes, and ponds
description: A master swimmer capable of holding its breath underwater for up to 17 minutes, this rodent constructs elaborate lodge homes and can dramatically reshape entire wetland ecosystems by consuming vast amounts of aquatic vegetation.

name: Narrow-faced Kangaroo Rat
region: West-central California coastal mountains
habitat: Chaparral and sandy soils with oak or pine
description: This nimble rodent possesses a distinctly narrow face among its kangaroo rat cousins, allowing it to navigate the chaparral scrublands of coastal California with remarkable agility. Equipped with powerful hind legs for jumping and specialized cheek pouches for carrying seeds, it's perfectly adapted to life in sandy, drought-prone terrain.

name: Narwhal
region: Canadian Arctic, Greenland waters
habitat: Arctic Ocean, pack ice, deep offshore waters
description: A medium-sized Arctic whale distinguished by its long, spiraling tusk—actually an oversized canine tooth—which can reach 10 feet in length and contains millions of sensory nerve endings. Capable of diving deeper than 4,920 feet and staying submerged for up to 25 minutes while hunting in the frigid polar depths.

name: Nearctic Brown Lemming
region: Northern Canada (Nunavut, Northwest Territories, Yukon), Alaska, coastal British Columbia
habitat: Arctic tundra, wetlands, polygon fens with grasses and sedges
description: This tiny arctic rodent weighs less than 3 ounces but can produce up to three litters yearly, with females birthing up to nine pups in a single litter. During winter, it burrows deep beneath the snow to stay warm and reproduce, emerging only when the Arctic thaw returns.

name: Nelson's Collared Lemming
region: Western and southwestern Alaska
habitat: Arctic tundra
description: A small arctic rodent adapted to extreme cold environments, belonging to a unique genus of lemmings found exclusively in North America's northernmost regions. One of seven collared lemming species, it survives harsh tundra conditions through specialized winter behaviors and thick insulating fur.

name: Nelson's Pocket Mouse
region: Western Texas, southeastern New Mexico, central and northern Mexico
habitat: Desert with sparse scrubby vegetation, rocky slopes with cactus and creosote bush
description: A nimble nocturnal forager with fur-lined cheek pouches and distinctive dark-tipped spines on its rump, this desert dweller can pack seeds into its pouches while moving between plants on rocky slopes. Despite abundant numbers in late summer, only 14% survive to their first birthday.

name: New England Cottontail
region: New England and New York
habitat: Early successional forests with dense shrubland and thickets
description: Nearly indistinguishable from the eastern cottontail, this elusive rabbit can only be reliably identified through DNA testing or by examining the jagged skull sutures that set it apart. Its range has shrunk by over 86% since 1960, leaving it on the brink of extirpation across much of New England.

name: New Mexico Shrew
region: New Mexico mountains (Capitan and Sandia-Manzano ranges)
habitat: High-elevation mountain forests
description: A tiny mountain dweller weighing less than a dime, distinguished from its closest relatives by unusually long rows of teeth and a wider gap between its upper front teeth. Known only from two isolated New Mexico mountain ranges, this elusive shrew was thought to be the same species as the montane shrew until 1996.

name: Nilgai
region: Southern Texas, with populations in Alabama, Florida, Mississippi, and Mexican border states
habitat: Prairies, scrub forests, oak forests, and agricultural lands
description: Asia's largest antelope, now feral in Texas with nearly 37,000 individuals roaming the landscape. Males weigh up to 635 pounds and display a striking bluish-grey coat, while females remain orange-tawny, making them one of nature's most sexually dimorphic ungulates.

name: Nine-banded Armadillo
region: Southeastern US, expanding northward to the Midwest and Mid-Atlantic
habitat: Grasslands, scrublands, rainforests, and open prairies
description: Encased in an impenetrable armor of bony plates, this insectivore can leap 3-4 feet straight into the air when frightened and hold its breath for up to six minutes while hunting underground. A single female can produce up to 56 young in her lifetime, driving the species' explosive expansion across North America.

name: North American Least Shrew
region: Southern Canada through eastern and central United States to Mexico
habitat: Grasslands, marshes, meadows, and weedy fields
description: One of North America's smallest mammals at just 3 inches long, this shrew must eat more than its own body weight daily and can live in social groups of up to 31 individuals huddled together for warmth.

name: North American Porcupine
region: Canada to northern Mexico, eastern North America to Alaska
habitat: Coniferous and mixed forests, shrublands, tundra
description: Armed with approximately 30,000 barbed quills covering its body, this slow-moving rodent relies on its formidable defense system rather than speed to survive. The only North American mammal to successfully live a solitary lifestyle among herbivores, it can remember complex mazes for up to 100 days.

name: North Atlantic Right Whale
region: Eastern North America, Atlantic coast from Florida to Newfoundland
habitat: Open ocean and coastal waters
description: A massive baleen whale weighing up to 77 short tons, with up to 45% of its body composed of blubber that allows it to float even after death. Once hunted to near extinction, fewer than 370 individuals remain in the western North Atlantic, making it one of the world's most critically endangered marine mammals.

name: North Pacific Right Whale
region: Alaska, Bering Sea, Gulf of Alaska
habitat: Cold ocean waters, continental shelf areas
description: One of Earth's most critically endangered whales, with fewer than 40 individuals remaining in the eastern North Pacific. These massive baleen whales can reach 60 feet long and weigh up to 220,000 pounds—twice as heavy as a humpback whale—yet feed by skimming tiny copepods from the ocean at concentrations exceeding 3,000 per cubic meter.

name: Northern Baja Deer Mouse
region: Southern California and Baja California peninsula
habitat: Desert and arid regions, Gulf of California islands
description: Once thought to be a subspecies of the cactus mouse, genetic analysis revealed this nimble rodent is actually more closely related to Eva's desert mouse, making it a prime example of hidden diversity in North American desert ecosystems.

name: Northern Bog Lemming
region: Canada, Alaska, Northern Washington, Minnesota, New England
habitat: Wet northern forests, bogs, tundra, meadows
description: A diminutive 30-gram rodent with distinctively grooved upper incisors and rust-colored ear patches, capable of maintaining year-round activity in harsh northern climates. Population numbers follow dramatic 3- to 4-year boom-and-bust cycles, with colonies bursting through snow and vegetation via elaborate runway systems.

name: Northern Bottlenose Whale
region: Northern Atlantic waters off eastern Canada (Nova Scotia, Labrador), occasionally ranging to Newfoundland
habitat: Deep ocean waters deeper than 6,500 feet; cold subarctic North Atlantic
description: A deep-diving marine mammal capable of reaching depths of 7,674 feet and holding its breath for up to 130 minutes while hunting squid on the ocean floor. Males develop distinctive large, flattened white melons (foreheads) as they age, making them unmistakable among beaked whales.

name: Northern Broad-footed Mole
region: Northern California, Nevada, Oregon
habitat: Moist, friable soils in forests and meadows
description: A subterranean specialist that spends nearly its entire life underground, using massive flattened forefeet with heavy claws to excavate tunnel networks that create distinctive volcano-shaped mounds at the surface. Despite weighing less than 3 ounces, it can consume its body weight in earthworms and insects daily.

name: Northern Collared Lemming
region: Arctic North America, Alaska, northern Canada, Greenland
habitat: Arctic tundra
description: A pint-sized Arctic survivor that turns pure white in winter and develops massive digging claws for tunneling beneath the snow. Its populations explode and crash in dramatic three- to four-year cycles, creating waves of dispersal across the frozen tundra.

name: Northern Elephant Seal
region: Pacific Coast (California to Alaska), breeding colonies from Point Reyes to British Columbia
habitat: Open ocean and continental shelf; breeds on remote offshore islands and mainland beaches
description: Males can weigh up to 3,700 pounds and dive deeper than 5,700 feet while holding their breath, using a specialized spleen that releases oxygenated blood cells to fuel extraordinary deep-sea hunts. A single breeding bull may father over 500 pups in his lifetime by dominating harems of up to 100 females.

name: Northern Flying Squirrel
region: Canada and northern United States, from Alaska to Nova Scotia, south to the Appalachian Mountains
habitat: Coniferous and mixed coniferous forests
description: A nocturnal glider that can soar up to 45 meters between trees by stretching a patagium membrane and making sharp 90-degree turns in mid-air before using its flat tail as a parachute to land safely on tree trunks.

name: Northern Fur Seal
region: Alaska, Pacific Northwest coast, California
habitat: North Pacific Ocean, Bering Sea, rocky coastal rookeries
description: Males can weigh over 600 pounds—more than 4.5 times heavier than females—making this the largest fur seal species. Their hind flippers possess uniquely elongated cartilaginous extensions, granting exceptional aquatic maneuverability.

name: Northern Grasshopper Mouse
region: Western US and northern Mexico, from Saskatchewan to central Washington
habitat: Dry grasslands, prairies, and pastures
description: A carnivorous rodent that hunts other mice and even snakes, making up to three-quarters of its diet from meat rather than plants. Makes high-pitched territorial calls throughout the night from its warren of specialized burrows, each serving a different purpose.

name: Northern Idaho Ground Squirrel
region: Western-central Idaho (Adams and Valley Counties)
habitat: Dry rocky meadows with ponderosa pine and Douglas-fir forests
description: This critically endangered squirrel hibernates for 8 months straight and can construct three different types of burrows for specific purposes—nest burrows for breeding, auxiliary burrows for escape, and hibernation burrows for winter survival. Once widespread across 1,600 square kilometers, fewer than 2,000 individuals remain today.

name: Northern Long-eared Myotis
region: Eastern half of US and Canada, from Manitoba and Newfoundland south to North Carolina and Alabama
habitat: Boreal and hardwood forests
description: A tiny bat weighing less than a penny that hunts by plucking insects directly from surfaces rather than catching them mid-flight, using echolocation calls so quiet they're inaudible to their moth prey. Once widespread across 37 states, populations have plummeted 99% in the northeast due to white-nose syndrome.

name: Northern Pocket Gopher
region: Western US and Canadian provinces (Alberta, Saskatchewan, British Columbia, Manitoba)
habitat: Mountain meadows and lowlands with good soil, near streams
description: A subterranean master engineer that rarely surfaces, constructing tunnel systems extending hundreds of feet underground where it lives, stores food, and mates. Despite their small 60-160 gram frame, these burrowers significantly reshape their ecosystems by altering plant composition and affecting herbivore populations.

name: Northern Pygmy Mouse
region: Mexico and southwestern United States
habitat: Grasslands and scrubland
description: One of North America's tiniest rodents, weighing less than a third of an ounce, yet defies rodent convention by having fathers actively care for and groom their offspring—a rare trait among mice.

name: Northern Red-backed Vole
region: Alaska, Northern Canada, and extreme northern US
habitat: Boreal forests, taiga, and tundra with dense ground cover
description: A nocturnal forest dweller weighing merely 30-40 grams that remains active throughout brutal Arctic winters by constructing elaborate tunnel networks beneath the snow. Despite its tiny frame, this vole can produce up to three litters per breeding season with an average of nearly 6 pups each.

name: Northern Rock Mouse
region: Mexico and the United States
habitat: Rocky terrain and mountainous areas
description: A nimble rock-dwelling rodent with an elongated snout perfectly adapted for foraging in crevices and rocky crevasses. Despite its small size, this mouse is an agile climber capable of navigating steep, rocky terrain where larger predators cannot venture.

name: Northern Short-tailed Shrew
region: Northeastern North America, from Saskatchewan to Atlantic Canada
habitat: Forests with leaf litter, grasslands, and moist areas
description: One of the few venomous mammals, this tiny shrew injects a kallikrein-like toxin through grooved lower incisors to paralyze prey up to three times its own size. It consumes nearly its entire body weight in food daily, making it one of nature's most voracious hunters.

name: Northern Yellow Bat
region: Southeastern US and Eastern Texas
habitat: Wooded areas near water with Spanish moss and palm trees
description: A nimble nocturnal hunter that roosts exclusively in Spanish moss and palm fronds, with a wingspan of 35-41 cm and the remarkable ability to carry its pups to safety if disturbed during the day. Despite weighing just 14-31 grams, this bat can form maternity colonies of multiple females in a single tree.

name: Northwestern Deer Mouse
region: Pacific Northwest (British Columbia, Alaska, Washington)
habitat: Floodplain forests and coastal woodlands
description: Named after Rev. John Henry Keen in 1894, this small rodent thrives in the temperate forests of the Pacific Northwest where it plays a crucial role in floodplain ecosystems. Despite its diminutive size, it displays remarkable spatial variation in population dynamics across different forest habitats.

name: Ocelot
region: Texas and Arizona
habitat: Dense tropical forests, mangrove swamps, and areas near water sources
description: A spotted nocturnal hunter with a unique color pattern on each individual, capable of hunting prey by following scent trails at speeds as slow as 0.3 km/h before pouncing with surprising agility. In Texas, only 50–80 individuals remain in the wild.

name: Oldfield Mouse
region: Southeastern US, Florida to Tennessee
habitat: Beaches and sandy fields
description: This tiny nocturnal rodent weighs less than a penny yet survives on sandy beaches where it's evolved to match its environment—turning pale white on white sand beaches while inland populations grow darker and smaller. Multiple subspecies face extinction despite the species' overall least concern status, with six distinct populations protected under the Endangered Species Act.

name: Olive-backed Pocket Mouse
region: Central Great Plains (Canada to Colorado)
habitat: Arid grasslands and semi-arid uplands
description: A nocturnal burrower that excavates tunnel systems reaching 6.5 feet deep and spanning nearly 10 feet across, storing hundreds of seeds in underground chambers to survive up to eight months of hibernation without emerging above ground.

name: Olympic Marmot
region: Olympic Peninsula, Washington
habitat: Alpine and subalpine meadows, mountain slopes
description: This stocky alpine rodent displays the most pronounced sexual dimorphism of any marmot species, with males weighing 23% more than females. Before hibernating for eight months without eating, they nearly double their body weight and lose half of it by spring.

name: Olympic Shrew
region: Northwestern Washington state and British Columbia
habitat: Boggy wetlands and Fraser Valley forests
description: So newly discovered it wasn't formally described until 2007, this elusive shrew is easily mistaken for its close relative the masked shrew and inhabits fewer than 15 known locations across the Pacific Northwest.

name: Ord's Kangaroo Rat
region: Great Plains and Great Basin, from southern Canada to central Mexico
habitat: Semiarid grasslands, shrublands, and sandy desert scrub
description: A nocturnal master of the desert with a fifth toe on its hind feet and a distinctive white-striped tail, this rat can make hundreds of seed caches to survive harsh conditions. Most water is obtained directly from seeds, allowing it to thrive in some of North America's most arid regions.

name: Ornate Shrew
region: Western North America, from Northern California to Baja California
habitat: Coastal marshes, salt marshes, and freshwater swamps with dense vegetation
description: This thumb-sized shrew must eat more than its own body weight daily to fuel its lightning-fast metabolism, consuming up to 24 insects per day. Of all vertebrates, shrews possess the largest brain-to-body mass ratio, making them surprisingly intelligent despite weighing just 5 grams.

name: Osgood's Mouse
region: Mexico
habitat: Unknown (endemic to Mexico)
description: A small Mexican rodent named after naturalist Wilfred Hudson Osgood, this humble deer mouse remains poorly studied despite its classification as a species of least concern in its native range.

name: Pacific Jumping Mouse
region: Pacific Northwest, California, western Canada
habitat: Moist meadows, marshes, riparian areas, and alpine grasslands
description: A nimble rodent capable of leaping over 150 centimeters to escape predators, with its distinctive three-striped back pattern setting it apart from other jumping mice. This gentle creature hibernates for up to 8 months and produces characteristic squealing vocalizations when threatened.

name: Pacific Marten
region: Western North America from British Columbia to New Mexico
habitat: Coniferous and deciduous forests, Rocky Mountains and Sierra Nevada
description: An agile forest acrobat that travels up to 2.83 miles daily through mountainous terrain, capable of burrowing through deep snow to hunt prey and evading predators like bobcats and golden eagles with remarkable tree-climbing prowess.

name: Pacific Pocket Mouse
region: Southern California coast
habitat: Coastal sand dunes and sage scrub near the Pacific Ocean
description: Believed extinct for nearly 20 years before its miraculous rediscovery in 1993, this tiny hibernator weighs less than a third of an ounce yet survives California's harsh coastal climate by storing seeds in fur-lined cheek pouches up to 12 inches long.

name: Pacific Shrew
region: Western Oregon and northern California coast
habitat: Damp forests near creeks, dense vegetation, collapsed trees
description: The largest brown shrew in western Oregon, this tiny hunter weighs only 10-18 grams yet fearlessly pursues scorpions and wasps by paralyzing them with a venomous bite—or killing them instantly if the hunt turns dangerous.

name: Pacific White-sided Dolphin
region: Pacific Coast (California to Alaska), Bering Sea
habitat: Cool to temperate offshore ocean waters
description: An acrobatic ocean dweller that travels in supergroups exceeding 300 individuals and readily bow-rides alongside boats with remarkable agility. With an average of 60 teeth and a diet spanning multiple prey species, these dolphins can live over 40 years while sleeping just seven hours per night.

name: Pale Kangaroo Mouse
region: Central Nevada and eastern California deserts
habitat: Sand dunes and sandy desert floors of the Great Basin
description: A nocturnal hopper weighing less than half an ounce, this bipedal rodent avoids moonlight and caches seeds across multiple hiding spots to outwit competing desert scavengers. Known to derive all its water from insects rather than drinking free water.

name: Pallid Bat
region: Western Canada to Central Mexico
habitat: Arid and semi-arid mountainous regions, rocky areas near water, open grasslands
description: Immune to the venom of Arizona bark scorpions—the most venomous scorpions in North America—thanks to special mutations in its sodium channels. This gleaning insectivore can consume up to half its body weight in insects every night while flying just 1–2 meters above the ground.

name: Palmer's Chipmunk
region: Southern Nevada (Spring Mountains)
habitat: High-altitude temperate forests with pinyon pine, juniper, fir, and bristlecone pine
description: A diminutive striped rodent weighing barely 60 grams that survives Nevada's harsh winters by caching ponderosa pine seeds and emerging on warm days to raid its own underground pantries. Found only in the remote Spring Mountains, this endangered chipmunk is losing ground to campground expansion and Las Vegas sprawl.

name: Panamint Chipmunk
region: Southeast California and southwest Nevada
habitat: Pinyon pine-juniper woodlands, bushes, boulders, and cliffs
description: A nimble desert dweller that navigates rocky cliffs and canyon walls with ease, serving as a vital food source for raptors, coyotes, and bobcats across the arid southwest. Despite its small size, it thrives in harsh pinyon-juniper environments where few other small mammals persist.

name: Panamint Kangaroo Rat
region: Eastern California and western Nevada (Mojave Desert)
habitat: Great Basin bush desert, sandy mounds with brush clumps at high elevations
description: A nocturnal desert hopper with a tail 140% longer than its body, equipped with fur-lined cheek pouches and the remarkable ability to survive indefinitely on metabolic water extracted from seeds, producing only a single drop of urine every 1–2 hours.

name: Pantropical Spotted Dolphin
region: Eastern Pacific Ocean, Gulf of Mexico
habitat: Tropical and temperate ocean waters
description: A highly acrobatic dolphin capable of clearing the water for over a second in a single leap, once hunted to near extinction with 3 million individuals killed between 1959 and 1972 before dolphin-safe fishing practices saved the species.

name: Perdido Key Beach Mouse
region: Northern Gulf Coast (Perdido Key, Florida/Alabama)
habitat: Coastal sand dunes with sea oats and beach vegetation
description: This tiny 14-gram mouse has evolved to match the white quartz sand of Gulf beaches so perfectly it becomes nearly invisible. Unlike its relatives, it refuses human food and instead sustains itself entirely on dune seeds, surviving on some of the harshest and most developed coastlines in America.

name: Perrin's Beaked Whale
region: Pacific Coast (California waters)
habitat: Deep oceanic waters, 1000+ meters offshore
description: An elusive deep-sea diver capable of holding its breath for up to two hours in abyssal waters off California. So rarely seen alive that scientists have only examined six specimens since its discovery in 2002.

name: Pinyon Mouse
region: Southwestern US, from Oregon and Wyoming south to Mexico border
habitat: Pinyon-juniper woodlands and rocky slopes
description: Distinguished by ears as large as its hind feet, this adaptable desert dweller maintains home ranges up to 7.2 acres and builds extensive food caches to survive in arid conditions with minimal water access.

name: Piute Ground Squirrel
region: Great Basin region of western US (California, Idaho, Nevada, Oregon, Utah, Washington)
habitat: Great Basin scrublands and arid regions
description: A nimble burrower endemic to the Great Basin, this small squirrel is perfectly adapted to arid environments and serves as a key food source for the region's raptors and predators.

name: Plains Harvest Mouse
region: Northern Mexico and central United States
habitat: Grassy fields and grazed prairie
description: A tiny harvest mouse weighing less than half an ounce, capable of reproducing every 21-27 days with a gestation period of just 3 weeks. Born naked and blind, these mice open their eyes in just 8 days and reach full adult size in 5 weeks.

name: Plains Pocket Gopher
region: Great Plains (Manitoba to Texas)
habitat: Grasslands and agricultural land with sandy, friable soils
description: A master tunneler that excavates up to 2,059 cm of new burrows per week, spending 72% of its time underground in a solitary lifestyle guided by extraordinary sensitivity to soil vibrations. Despite being dismissed as pests, these rodents are vital ecosystem engineers that improve soil aeration, drainage, and plant diversity across the Great Plains.

name: Plains Pocket Mouse
region: Great Plains and Southwest, from Minnesota and North Dakota to Texas and northern Mexico
habitat: Sandy soil areas with Spanish bayonet and prickly pear plants
description: A tiny rodent barely 5 inches long that carries seeds in specialized cheek pouches, capable of storing enough foraged food to survive in arid grasslands where other mammals struggle.

name: Plains Spotted Skunk
region: Great Plains, central and upper midwest US
habitat: Grasslands, prairie ecosystems, rocky and woody areas with dense vegetation
description: This diminutive carnivore performs a unique handstand warning display before unleashing a spray accurate up to 15 feet away, capable of firing five times in succession with only 1 tablespoon of reserve odor.

name: Pocketed Free-tailed Bat
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, California, New Mexico, Texas) and Mexico
habitat: Caves, mines, crevices, and man-made structures
description: A nimble nocturnal hunter weighing just 10-14 grams, identified by the distinctive skin pocket stretching along its hind legs that gives this insect-eating bat its memorable name. Young pocketed free-tailed bats achieve flight within just 1-1.5 months of birth, reaching about 22% of adult weight at birth.

name: Polar Bear
region: Alaska, Arctic waters
habitat: Sea ice, coastal Arctic regions
description: The largest land carnivore on Earth, weighing up to 1,760 pounds with a specialized body built for hunting seals on sea ice. Capable of swimming for days at a stretch and surviving months without food by relying on fat reserves.

name: Polynesian Rat
region: Not established in North America; introduced to Pacific islands
habitat: Grasslands, forests, human settlements, and coastal areas
description: An invasive Pacific traveler that hitchhiked across the ocean with Polynesian sailors, this nimble climber has become the world's third most widespread rat species and has driven numerous bird species to extinction on isolated islands where they evolved without mammalian predators.

name: Prairie Shrew
region: Canadian prairies and midwestern United States
habitat: Open grasslands, often near water
description: A tireless nocturnal hunter weighing just 4 grams, this tiny shrew must eat almost constantly to fuel its hyperactive metabolism and can consume insects, worms, snails, and small mammals across grasslands year-round.

name: Prairie Vole
region: Central North America, from Rocky Mountains to West Virginia and Canadian Prairies
habitat: Grasslands, fallow fields, and hay fields
description: A monogamous rodent that mates for life with a single partner, exhibiting human-like social bonding behavior rarely seen in other vole species. Their brains contain specialized oxytocin and vasopressin receptors that create a lifelong attachment to their mate.

name: Preble's Meadow Jumping Mouse
region: Colorado and Wyoming uplands
habitat: Meadows and riparian areas with dense vegetation
description: A tiny rodent that can leap four feet in a single bound despite being only nine inches long—60% of which is a scaly tail used for balance and drumming communication. This elusive jumper hibernates for nearly eight months straight, surviving on a diet of plants, insects, and slugs in the high meadows of the Colorado Rockies.

name: Preble's Shrew
region: Great Basin and Northern Great Plains (California, Nevada, Oregon, Washington, Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, Utah, southern British Columbia)
habitat: Sagebrush-dominated shrublands and grasslands at 1,280-2,550 meters elevation
description: The smallest shrew in its genus across North America, measuring just 77-95mm in total length with a bite force so weak it can only consume soft-bodied prey like insects and worms. Despite being listed as Least Concern, it remains one of the least abundant shrew species wherever it coexists with other shrew species, suggesting it struggles to compete in its own ecosystem.

name: Pribilof Island Shrew
region: Alaska, Pribilof Islands
habitat: Coastal islands and grasslands
description: Found nowhere else on Earth, this tiny shrew is endemic to Alaska's remote Pribilof Islands, where it hunts insects and small invertebrates across windswept tundra. Despite its restricted range and endangered status, this pocket-sized predator remains one of the least-studied mammals in North America.

name: Pronghorn
region: Western and central North America, west of the Mississippi River
habitat: Open expansive grasslands and prairies at 3,000-5,900 ft elevation
description: The fastest land mammal in the Western Hemisphere, capable of sustaining speeds of 55 mph for half a mile—far exceeding the top speed of any modern North American predator. When alarmed, it flashes its white rump and releases a compound that smells like buttered popcorn, visible to herd mates from 60-100 feet away.

name: Pygmy Beaked Whale
region: California coast, rare
habitat: Deep ocean waters, eastern tropical Pacific
description: One of the ocean's newest discoveries, this elusive deep-diver grows only to about 13 feet—making it the smallest of all beaked whales. Unlike its squid-eating cousins, this species uniquely hunts fish, and has been spotted as far north as California and south as Chile.

name: Pygmy Killer Whale
region: Gulf of Mexico, Atlantic coast (South Carolina to Gulf waters)
habitat: Deep oceanic waters (500-2000m depth)
description: A rarely-seen oceanic hunter capable of echolocation clicks reaching 223 decibels, despite being the smallest cetacean with 'whale' in its name at just over 2 meters long. Known for extreme aggression in captivity, though this behavior remains mysteriously absent in the wild.

name: Pygmy Rabbit
region: Great Basin and intermountain West (Montana, Idaho, Oregon, Utah, Nevada, California, Wyoming, Washington)
habitat: Dense sagebrush thickets on deep soils
description: The world's smallest rabbit species, weighing just 375-500 grams, and the only native North American rabbit that digs its own burrows—extending up to 1 meter deep with 4-10 entrances at the base of sagebrush plants.

name: Pygmy Sperm Whale
region: Atlantic and Pacific coastal waters, occasionally off Russia
habitat: Deep offshore waters, 400-1,000m depth near upwelling zones
description: A master of stealth that rises to the surface with barely a splash, this whale produces ultrasonic echolocation clicks at 125 kHz to hunt bioluminescent squid in the deep. Uniquely among cetaceans, it can eject up to 12 liters of dark red fluid from its intestines to confuse predators, mimicking the defensive behavior of squid.

name: Raccoon
region: Continental US and southern Canada
habitat: Deciduous and mixed forests, urban areas, coastal marshes, mountainous regions
description: A cunning masked bandit renowned for its intelligence and extraordinary sense of touch, capable of remembering solutions to complex tasks for at least three years. Its hypersensitive front paws use nearly two-thirds of its brain's sensory cortex—more than any other studied animal.

name: Rafinesque's Big-eared Bat
region: Southeastern United States
habitat: Mature forests, caves, and abandoned buildings
description: An acrobatic nocturnal hunter with ears over an inch long that make up nearly a third of its head, capable of plucking moths from the air with precision or gleaning them directly from foliage. Moths comprise 90% of its diet, making it a specialized aerial insectivore.

name: Red Deer
region: Western US (introduced; not native)
habitat: Forested mountains and woodlands
description: A massive cervid with males sporting elaborate antlers that can grow at 2.5 cm per day and weigh up to 11 pounds, capable of shedding and regrowing an entirely new set annually. During the rut, dominant stags roar constantly to maintain harems of up to 20 females, losing up to 20% of their body weight in the process.

name: Red Fox
region: Continental US, Canada, Alaska
habitat: Forests, grasslands, suburban and urban areas
description: An adaptable predator capable of jumping over 6-foot fences and traveling 200 miles in a single year, this cunning canine has successfully colonized cities and farms across North America despite centuries of hunting.

name: Red Tree Vole
region: Pacific Northwest (Oregon and northern California)
habitat: Coastal Douglas-fir forests
description: This arboreal rodent can spend its entire life in a single Douglas-fir tree, meticulously stripping resin ducts from needles to build elaborate nests high in the canopy. A crucial prey species for the threatened Northern Spotted Owl, it reproduces slowly with only 1-4 offspring per litter but can have multiple generations living in different parts of the same tree.

name: Red Wolf
