region: Southeastern US (North Carolina coast, formerly throughout Southeast to Texas)
habitat: Coastal marshes, swamps, bottomland forests, agricultural fields, forest/wetland mosaics
description: A social canine intermediate between coyotes and gray wolves, weighing only 20-39 kg yet capable of breeding from a bottleneck of just 14 founders. Once hunted to near extinction, this species was declared extinct in the wild in 1980 before a remarkable reintroduction effort brought it back from the brink.

name: Red-tailed Chipmunk
region: Pacific Northwest and Northern Rockies (British Columbia, Alberta, Washington, Idaho, Montana)
habitat: Coniferous forests and woodland edges at high elevations (2,360-7,870 ft)
description: A bushy-tailed mountain dweller weighing barely 2 ounces that stores seeds in expandable cheek pouches and enters torpor during harsh winters rather than full hibernation. Its distinctive pinkish-buff and orange-brown coloring makes it nearly impossible to distinguish from the yellow-pine chipmunk without skeletal examination.

name: Rhesus Monkey
region: Florida, Puerto Rico, South Carolina
habitat: Mixed forests and urban areas near human settlements
description: An escaped research primate that has thrived in Florida for over 80 years, with populations now numbering 550–600 individuals and spreading hundreds of kilometers across the state. Highly adaptable and known for testing positive for herpes B virus, making them a persistent public health concern despite strong local support for their survival.

name: Ribbon Seal
region: Alaska, Arctic waters of the North Pacific
habitat: Pack ice and sea ice in Arctic/Subarctic waters
description: Instantly recognizable by its striking pattern of white stripes and circles against black fur, this seal can dive to depths of 200 meters in search of fish and squid, using a unique serpentine undulation to propel itself across ice.

name: Rice's Whale
region: Gulf of Mexico (Northern waters off Florida, Alabama, Louisiana)
habitat: Continental slope in deep ocean waters (150-410 meters depth)
description: One of the world's most critically endangered whales with fewer than 33 individuals remaining, this deep-diving baleen whale feeds at depths up to 271 meters at night and surfaces during the day—a behavior unique among its kind. Nearly wiped out by a single oil spill in 2010 that killed 20% of the entire population.

name: Richardson's Ground Squirrel
region: Northern US (North Dakota, Montana) and western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan)
habitat: Short grass prairies and grasslands; adapts to suburban areas
description: Named for its constantly trembling tail that earns it the nickname "flickertail," this ground squirrel can nearly triple its weight from 250g to 750g before hibernation. Notable for its cannibalistic tendencies and the ability to communicate through both audible whistles and ultrasonic alarm calls to warn colony mates of approaching predators.

name: Ring-tailed Cat
region: Southwestern US (Oregon, California, Arizona, New Mexico, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas, Louisiana)
habitat: Rocky desert regions, riparian canyons, and areas near water sources
description: This nimble nocturnal climber uses its distinctively ringed tail—roughly equal in length to its entire body—as both a balance beam and a decoy to distract predators from its vulnerable body. With ankle joints that rotate over 180 degrees and the ability to perform cartwheels to reverse direction, it's one of the most agile mammals in North America.

name: Ringed Seal
region: Arctic Canada, Alaska, Greenland, northern North Atlantic coasts to Newfoundland
habitat: Pack ice and sea ice floes in Arctic and sub-Arctic waters
description: This Arctic seal uses claws thicker than 1 inch to maintain breathing holes through 6.5-foot-thick ice, making it the most abundant ice seal in the Northern Hemisphere. Its distinctive silver rings and silver belly provide camouflage in frozen seas where it can live up to 40 years.

name: Rio Grande Ground Squirrel
region: Southwestern US (Texas and New Mexico), northeastern Mexico
habitat: Arid and semi-arid grasslands
description: Once classified as a subspecies of the Mexican ground squirrel, genetic analysis revealed this burrowing rodent was distinct enough to warrant its own genus—Ictidomys—reshaping our understanding of ground squirrel evolution.

name: Risso's Dolphin
region: Western US coast (California to Alaska), Eastern Seaboard, Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean
habitat: Deep ocean waters near continental shelf, 400-1,000m depths
description: The largest dolphin species, reaching 13 feet long and covered in distinctive scars that tell the story of social battles. These deep-diving hunters plunge over 2,000 feet to hunt squid, using barrel rolls to descend almost vertically and maximize foraging time.

name: Robust Cottontail
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico, Texas) and Western Mexico
habitat: High-altitude dry, brushy mountains above 1,500 meters
description: A mountain-dwelling cottontail weighing just 1.3–1.8 kg, distinguished from its eastern cousins by unique dental and cranial features confirmed through genetic analysis. The Davis Mountains subspecies is suspected extinct in two of its four historical ranges.

name: Rock Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern United States and Mexico
habitat: Rocky desert outcrops
description: A nocturnal desert dweller that has evolved a striking example of adaptive melanism, with dark-colored populations perfectly matching black volcanic rock formations while lighter cousins blend seamlessly into tan desert stone. The same dark coat has evolved independently in separate populations through entirely different genetic mutations, a remarkable case of convergent evolution.

name: Rock Squirrel
region: Southwestern US and Mexico (Nevada, Utah, Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico, West Texas, Oklahoma panhandle)
habitat: Rocky mountains, canyon walls, cliffs, and steep rocky hills
description: One of the largest ground squirrels in North America, reaching up to 21 inches in length, with the remarkable ability to survive up to 100 days without water. These social burrowers can carry up to 62 acorns in their cheek pouches and will fearlessly throw debris at approaching snakes.

name: Rock Vole
region: Eastern Canada and northeastern United States
habitat: Moist rocky slopes
description: A secretive yellow-nosed vole that weighs barely 1.4 ounces but maintains complex underground tunnel systems and produces up to three litters of seven young per year. Despite being active year-round, it is rarely seen by humans.

name: Roof Rat
region: Widespread in warmer areas of continental US, particularly ports and coastal regions
habitat: Urban warehouses and buildings, agricultural areas, forests with trees and palms
description: An agile climber with a tail as long as its body that can weigh as little as 75 grams yet consume up to 15 grams of food daily—making it a serious threat to crops across the world. Once blamed for spreading the Black Death, recent studies suggest humans were the real culprits.

name: Rough-toothed Dolphin
region: Coastal waters off Hawaii, California, and Gulf of Mexico
habitat: Deep warm tropical and subtropical ocean waters beyond continental shelf
description: A deep-diving oceanic hunter with a distinctively conical head and roughened teeth, capable of descending at least 50 meters and holding its breath for over 15 minutes. Despite their slender 9-foot frames, rough-toothed dolphins hunt squid and fish in tropical waters worldwide.

name: Round-tailed Ground Squirrel
region: Southwestern US and Northwestern Mexico
habitat: Desert regions with loose soil, mesquite trees, and creosote bushes
description: This tiny desert burrower weighs merely 125 grams and survives the harshest conditions by choosing foods with 80% water content, never needing a drink. When threatened by snakes, it performs a distinctive tail-wagging display and even kicks dirt at its predators.

name: Round-tailed Muskrat
region: Southeastern US (Florida and Georgia)
habitat: Freshwater swamps and wetlands
description: A nocturnal semi-aquatic rodent weighing less than 10 ounces that constructs woven lodges above water level and maintains 10-15 separate rest sites within its territory. Despite its small size, it maintains population densities of 100-120 animals per acre in ideal wetland habitats.

name: Sagebrush Vole
region: Western US and southern western Canada
habitat: Dry open brushy areas and sagebrush plains
description: A diminutive vole weighing merely 21-39 grams with a fluffy grey coat and a fur-covered tail, capable of producing 5 or more litters of 4-6 young per year. Active day and night, it creates extensive tunnel networks and can burrow beneath snow throughout winter.

name: Saint Lawrence Island Shrew
region: Alaska (Saint Lawrence Island only)
habitat: Arctic tundra and grasslands
description: Found exclusively on a remote Alaskan island, this tiny shrew is one of North America's most geographically restricted mammals, surviving in the harsh Arctic environment by hunting insects and other small invertebrates.

name: Salt Marsh Harvest Mouse
region: San Francisco Bay Area, California
habitat: Salt marshes with pickleweed and tules
description: This tiny 10-20 gram mouse possesses an extraordinary adaptation allowing it to drink and survive purely on salt water, a physiological trick unknown to many researchers. Nocturnal and particularly active on moonlit nights, it can live up to 18 months in its shrinking San Francisco Bay habitat.

name: Sambar
region: Florida (St. Vincent Island), Texas (Edwards Plateau and South Texas)
habitat: Lowlands, marshes, and coastal gullies
description: An introduced Asian deer species capable of weighing up to 1,200 pounds, with distinctive three-pointed antlers reaching 110 cm in length. Despite lacking antlers, females fiercely defend their young by lashing at predators in shallow water, sometimes forming defensive formations that touch rumps while vocalizing loudly.

name: San Bernardino Kangaroo Rat
region: Southern California (San Bernardino and Riverside counties)
habitat: Sandy alluvial scrub with chaparral and coastal sage scrub
description: A four-toed desert dweller with an extraordinarily compressed range: once spanning 320,000 acres, its habitat has shrunk to just 3,247 acres by 1998. These tiny rodents can leap across sandy floodplains using their oversized hind feet and balancing tail, but urban development and flood control projects now threaten their survival.

name: San Diego Pocket Mouse
region: Southern California and northern Baja California
habitat: Desert scrub, rocky areas with herbaceous vegetation
description: A nocturnal forager equipped with fur-lined cheek pouches that can survive indefinitely without drinking water by extracting moisture from seeds and metabolic processes. Males defend territories spanning nearly an acre while females patrol smaller ranges of just over half an acre.

name: San Joaquin Antelope Squirrel
region: San Joaquin Valley, California
habitat: Sandy grasslands with sparse vegetation; Carrizo Plain
description: This tiny squirrel can survive at least 7 months without water in the shade and cleverly uses the white underside of its tail as a predator-deceiving lure, flicking it to mimic thistledown blowing in the wind. Once abundant across the San Joaquin Valley, fewer than 1 per hectare remain today due to agricultural expansion.

name: San Joaquin Kit Fox
region: Central California, San Joaquin Valley
habitat: Open grasslands and scrublands
description: The smallest member of the dog family in North America at just 5 pounds, this nocturnal hunter relies on conspicuously large ears to track kangaroo rats across fragmented grasslands it once dominated by the millions of acres.

name: San Joaquin Pocket Mouse
region: California (Central Valley, Sierra Nevada foothills, Mojave Desert)
habitat: Desert and semi-desert grasslands with creosote bush and Joshua tree
description: A tiny desert rodent equipped with fur-lined cheek pouches that can carry seeds back to its burrow for storage during lean seasons. Despite weighing mere ounces, it may enter a dormant state called torpor to survive harsh winters.

name: Sand Hills Pocket Gopher
region: Great Plains (Wyoming, Colorado, South Dakota, Nebraska)
habitat: Sand Hills grasslands, Mississippi basin
description: A master tunneler that spends most of its life underground, this pocket gopher was long debated by scientists before genetic evidence confirmed it as a distinct species rather than a regional variant of the plains pocket gopher.

name: Scimitar-horned Oryx
region: Texas Hill Country (captive populations only)
habitat: Desert and steppe ranches
description: This desert antelope can survive 9-10 months without water by employing a specialized metabolism that allows its body temperature to rise to 115.7°F before sweating, and possesses scimitar-shaped horns that can reach nearly 4 feet in length. Once thought to be the inspiration for unicorn mythology, it was declared extinct in the wild in 2000 but has been successfully reintroduced to Chad with over 400 individuals now living free.

name: Sea Mink
region: Gulf of Maine, New England coast, Maritime Provinces
habitat: Rocky coastal shores, intertidal zones, island ledges
description: Once the largest mink species in North America, this seafaring predator reached up to 36 inches in length and crushed hard-shelled marine prey with specially adapted teeth before vanishing from the Gulf of Maine by 1894.

name: Sea Otter
region: Alaska, Washington, British Columbia, California
habitat: Coastal waters near rocky shores, kelp forests, and barrier reefs
description: This marine mammal possesses the densest fur of any animal on Earth—up to 150,000 strands per square centimetre—and is one of the few mammals that uses tools, wielding rocks to crack open shellfish with precision strikes reaching 45 blows in just 15 seconds.

name: Sei Whale
region: Northern Atlantic and Pacific coasts, rare in Gulf of Mexico
habitat: Deep offshore waters, continental slopes, open ocean
description: The third-largest whale species, capable of reaching speeds up to 50 km/h in short bursts—earning comparisons to the cheetah of the sea. Filter-feeds on tiny zooplankton using baleen plates with bristles just 0.1mm thick, consuming nearly 900 kg of food daily.

name: Seminole Bat
region: Southeastern US, migratory to Gulf Coast and upper Mississippi Valley
habitat: Forested areas with Spanish moss
description: Often mistaken for the eastern red bat, this mahogany-colored insectivore weighs barely 12 grams but migrates hundreds of miles seasonally from the Gulf Coast to Missouri and Kentucky, relying on Spanish moss as both shelter and a key limiting factor in its range.

name: Short-beaked Common Dolphin
region: Atlantic Coast (Cape Hatteras to Newfoundland), California Coast
habitat: Coastal and offshore ocean waters, continental shelf edges
description: The world's most abundant cetacean with a population exceeding 6 million, displaying an distinctive hourglass color pattern and capable of diving to depths of 660 feet in search of fish and squid. These highly social dolphins form pods numbering in the thousands and communicate using individualized signature whistles that function like personal names.

name: Short-finned Pilot Whale
region: US coasts (West Coast, East Coast, Hawaiian Islands)
habitat: Oceanic waters, continental shelf breaks
description: Known as the 'cheetahs of the deep,' these apex predators pursue squid at depths exceeding 3,000 feet at high speeds, diving for up to 21 minutes and generating rapid clicking sounds to echolocate their prey in complete darkness.

name: Shrew-mole
region: Pacific Northwest (northwestern US and southwestern British Columbia)
habitat: Damp forested areas and bushy regions with deep, loose soils; streams and moist woods in northern range, swampy vegetation in southern range
description: The smallest mole species in North America at just 10 cm long and weighing 10 grams, this creature digs using lateral strokes rather than forward thrusts, carving shallow tunnels rarely deeper than 30 centimeters with its massive rectangular humerus bones and specially modified pectoral girdle.

name: Siberian Ibex
region: New Mexico (introduced population)
habitat: High altitude rocky slopes and alpine meadows
description: A massive mountain climber with curved horns reaching up to 58 inches long, capable of navigating near-vertical rocky slopes where few other animals can survive. Males can weigh up to 286 pounds yet possess the strength to rear up and clash horns with rivals during intense winter rut battles.

name: Sierra Nevada Bighorn Sheep
region: Sierra Nevada mountains of eastern California
habitat: High-elevation rocky slopes and alpine terrain, 10,000–14,000 feet
description: A master of vertical terrain with specialized adhesive-soled hooves, this sheep can weigh up to 220 pounds and climb near-vertical rocky cliffs that predators cannot follow. Males clash horns with tremendous force to establish dominance, their massive curving horns growing a new ring each year like a tree.

name: Sika
region: Eastern United States (Delaware, Kansas, Maryland, Oklahoma, Nebraska, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Virginia, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, Maine, New York, Texas, Wyoming, Washington)
habitat: Temperate and subtropical forests with dense understory
description: A Japanese native with spots that never fade, even in adulthood—unlike most deer species. Males produce over 10 distinct vocalizations and establish territories marked by deep scrapes, sometimes engaging in fierce battles with rivals that can last hours.

name: Silky Pocket Mouse
region: Southwest US and northern/central Mexico
habitat: Arid and semiarid grasslands, sandy areas, shrublands with yucca and cactus
description: The smallest pocket mouse in its family, this nocturnal forager can collect and store an entire 25-gram pile of seeds—enough to sustain itself for 10 days—in a single night. When temperatures drop below freezing, it enters short periods of torpor and survives on its meticulously organized underground seed caches.

name: Silver-haired Bat
region: Alaska to northeastern Mexico; found throughout Canada and continental US
habitat: Forests and woodlands; roosts in tree cavities and bark crevices
description: A slow but acrobatic nocturnal hunter weighing just 8–12 grams, identifiable by its jet-black fur tipped with white hairs that create a frosted appearance. Responsible for more human rabies deaths in recent years than any other North American bat species.

name: Singing Vole
region: Alaska and northwestern Canada
habitat: Arctic tundra above tree line, open slopes with shrubs and sedges
description: This diminutive rodent constructs elaborate haystacks up to 50 centimeters tall on rocks and branches to survive Arctic winters, earning its name from a distinctive high-pitched warning trill. Fossils suggest it once ranged as far south as Iowa during the Ice Ages, over 300,000 years ago.

name: Siskiyou Chipmunk
region: Northern California and central Oregon
habitat: Siskiyou Mountains and forested areas between the Klamath and Rogue Rivers
description: This striped rodent sports a distinctive pattern of five dark brown and four gray stripes running down its back, with the central stripe appearing almost black. Most active during early evening hours, it communicates with distinctive single-syllable calls spaced evenly apart.

name: Smoky Shrew
region: Eastern Canada and northeastern United States, extending south along the Appalachian Mountains
habitat: Cool damp deciduous and mixed forests near streams
description: This tiny 5-gram shrew consumes its own body weight in food daily, hunting beetles and invertebrates through tunnels it borrows from moles rather than digging its own. Despite its diminutive size, it remains active year-round and produces up to 24 offspring annually across multiple litters.

name: Snowshoe Hare
region: Northern North America, from Newfoundland to Alaska; scattered populations in Rocky Mountains and Appalachians
habitat: Boreal forests, dense shrublands, and early successional forests with thick understory cover
description: This forest dweller's oversized hind feet function like natural snowshoes, preventing it from sinking into snow while hopping at high speed. Its fur transforms from rusty brown to bright white each winter for camouflage, creating a textbook predator-prey cycle with Canada lynx that repeats every 10 years—a phenomenon studied by biologists worldwide.

name: Sonoma Chipmunk
region: Northwestern California (Sonoma and Marin counties)
habitat: Coniferous forests and chaparral, from sea level to 5,900 feet
description: These tiny striped rodents weigh less than half an ounce yet produce alarm calls so distinct they're recognized across chipmunk species, with females working overtime as protective sentries for their young. Masters of camouflage, their barely-demarcated back stripes blur seamlessly into chaparral habitat while they cache seeds in oversized cheek pouches.

name: Sonoran Pronghorn
region: Sonoran Desert (Arizona/Mexico border)
habitat: Open desert grasslands and shrublands
description: One of North America's rarest mammals, with fewer than 200 individuals surviving in Arizona after nearly disappearing entirely. These fleet-footed desert specialists can survive longer without water than most pronghorns, relying on exceptional eyesight to evade predators across open terrain.

name: Southeastern Myotis
region: Southeastern US (Gulf Coastal Plain and Lower Mississippi Alluvial Plain)
habitat: Bottomland hardwood forests near water; caves, cisterns, and bridges
description: This diminutive insectivore weighs just 5–8 grams yet is the only Myotis species in the United States that regularly gives birth to twins instead of a single pup. Known for its specialized diet of caddisflies, it hunts exclusively over water with a 9–11 inch wingspan.

name: Southeastern Pocket Gopher
region: Southeastern US (Alabama, Georgia, Florida)
habitat: Sandy pine woodlands and scrubland with longleaf pine and turkey oak
description: A master underground architect that creates elaborate burrow systems with spiral staircases, pushing up distinctive fan-shaped mounds as it digs. Despite producing only an average of two offspring per year, this industrious burrower thrives throughout the Southeast and may actually improve soil fertility through its excavations.

name: Southeastern Shrew
region: Southeastern US
habitat: Forests, woodlands, swamps, and disturbed fields with dense ground cover
description: A tiny, reddish-brown nocturnal hunter weighing less than a penny, with acute hearing and smell that make it lethal to insects despite living barely over a year in the wild. Spiders beware: this shrew consumes them voraciously from the forest floor.

name: Southern Bog Lemming
region: Eastern North America, from southern Canada to Georgia
habitat: Deciduous and mixed forests with grassy openings, wetlands, and grasslands
description: This tiny 35-gram rodent carves intricate mazes of tunnels through forest floors and can produce 2-3 litters of up to six young per year when food is plentiful, allowing populations to boom in a 3-4 year cycle.

name: Southern Broad-footed Mole
region: Southern California and northernmost Baja California
habitat: Sierra Nevada foothills and southern California lowlands
description: A subterranean specialist smaller than its northern cousin, this mole boasts a distinctly longer and wider skull adapted for burrowing through California's varied terrain. When ranges overlap with the northern broad-footed mole, it claims the lower elevations while its relative dominates the heights.

name: Southern Deer Mouse
region: Southwestern United States and Mexico
habitat: Arid and semi-arid regions, shrublands
description: Once thought to be a subspecies of the eastern deer mouse, genetic studies revealed this southwestern rodent as a distinct species in 2019. A tiny but geographically widespread inhabitant of the US-Mexico borderlands, often sharing territory with the similar black-eared mouse.

name: Southern Flying Squirrel
region: Eastern North America, from southeastern Canada to Florida; disjunct populations in Mexican highlands
habitat: Deciduous and mixed forests with hickory, beech, oak, maple, and poplar trees
description: This nocturnal glider extends a furry membrane between its limbs to descend at 30-40 degree angles, making precise 90-degree turns mid-air before raising its flattened tail to brake and land safely. Despite being clumsy on the ground, it can return to its nest from up to a kilometer away using spatial memory alone.

name: Southern Grasshopper Mouse
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, California, Nevada, New Mexico, Utah) and Mexico
habitat: Hot arid valleys and scrub deserts
description: A fearless nocturnal predator that hunts scorpions with impunity, neutralizing their venom through a specialized neural mechanism that blocks pain signals to the brain. This aggressive 120-163mm rodent is one of North America's few carnivorous mice, routinely consuming the highly venomous Arizona bark scorpion that other predators avoid entirely.

name: Southern Idaho Ground Squirrel
region: Southwestern Idaho
habitat: Rolling hills, basins, and flats at moderate elevation
description: Found only in a 30-by-70 kilometer range of southwestern Idaho, this ground squirrel weighs between 120 and 290 grams and exhibits notable sexual dimorphism with males significantly larger than females. Once considered the same species as its northern cousin, this vulnerable rodent inhabits the unique terrain bounded by the Payette and Snake rivers.

name: Southern Plains Woodrat
region: Southern Plains and Southwest US (Colorado, Kansas, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Texas) and northwest Mexico
habitat: Arid and semi-arid grasslands and shrublands
description: A nocturnal pack rat famous for its compulsive hoarding behavior, collecting shiny objects and plant materials in elaborate stick nests. The White Sands subspecies is uniquely adapted with white fur, found nowhere else on Earth except at White Sands National Park in New Mexico.

name: Southern Pocket Gopher
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico) and Mexico
habitat: High altitude grassland and shrubland, desert grassland and woodland
description: A prolific burrower that creates distinctive mounds of excavated soil across grasslands, this rodent can produce litters of up to ten young in a single breeding season. Active year-round without hibernation, it shares its underground tunnels with other species and serves as prey for owls, hawks, coyotes, and badgers.

name: Southern Red-backed Vole
region: Canada and northern United States
habitat: Coniferous, deciduous, and mixed forests near wetlands
description: This tiny slender vole measures just 12–16.5 cm long yet remains active year-round, tunneling through snow in winter and creating elaborate runway systems through forest undergrowth. Despite weighing only 20.6 grams on average, it stores roots, bulbs, and nuts for winter survival while serving as a crucial food source for hawks, owls, and mustelids across North American forests.

name: Southern Short-tailed Shrew
region: Southeastern US, from Virginia to Texas
habitat: Pine forests, from dry to swampy areas
description: This venomous mammal injects toxin through its teeth strong enough to kill mice, yet causes only severe pain in humans. Despite weighing less than half an ounce, it consumes roughly half its body weight daily to fuel its extreme metabolism.

name: Southern Yellow Bat
region: Southwestern US to Argentina
habitat: Wooded areas with palm trees, forests, and vegetation
description: This golden insectivore hunts for just one to two hours after sunset, snatching flying insects near its preferred palm tree roosts. Known for its remarkable reproductive strategy, females store sperm for 6 months before fertilizing eggs—a feat of delayed reproduction found in few bat species.

name: Southwestern Myotis
region: Arizona and New Mexico
habitat: Ponderosa pine forests
description: A nocturnal insect hunter with oversized ears and a larger skull than related bat species, capable of echolocating prey while hunting in both urban and forest environments. Males consume significantly more moths than females despite the species showing no other physical differences between sexes.

name: Southwestern Red Squirrel
region: Southwestern US (Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona)
habitat: High-altitude mixed coniferous and spruce-fir forests
description: A tree-dwelling survivor of the last ice age, this species has remained isolated in mountain refuges for over 130,000 years with virtually no genetic exchange between populations. Its scattered populations face an uncertain future as habitat fragmentation threatens to drive them toward extinction.

name: Sowerby's Beaked Whale
region: Northwestern Atlantic (Nantucket to Labrador)
habitat: Deep ocean waters, 200-1,500 meters depth
description: A reclusive deep-sea hunter that dives beyond 1,000 meters while foraging on small fish and squid, identifiable by the pair of teeth positioned far back in the male's jaw. Their dives typically last 30-40 minutes, making them one of the more active beaked whales despite their elusive nature.

name: Sperm Whale
region: Atlantic and Pacific coastal waters, worldwide distribution
habitat: Deep pelagic ocean waters
description: The largest toothed predator on Earth, wielding a brain five times heavier than a human's and capable of diving to depths exceeding 7,000 feet. Hunts using echolocation clicks as loud as 236 decibels underwater.

name: Spiny Pocket Mouse
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, California, Nevada) and Baja California
habitat: Rocky desert landscapes and desert islands
description: A nocturnal desert dweller weighing just 0.5 ounces, distinguished by flexible spines running down its back that help it navigate rough, rocky terrain. Its tail grows to 126% the length of its body and head combined, aiding balance in the harsh desert environment.

name: Spotted Bat
region: Southwestern and Western US, British Columbia
habitat: Cliff roosts, deciduous and coniferous forests, desert, grasslands, riparian areas
description: Possesses the largest ears of any North American bat species at up to 4 cm long, using them to hunt grasshoppers and moths across desert and forest landscapes. These distinctive white-spotted black bats weigh only 15 grams despite their 35 cm wingspan.

name: Spotted Ground Squirrel
region: Central and western US (South Dakota to Texas), Mexico
habitat: Sandy arid regions, dunes, sparse grasslands
description: One of North America's tiniest squirrels, this spotted burrower enters hibernation for up to 10 months per year and employs 7 distinct alert postures to warn companions of danger. Males engage in frenzied mating displays, darting in and out of burrows in rapid succession.

name: Spotted Seal
region: Alaska (Bristol Bay to Demarcation Point)
habitat: Arctic ice floes and open ocean waters
description: A deep-diving seal capable of plunging to 980 feet while hunting, marked by dark irregular spots that distinguish it from its close relative, the harbor seal. Seals in the Yellow Sea population migrate over 2,100 miles annually.

name: Star-nosed Mole
region: Northern North America, eastern Canada to southeastern US
habitat: Wet lowlands, marshes, and stream banks
description: A hamster-sized burrower armed with 25,000 sensory receptors in its bizarre star-shaped snout, capable of identifying and consuming prey in as little as 120 milliseconds—making it the fastest-eating mammal on Earth. Its brain decides whether food is edible in just 8 milliseconds, operating at the very limit of neural speed.

name: Stejneger's Beaked Whale
region: Northern Pacific (Bering Sea, Alaska to California)
habitat: Deep ocean waters
description: A deep-diving enigma of the northern Pacific, armed with massive saber-like teeth that point forward and inward—only surpassed in length by two other beaked whale species. Males bear extensive battle scars from fierce tooth-to-tooth combat with rivals.

name: Steller Sea Lion
region: Pacific Northwest to Alaska; California to Kamchatka
habitat: Coastal marine waters and isolated rocky islands
description: The largest eared seal in the world, these massive marine hunters can weigh up to 1,120 kg and dive deep using specialized adaptations like apnea and bradycardia to maximize oxygen storage. Once hunted to near extinction, they have made a remarkable recovery after being removed from the Endangered Species List in 2013.

name: Steller's Sea Cow
region: Bering Sea (Alaska/Russia border), formerly North Pacific
habitat: Shallow coastal waters with kelp forests
description: A massive marine herbivore weighing up to 10 tons with a forked tail and bristled upper lip instead of teeth, hunted to extinction within 27 years of European discovery in 1741. Despite its enormous size, it was so slow and docile that it could be caught by hand, feeding peacefully on kelp in the frigid Bering Sea.

name: Stephen's Woodrat
region: Arizona, New Mexico, and Utah
habitat: Rocky pinyon-juniper woodlands and mountain areas
description: A nocturnal specialist that has evolved 2.4 times more of a protective intestinal protein than its generalist cousins, allowing it to safely consume toxic juniper leaves that would poison other rodents. This tiny architect constructs elaborate debris middens among rocks and trees, raising up to two litters yearly with an average of two offspring each.

name: Stephens' Kangaroo Rat
region: Southern California, primarily western Riverside County
habitat: Sparsely vegetated temperate grassland with gravelly soils
description: This medium-sized rodent's tail is 1.45 times longer than its body, and it creates a keystone effect on its ecosystem by clearing vegetation patches and dispersing seeds through caching, increasing plant diversity around its burrows.

name: Stoat
region: Alaska, western Canada, and Arctic regions east to Greenland
habitat: Grasslands, tundra, forests, and burrow systems
description: This elongated predator can pursue prey into the deepest burrows thanks to its snake-like body, and females are sexually mature at just 2-3 weeks old while still blind and hairless. Males are 25% larger than females and possess territories up to 50 times bigger than subordinate rivals.

name: Strecker's Pocket Gopher
region: Texas
habitat: Underground burrows in grasslands and prairies
description: A burrowing rodent that was long mistaken for its close relative until chromosomal analysis revealed it as a distinct species. Named after American herpetologist John Kern Strecker, this pocket gopher spends most of its life underground, using powerful claws to excavate elaborate tunnel systems across Texas grasslands.

name: Striped Dolphin
region: Atlantic Ocean, Gulf of Mexico
habitat: Temperate and tropical offshore waters
description: Sleek oceanic sprinter recognizable by distinctive black stripes running across its eyes and flanks, capable of diving to depths of 700 meters to hunt squid and fish. Known as "streakers" in the Pacific for their rapid escape behavior, these dolphins live in groups numbering up to thousands and can live 55-60 years.

name: Striped Skunk
region: Southern Canada, continental United States, northern Mexico
habitat: Mixed woodlands, brushy fields, cultivated areas with wooded ravines
description: Armed with two scent glands containing 15 milliliters of musk each, this striped defender can spray a potent mixture of sulfur compounds up to several meters—an odor likened to perfume musk, garlic, burning sulfur, and sewer gas magnified a thousand times.

name: Swamp Rabbit
region: South-central and southeastern US, Gulf Coast
habitat: Cypress swamps, marshes, floodplains, and wetlands
description: The largest cottontail rabbit species, this amphibious hunter can dive into water and hide motionless with only its nose visible to escape pursuing dogs. Snow cover can nearly double its mortality rate by concealing food and reducing hiding spots.

name: Swift Fox
region: Western grasslands from Montana to Texas, southern Canada
habitat: Short-grass prairies and desert grasslands
description: A cat-sized canine that nearly vanished in the 1930s but made a remarkable comeback through reintroduction efforts, now running at speeds over 60 km/h across the prairies it once disappeared from entirely.

name: Taiga Vole
region: Alaska and Northwestern Canada
habitat: Boreal forests and tundra near water, bogs, and wetlands
description: This unusually large vole must eat every 24 hours or starve to death, consuming its entire liver glycogen supply in just 4 hours. Named for the rusty-yellow coloring around its face, it survives harsh winters by huddling with 5-10 companions in extensive underground burrows that sometimes extend into water.

name: Tawny-bellied Cotton Rat
region: Arizona, New Mexico, and central Mexico
habitat: Dense grasslands and bunchgrass fields
description: A modest rodent weighing merely 206-222 grams, yet prized by researchers for its remarkable ability to contract human diseases like HIV-1 and tuberculosis with immune responses nearly identical to humans, making it invaluable for developing vaccines and treatments.

name: Texas Antelope Squirrel
region: Western Texas, south-central New Mexico, and northern Mexico
habitat: Desert burrows and rock crevices near bushes and shrubs
description: This small desert dweller can consume so much prickly pear cactus fruit that its flesh turns purple, and remarkably remains active year-round without hibernating despite harsh desert conditions.

name: Texas Kangaroo Rat
region: North-central Texas and Oklahoma
habitat: Clay-loam prairie with mesquite and lotebush brush, prairie mounds
description: This relatively large kangaroo rat stores seeds and vegetation in its cheek pouches and can survive on bare ground and prairie mounds without brush, making it a surprisingly adaptable rodent despite its vulnerable status across only 13 Texas counties.

name: Texas Mouse
region: South-central US (Texas, Oklahoma, Missouri, Kansas, Arkansas)
habitat: Rocky areas with cedar glades and hardwood forests, limestone woods with oak and hickory
description: A nimble nocturnal climber that spends about 70% of its time in trees, using its long bicolored tail and large hind feet to navigate vertical surfaces in near-total darkness. Weighing only 25-35 grams, this arboreal rodent is perfectly adapted for life in the canopy.

name: Texas Pocket Gopher
region: Southern Texas and northeastern Mexico
habitat: Sandy soils and sand drifts, including coastal islands
description: An underground specialist that constructs burrow systems stretching nearly 100 feet, this rodent pulls plant roots down into its tunnels to avoid surface predators and even practices coprophagy to maximize nutrient extraction.

name: Thirteen-lined Ground Squirrel
region: Central and northern North America grasslands and prairies
habitat: Grasslands and prairies
description: This striped burrower can survive over six months in hibernation without food or water, slowing its breathing from 200 breaths per minute to just one breath every five minutes. Known for its distinctive upright posture and bird-like alarm trill, it dives into burrows up to 20 feet long at the first sign of danger.

name: Tipton Kangaroo Rat
region: Central California (Kern and Tulare Counties)
habitat: Ground burrows in grasslands and scrublands
description: A diminutive desert hopper weighing just 35-38 grams, this creature compensates for its tiny forefeet with exceptionally oversized hind legs and a 125mm tail used for balance during explosive leaps. Known to survive on a diet of seeds with only occasional insects, it remains one of California's most critically endangered rodents.

name: Townsend's Big-eared Bat
region: Canada, United States, and Mexico
habitat: Caves, mines, abandoned buildings, and rocky crevices
description: A master of stealth echolocation, this tiny moth-hunter whispers its hunting calls at frequencies so low they're nearly impossible for humans to detect. With ears as long as its body and the agility to hover mid-flight, it can pluck prey from the air at speeds up to 12 mph.

name: Townsend's Chipmunk
region: Pacific Northwest (southwestern British Columbia through western Washington and Oregon)
habitat: Pacific Northwest forests with dense shrubbery
description: A large chipmunk reaching 14 inches from nose to tail, identifiable by its grayish-and-reddish tail and distinctive brown coloration. In mild climates, this omnivorous forager remains active year-round, switching from summer berries to acorns and conifer seeds as seasons change.

name: Townsend's Ground Squirrel
region: Great Basin and Columbia Plateau (Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Utah, Nevada, California)
habitat: High desert shrublands, arid grasslands, and sagebrush-grasslands
description: A desert burrower that enters dormancy for 7.5 to 9 months each year, emerging in late winter to breed and forage. Critical prey for ferruginous hawks and prairie falcons across the Great Basin, with population densities fluctuating wildly from 3 to 331 individuals per hectare depending on habitat conditions.

name: Townsend's Mole
region: Pacific Northwest (British Columbia to northwestern California)
habitat: Open lowland and wooded areas with moist soils
description: North America's largest mole, this velvet-furred digger weighs only 138 grams but possesses massive spade-shaped front paws perfectly adapted for tunneling through moist soil in search of earthworms and invertebrates year-round.

name: Townsend's Pocket Gopher
region: Northwestern US (Idaho, Oregon, Nevada, California)
habitat: Deep, moist soils near rivers and lakes, irrigated cropland
description: A powerful underground excavator that can measure up to 11 inches long and weigh nearly a pound, equipped with massive digging claws and fur-lined cheek pouches. This solitary burrower spends almost its entire adult life underground, leaving behind telltale mounds of soil across the landscape.

name: Townsend's Vole
region: Pacific Northwest (British Columbia, Washington, Oregon) and northern California
habitat: Wet meadows, marshes, and flood plains
description: One of North America's largest voles, capable of reaching population densities of up to 800 individuals per hectare—so prolific it can completely exclude other species from its territory. Its prominent ears and dark coloring make it easily recognizable among its smaller vole cousins.

name: Tropical Bottlenose Whale
region: Hawaii, possibly Gulf of Mexico and tropical Atlantic
habitat: Tropical and subtropical ocean waters
description: A mysterious deep-diving cetacean that was once thought to be the world's rarest whale until recent decades brought over 65 sightings. Groups can exceed 70 individuals and dive for up to 45 minutes in search of deep-sea prey.

name: Trowbridge's Shrew
region: Pacific Northwest and California coast
habitat: Forested areas with ground debris, dry and moist forests, swampy woodlands
description: A tiny shrew weighing only 3.8 grams that molts twice yearly, switching between a thick gray winter coat and a lighter brown summer coat. Distinguished by its distinctive bi-colored tail with a sharp line separating the darker top from the lighter bottom.

name: True's Beaked Whale
region: Northeastern Atlantic coast, Nova Scotia to Florida
habitat: Deep ocean waters, North Atlantic
description: A deep-diving squid hunter that can reach 17 feet in length, identifiable by its bulbous melon and small teeth set at the very tip of its beak. Males bear distinctive scars from battles with one another and cookiecutter sharks.

name: Tundra Shrew
region: Alaska, northern Yukon Territory, Northwest Territories, northwestern British Columbia
habitat: Tundra hillsides with shrubs, grassy vegetation, and dry ridges near marshes or bogs
description: This tiny arctic predator weighs only 11 grams yet hunts insects and worms year-round, tunneling through snow in winter and remaining active both day and night without hibernation.

name: Tundra Vole
region: Alaska and northwestern Canada
habitat: Damp tundra and moist meadows near water
description: This tiny 50-gram rodent survives year-round in harsh tundra by creating elaborate snow tunnels in winter and storing licorice roots for sustenance. Its name comes from its 'economical' behavior of meticulously hoarding seeds and roots in underground burrows.

name: Uinta Chipmunk
region: Western United States (Utah, Arizona, Nevada, California, Wyoming, Colorado)
habitat: Montane and subalpine pine and fir forests
description: A nimble forest dweller that can emit bursts of sharp "chip" sounds lasting up to 15 minutes from exposed perches. Despite their small 67-gram frame, these solitary chipmunks fiercely defend territories spanning up to 12 acres in high mountain elevations.

name: Uinta Ground Squirrel
region: Northern and central Utah, eastern Idaho, southwestern Montana, and western Wyoming
habitat: Alpine and subalpine meadows, pastures, and shrub-steppe
description: Known locally as a "chisler," this ground squirrel emerges from hibernation weighing just 7.4 ounces and nearly doubles its weight before retreating underground again—spending less than half the year awake. Despite living in colonies, adults are aggressively territorial and communicate through six distinct vocalizations to warn of predators or assert dominance.

name: Unalaska Collared Lemming
region: Aleutian Islands, Alaska
habitat: Arctic tundra
description: A small arctic rodent found only on two remote Aleutian islands, this collared lemming is so poorly studied that its conservation status remains a mystery to science. Equipped with specialized winter claws that help it burrow through snow, it thrives in one of North America's harshest tundra environments.

name: Underwood's Bonneted Bat
region: Southwestern US, Mexico, and Central America
habitat: Tree hollows and palm fronds in dry areas
description: A swift nocturnal hunter with a 20-22 inch wingspan, making it the second-largest bat in the US. This aerial acrobat feasts on grasshoppers and moths while flying through the night on long, narrow wings built for speed.

name: Utah Prairie Dog
region: South-central Utah
habitat: Semi-arid grasslands and swale areas with herbaceous vegetation
description: The smallest prairie dog species, these highly social rodents engineer elaborate underground towns that transform landscapes and provide homes for countless other species. Once numbering 95,000 individuals in 1920, their population plummeted 87% by the 1970s due to habitat destruction and human persecution.

name: Vagrant Shrew
region: Western North America, west of the Continental Divide
habitat: Wet grasslands, meadows, and open coniferous forests near water sources
description: A hypermetabolic shrew that must consume over 160% of its own body weight in food daily to survive, making it one of nature's most voracious eaters relative to size. Despite weighing only 4-8 grams, it actively hunts earthworms and insects throughout the day in quick 5-10 minute bursts.

name: Velvety Free-tailed Bat
region: Florida Keys, Cuba, Mexico, and throughout the Caribbean
habitat: Open areas, forest edges, and around streams and ponds
description: A nimble nocturnal hunter with a 12-inch wingspan that snatches moths, beetles, and flying ants from the air at dusk. Notable as one of the few bat species ever documented as prey for a giant centipede, which injected venom into the bat's neck while roosting.

name: Velvety Fruit-eating Bat
region: Arizona (rare vagrant)
habitat: Tropical forests and woodland areas
description: A diminutive fruit bat weighing less than a penny, with velvety black fur and a forearm barely over an inch long, this elusive species roosts in Central and South American canopies and occasionally strays into the southwestern United States.

name: Vervet Monkey
region: Introduced populations in Florida (Dania Beach area)
habitat: Urban and rural environments, fragmented vegetation
description: This African primate possesses up to 30 distinct alarm calls—each acoustically unique and designed to warn of specific predators like leopards, eagles, and pythons. Known for remarkable cognitive abilities including individual recognition and complex social hierarchies, it serves as a key model for understanding human-like behaviors such as anxiety and social dependency.

name: Virginia Opossum
region: Continental US and southern Canada, expanding northward from Maryland to Maine, Ontario, and British Columbia
habitat: Urban and suburban areas, forests, and mixed terrain near food sources
description: North America's only marsupial north of Mexico, equipped with 50 teeth—more than any other land mammal on the continent—and an opposable thumb on its hind feet for gripping. When threatened, it famously plays dead with such conviction that its heart rate drops by half and breathing becomes nearly undetectable.

name: Wagner's Bonneted Bat
region: Southern US (Florida), Mexico, Central America
habitat: Subtropical and tropical forests, urban areas
description: A master of the night sky, this medium-sized bat flies at remarkable speeds in nearly straight lines while emitting piercing high-pitched screams that can be heard mid-flight. With a wingspan of 41-47 centimeters and the ability to roost in urban environments, it thrives alongside human civilization despite being a rapid, elusive insect hunter.

name: Walrus
region: Arctic Alaska, Bering Sea
habitat: Arctic ice floes and shallow continental shelf waters
description: An enormous marine mammal weighing up to 2,000 kg (4,400 lbs) with elongated tusks reaching 1 meter in length, used to haul itself onto ice and maintain breathing holes. Armed with highly sensitive whiskers capable of detecting prey just 2-3 mm thick, it vacuums benthic mollusks from the seafloor using a piston-like tongue that creates powerful suction.

name: Washington Ground Squirrel
region: Pacific Northwest (Washington and Oregon)
habitat: Sagebrush and grassland in the Columbia River Basin
description: This burrowing rodent hibernates for 7–8 months annually and can disperse over 3.5 kilometers from its birthplace, with juvenile males showing remarkable survival rates higher than their sedentary siblings.

name: Water Vole
region: Northwestern US and southern western Canada (British Columbia, Alberta, Oregon, Washington, Montana, Idaho, Wyoming, Utah)
habitat: Alpine and semi-alpine meadows near water sources
description: The largest North American vole with unusually large hind feet (25-34mm) that make it an exceptional swimmer, capable of tunneling through snow for 7-8 months of the year without surfacing. Despite their rodent size, these semi-aquatic burrowers maintain a metabolic rate so high they must consume significantly more food than other rodents their size.

name: West Indian Manatee
region: Southeastern US (Florida coast), Gulf Coast of Texas
habitat: Shallow coastal waters, rivers, and estuaries
description: A gentle giant weighing up to 3,649 pounds that grazes on seagrass for 5-8 hours daily, powered by an endless conveyor belt of replacement molars that migrate through its jaw at 1-2 millimeters per month. Its entire body is covered in ultrasensitive whiskers that allow it to navigate murky waters and detect prey with the same precision fish use their lateral line system.

name: Western Deermouse
region: Western North America, west of the Mississippi River
habitat: Forests, woodlands, grasslands, and brushy areas from boreal forests to desert scrub
description: A key prey species for raptors and carnivores across western North America, this tiny rodent exhibits remarkable adaptability with distinct forest and grassland morphs—the forest variant sports long tails and large ears, while the grassland morph is compact and built for prairie life. Some populations can completely turn over in just a single summer due to predation and environmental pressures.

name: Western Gray Squirrel
region: Western coast of the United States and Mexico, from Washington to Baja California
habitat: Coniferous and oak forests, arboreal tree dweller up to 2,000 m elevation
description: A shy forest acrobat weighing less than a kilogram with a distinctive silver-gray coat and perpetually bushy tail curved in an 'S' shape. Despite being the largest native tree squirrel on the western coast, it struggles to compete with introduced species and can take six months or longer to fledge its young.

name: Western Harvest Mouse
region: Western US from British Columbia to Texas, extending to interior Mexico
habitat: Fields, grasslands, and shrublands with protective vegetation
description: A prolific nocturnal rodent capable of producing 40 to 60 offspring annually, with females sometimes bearing up to 14 litters per year. Despite weighing less than an ounce, this agile climber constructs intricate spherical grass nests and stores food in underground vaults to survive harsh winters.

name: Western Heather Vole
region: Western North America, British Columbia, Yukon, and western United States
habitat: Alpine meadows, shrubby areas, dry forests, and tundra regions near water
description: A tiny alpine rodent weighing just 40 grams that survives harsh winters by tunneling beneath the snow and storing food year-round. Once considered the same species as its eastern cousin, this docile vole has migrated northward over millennia as glaciers retreated from regions as far south as Tennessee.

name: Western Jumping Mouse
region: Western North America from Yukon to New Mexico
habitat: Mountainous meadows and forests near fresh water, dominated by alder, aspen, or willow
description: A tiny nocturnal rodent capable of leaping up to 28 inches across the ground when startled, relying on explosive jumps to escape predators. This hibernator sleeps for 8-10 months per year without eating, surviving entirely on fat reserves while waking roughly once every 38 days.

name: Western Mastiff Bat
region: Southwestern US (California, Arizona, New Mexico, Texas)
habitat: Desert scrub, woodlands, grasslands; roosts in rocky cliffs and canyons
description: North America's largest bat, boasting a wingspan over 22 inches and the ability to sustain flight at high speeds for 6-7 hours nightly while traveling up to 14.9 miles. Its echolocation call is so powerful it can be heard from 990 feet away.

name: Western Meadow Vole
region: Midwestern and western North America from Ontario to Alaska, south to Missouri and central Washington
habitat: Wet meadows, sedge fens, riparian areas, and tallgrass prairie with dense vegetation
description: A small rodent so abundant in northern prairie wetlands that it often comprises over 40% of all small mammals present, driving the survival rates of owls, hawks, and foxes that depend on its cyclical population surges.

name: Western Pipistrelle
region: Western US and Mexico, from Washington to Michoacán
habitat: Desert lowlands and rock crevices, below 5,000 feet elevation
description: The smallest bat in the United States, weighing just 3-6 grams with a wingspan of only 7.5-8.5 inches, yet capable of flying at speeds as low as 5 mph with remarkable aerial maneuverability. Often the first bat to emerge at dusk and last to vanish at dawn, hunting flying insects in erratic, fluttery flight patterns.

name: Western Red-backed Vole
region: Northern California and Western Oregon
habitat: Mature coniferous forests and mixed fir-oak forests
description: This small burrower plays a crucial role in forest health by spreading mycorrhizal fungal spores through its droppings, creating a three-way symbiosis that allows trees to thrive—making it an unsung hero of Pacific Northwest ecosystems. Feeds almost exclusively on underground fungal fruiting bodies and can produce 2-7 young per litter year-round.

name: Western Small-footed Myotis
region: Western North America, from British Columbia to Mexico
habitat: Arid and semiarid regions, deserts, badlands, pine and juniper forests
description: This tiny insectivore weighs just 4-5 grams but boasts unusually small feet—half the length of its tibia—and a distinctive black face mask that sets it apart from similar species. Despite its diminutive size, it navigates the night sky with remarkable agility, using echolocation calls that sweep from 60 down to 40 kHz.

name: Western Spotted Skunk
region: Western US, northern Mexico, southwestern British Columbia
habitat: Mixed woodlands, riparian areas, open farmlands, cliffs and canyons
description: This pint-sized skunk reaches sexual maturity faster than any other skunk species and possesses a musk with a uniquely pungent odor containing 2-phenylethanethiol. Despite weighing less than a pound, it can consume prey as large as seabirds and has been observed denning in groups of up to 20 during winter.

name: Western Yellow Bat
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, California, New Mexico), Mexico, and Baja California
habitat: Tree roosts including cottonwoods, sycamores, and oaks; palm fronds when available
description: A diminutive insectivore weighing barely half an ounce with a distinctive bright yellow coat, this bat roosts in desert trees and palm fronds while hunting for flying insects under the southwestern night sky.

name: White-ankled Mouse
region: Southwestern US (New Mexico, Oklahoma, Texas) and Mexico
habitat: Rocky and bushy terrain in deserts, grasslands, and woodlands
description: Often mistaken for its close relatives, this tiny rodent can be definitively identified by the uniquely long, cartilaginous baculum of males—a feature shared by no other mouse in its range. Unlike the sympatric Texas mouse, it stubbornly avoids trees regardless of habitat conditions.

name: White-beaked Dolphin
region: Cape Cod and St. Lawrence River eastward
habitat: Cold temperate ocean waters, continental shelf
description: A robust oceanic acrobat with a distinctive white beak that can dive to 148 feet and communicate through whistles audible to other dolphins up to 6.2 miles away. Possesses more vertebrae than any other dolphin species at up to 92, making it exceptionally flexible in the cold North Atlantic waters.

name: White-eared Pocket Mouse
region: Southern California mountains
habitat: High-elevation pine forests and chaparral
description: A tiny mountain dweller named for the distinctive white-edged ears adorning its yellowish-brown fur, this pocket mouse reaches only 155 mm in length and inhabits pine forests above 4,900 feet in the San Bernardino and Tehachapi Mountains.

name: White-footed Mouse
region: Eastern and central North America from Canada to southwestern US and Mexico
habitat: Forests, woodlands, and urban parks; nests in trees and human structures
description: A nimble forest dweller that has evolved distinct adaptations to urban life in just a few generations, developing shorter teeth, specialized metabolism for processed foods, and enhanced immunity to city pathogens. Urban populations show genetic evidence of rapid evolution, including faster sperm production driven by intense competition in dense park populations.

name: White-footed Vole
region: United States only
habitat: Temperate forests
description: A diminutive forest dweller found exclusively in American temperate woodlands, this tiny rodent remains one of the least-studied voles in North America despite its stable population status.

name: White-nosed Coati
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico), introduced population in Florida
habitat: Tropical and subtropical forests, wooded areas from sea level to 9,800 feet
description: A tree-climbing omnivore with an elongated snout and prehensile tail, known to pollinate balsa trees by inserting its nose into flowers and disseminating pollen across the forest while foraging for fruits, insects, and small vertebrates during daylight hours.

name: White-sided Jackrabbit
region: Southwestern New Mexico to central Mexico
habitat: High-elevation grassy plains and plateaus
description: A nocturnal sprinter with distinctive pure white sides that flash when fleeing predators, capable of making long, high leaps while running in a zig-zag pattern to evade pursuers. These hares form devoted pair bonds and are primarily threatened by nighttime vehicle strikes from US Border Patrol traffic.

name: White-tailed Antelope Squirrel
region: Southwestern US (Oregon to New Mexico) and Baja California
habitat: Arid desert regions and shrublands
description: This desert sprinter is surprisingly carnivorous, hunting lizards and rodents despite being a ground squirrel. Active during the day to avoid nighttime predators, it covers up to 4 acres daily across some of the harshest terrain in North America.

name: White-tailed Deer
region: Eastern North America, Rocky Mountain foothills, southwestern Arizona, Mexico
habitat: Deciduous forests, forest edges, mixed woodlands, prairies, savannas, riparian corridors
description: This fleet-footed ungulate can sprint at 60 km/h and leap up to 9 meters horizontally, making it nearly impossible to catch once alarmed. Its distinctive white tail serves as a warning flag, flashing danger to nearby herd members in an instant.

name: White-tailed Jackrabbit
region: Western and Central North America, from British Columbia to the Great Plains
habitat: Plains, prairies, and alpine meadows with scattered coniferous trees
description: A massive hare capable of reaching 9 kg in northern regions and leaping up to 16 feet, this prairie sprinter can bound away at 34 mph when detected by predators. In winter, northern populations turn completely white except for their ears—a stunning seasonal transformation.

name: White-tailed Prairie Dog
region: Western Wyoming, western Colorado, eastern Utah, southern Montana
habitat: High-elevation grasslands and prairie (5,000-10,000 feet)
description: Colonial herbivores that live in complex family units and communicate through barks and visual signals, these tan-brown rodents have mysteriously declined to occupy just 8% of their original range despite conservation efforts.

name: White-throated Woodrat
region: Western US and Mexico (Utah, Colorado, Arizona, California, Texas south to central Mexico)
habitat: Desert grasslands, shrublands, pinyon-juniper woodlands, and saguaro cactus communities
description: A master architect of the desert, this rodent constructs elaborate midden houses up to 3 feet tall using locally scavenged materials like cactus parts and sticks, with a nest chamber kept meticulously free of feces. It can survive on just cacti and xerophytic plants, extracting water from spiny species and storing food for harsh seasons.

name: White-toothed Woodrat
region: New Mexico and Trans-Pecos Texas
habitat: Woodland to desert habitats with cacti, especially cholla and prickly pear
description: A master architect of the desert, this rodent constructs elaborate stick-and-vegetation dens that provide refuge from predators and extreme heat. Its diet revolves around cacti, making it perfectly adapted to arid environments where other mammals struggle to survive.

name: Wild Boar
region: Southern and central US, spreading northward
habitat: Forests, wetlands, and agricultural areas
description: An invasive powerhouse capable of digging 3-4 inches into frozen ground and uprooting rocks weighing up to 110 pounds with its massive head and neck. Males can reach 600 pounds in northeastern Asia and develop razor-sharp tusks that grow throughout their entire lives.

name: Wolverine
region: Northern Canada, Alaska; historically present throughout much of northern US
habitat: Arctic, boreal, and alpine tundra; remote northern forests
description: A muscular glutton with a reputation for ferocity wildly out of proportion to its medium-dog size, capable of killing prey many times larger than itself including moose and elk. Armed with a rotated molar tooth that shears frozen meat and fur so thick it resists frost, it ranges over 620 square kilometers hunting and scavenging across the frozen north.

name: Wood Bison
region: Northern Canada and Alaska; introduced to Yakutia, Russia
habitat: Boreal forests and northern grasslands
description: The heaviest and longest terrestrial animal in North America, reaching up to 1,179 kg and 3.35 meters in body length. Its dense woolly coat is so effective at insulation that falling snow accumulates on its fur rather than melting, keeping it warm in temperatures plummeting to −60°C.

name: Woodland Jumping Mouse
region: Northeastern North America
habitat: Cool, moist boreal woodlands with spruce-fir and hemlock, near streams and meadows
description: A diminutive rodent capable of leaping up to 10 feet using its extraordinarily powerful hind legs and lengthy tail, which comprises 60% of its body length. During hibernation, this mouse's body temperature plummets from 98.6°F to 36°F, and only one in three mice survives the winter.

name: Woodland Vole
region: Eastern North America, ranging to Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, and Texas
habitat: Deciduous forests, apple orchards, and dry fields with moist, friable soils
description: This diminutive burrower causes nearly $50 million in annual damage to apple orchards through root feeding, making it one of agriculture's smallest but costliest pests. Its reduced eyes, ears, and tail are perfectly adapted for a subterranean lifestyle where it rarely ventures above ground.

name: Wyoming Ground Squirrel
region: Northwestern United States
habitat: Grasslands and open meadows
description: A small burrowing rodent endemic to the Pacific Northwest, identifiable by its elegant coloring and pale color variants that resemble cream-colored mutations found in laboratory rats.

name: Wyoming Pocket Gopher
region: Southern Wyoming
habitat: Flat, well-drained areas with greasewood and saltbush
description: The smallest member of its genus, this pocket gopher weighs just 44-72 grams yet possesses disproportionately powerful digging claws and cheek pouches that extend 44mm back from its snout for carrying food through narrow underground tunnels.

name: Yellow-bellied Marmot
region: Rocky Mountains, Sierra Nevada, Great Basin; southwestern Canada to northern New Mexico
habitat: Alpine meadows, talus fields, and open rocky areas above 2,000 meters
description: This rotund ground squirrel spends 80% of its life underground, hibernating for eight months straight in burrows up to 23 feet deep. Known as the "whistle pig" for its distinctive alarm calls that warn colonies of approaching predators.

name: Yellow-cheeked Chipmunk
region: Northern California coast
habitat: Coastal coniferous forests
description: The largest chipmunk in its genus, this secretive rodent emits a distinctive low-pitched "chuck-chuck" call and can grow up to 11.7 inches long. Despite its limited range of just 20,000 square kilometers along the California coast, its population remains steady and untroubled by threats.

name: Yellow-faced Pocket Gopher
region: Southwestern US and Northern Mexico
habitat: Shortgrass prairies with deep sandy or silty soils
description: An industrious burrower that excavates tunnel systems averaging 75.8 meters in length, pulling entire plants into its underground network by their roots. Males continue growing throughout their lives, eventually becoming significantly larger than females.

name: Yellow-nosed Cotton Rat
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico, Texas) and Mexico
habitat: Mountain grasslands, rocky slopes, and pinyon-juniper woodlands
description: A drought-adapted rodent distinguished by its distinctive ochre-colored snout and eye rings, capable of reproducing rapidly with litters of 2-6 young that open their eyes within a day of birth. Despite its small 155mm frame, it actively forages during daylight hours and can cache food supplies underground for later consumption.

name: Yellow-pine Chipmunk
region: Western North America, parts of Canada and the United States
habitat: Brush-covered areas and coniferous forests at high elevation
description: This industrious rodent defies typical mammalian trends by having females larger than males, and survives harsh winters entirely on cached seeds gathered during summer—storing food up to 4.9 meters apart to maximize survival odds through hibernation.

name: Yuma Myotis
region: Western North America, from British Columbia to Texas
habitat: Lowland areas near standing water; caves, attics, bridges, and mines
description: This tiny 6-gram bat navigates darkness by emitting ultrasonic calls that sweep from 59 to 72 kHz, using echolocation to snag insects mid-flight at speeds up to 9 mph while hunting above water's surface.

name: Zacatecan Deer Mouse
region: Mexico (Sierra Madre Occidental and Oriental)
habitat: Rocky mountainous terrain with chaparral, juniper-oak-pine forests, and semi-arid brush
description: A nimble climber with a tail longer than its body, capable of producing up to three litters of three pups each during the rainy season, with some females reaching sexual maturity and breeding within just six months of birth.

name: African Collared-dove
region: Not found in wild North America; introduced to southwestern United States
habitat: Arid lands near water sources
description: A small dove measuring just 26 cm with pinkish plumage that serves as the wild ancestor of the domestic Barbary dove, capable of hybridizing to produce new color variations in captive populations.

name: Allen's Hummingbird
region: Western US (coastal California and southern Oregon)
habitat: Brushy woods, gardens, and meadows
description: Weighing less than a penny, this hummingbird performs a frantic 25-foot courtship dive followed by a 100-foot plunge that produces a characteristic sharp tail flutter to attract mates. Despite their tiny size, males are fiercely territorial and have been known to attack hawks and kestrels.

name: Alpine Swift
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Not applicable
description: An Old World alpine swift found exclusively in Africa, Europe, and Asia—not present in North America. Capable of staying aloft for over 200 consecutive days without landing, performing all vital functions including sleep while flying.

name: American Black Duck
region: Eastern North America, Great Lakes to Atlantic Coast
habitat: Coastal and freshwater wetlands, marshes, estuaries, beaver ponds
description: The heaviest dabbling duck in its genus, weighing up to 3.6 pounds, this eastern waterfowl is known for regularly hybridizing with mallards—a trait so common that some scientists debate whether it deserves to be its own species.

name: American Flamingo
region: Southern Florida, Yucatan Peninsula (rare vagrant to eastern US)
habitat: Saline lagoons, mudflats, shallow brackish coastal lakes
description: A brilliant pink wading bird with a specialized salt-filtering beak that can extract nutrients from hypersaline water—and even drink near-boiling water from geysers. Known for elaborate synchronized courtship dances and lifespans exceeding 40 years, among the longest of any bird species.

name: American Wigeon
region: Canada, Alaska, Interior West, Pacific Flyway
habitat: Open wetlands, marshes, wet grasslands
description: Known for its cream-colored cap and green eye mask, this dabbling duck is a cunning "poacher" that steals vegetation brought to the surface by diving birds—earning it the nickname "robber duck." With a largely vegetarian diet and distinctive three-note whistle, it forms flocks of millions across North America.

name: Amethyst-throated Mountain-gem
region: Southern Mexico, Central America; rare vagrant to Texas and Quebec
habitat: Montane evergreen and pine-oak forests at 3,000–9,800 feet elevation
description: A brilliant jewel of the mountains, this hummingbird weighs less than a penny yet performs acrobatic aerial displays diving toward females up to five times in succession. Males sport a dazzling rosy-pink gorget that shifts to violet-blue in the rarest subspecies, and both sexes produce complex vocalizations with up to nine distinct phrases.

name: Anna's Hummingbird
region: Western North America, from British Columbia to northern Baja California; expanding northward to Pacific Northwest
habitat: Open woodlands, shrubby areas, mountain meadows, urban gardens and parks with flowering plants
description: This iridescent jewel performs acrobatic courtship dives reaching 385 body lengths per second—faster than a Formula 1 racecar relative to body size—while producing an explosive squeak with its tail feathers. The only North American hummingbird with a crimson crown, it can survive subfreezing winters by entering torpor and has expanded its range northward into snowbound cities.

name: Antillean Crested Hummingbird
region: Rare vagrant to Florida
habitat: Tropical moist lowland forests, semi-arid forests, flowering plants from sea-level to high mountains
description: One of the few hummingbirds sporting a distinctive metallic crest, this tiny Caribbean jewel holds the distinction of being the first avian species ever documented as prey to a tailless whipscorpion. Males flash brilliant blue-green or golden crests while aggressively defending territory from birds, reptiles, and insects alike.

name: Antillean Nighthawk
region: Florida Keys and the Caribbean
habitat: Open country, cleared forest areas, airports, and pastures
description: A master of aerial acrobatics that pulls dramatic dives just feet from the ground, creating a distinctive booming sound with its wings. This nocturnal insect-hunter emits a sharp pikadik call that echoes overhead, earning it the Taíno name querequequé in the Caribbean.

name: Antillean Palm-swift
region: Florida (vagrant)
habitat: Dry grassy areas with palm patches, scrublands, and urban areas
description: A tiny aerial acrobat weighing less than half an ounce, this swift hunts insects on the wing while producing an almost constant twittering call. It builds elaborate hanging pouch nests from plant fibers glued together with its own saliva, hanging them from dead palm fronds in small colonies.

name: Bahama Woodstar
region: Southern Florida, rare vagrant
habitat: Gardens, scrubland, tropical forests, pine forests
description: One of the smallest hummingbirds in North America at just 3.1-3.7 inches long and weighing less than a dime, this iridescent jewel can produce high-pitched songs lasting 30 seconds while hovering motionless in mid-air.

name: Baikal Teal
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Not applicable
description: This striking Asian duck breeds across eastern Siberia and winters in East Asia, making a remarkable recovery from near extinction with populations soaring from hundreds of thousands in the 2000s to over 1 million individuals by 2010.

name: Band-tailed Pigeon
region: Western US from British Columbia to California, Arizona; migrates to New Mexico, Utah, Colorado
habitat: Oak, pine-oak, and coniferous forests at higher elevations
description: North America's largest native pigeon, weighing up to 18 ounces with a distinctive pale tail band and iridescent green neck plumage. This species is the closest living relative of the extinct passenger pigeon and may hold the key to resurrecting that species through genetic restoration.

name: Barnacle Goose
region: Northeastern United States and Canada (rare/occasional)
habitat: Coastal wetlands, tidal flats, and cliff breeding grounds
description: A striking black-and-white goose that defies nature itself—medieval Europeans believed these birds grew from driftwood like fruit on a tree, complete with shells. In reality, goslings survive cliff falls up to 70 cm high by jumping from mountain nests, with feathery down cushioning the impact as their parents call from below.

name: Barrow's Goldeneye
region: Northwestern North America, scattered eastern Canada, Iceland
habitat: Wooded lakes, ponds, and coastal estuaries
description: A diving duck that stays flightless for up to 40 days while molting, relying on deep-water mussel beds to survive the vulnerable period. Males defend their territories with aggressive displays lasting around 6 minutes each.

name: Berylline Hummingbird
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, rarely New Mexico and Texas)
habitat: Oak and pine-oak forests, scrublands, deciduous and thorn forests
description: A tiny emerald jewel weighing merely 4.4 grams, this hummingbird dominates feeding territories with aggressive territoriality and can hover in place by beating its wings up to 80 times per second.

name: Black Francolin
region: Southwestern Louisiana, South Florida
habitat: Scrubland and grasslands with cultivated crops, near water sources
description: This explosive gamebird prefers to creep away unseen rather than fly, but when disturbed launches into rapid, direct flight punctuated by graceful glides. Males attract mates with an extraordinary creaking call that echoes all day long during the April breeding season.

name: Black Scoter
region: Northern North America; winters along US coasts and Great Lakes
habitat: Coastal waters, sea bays, freshwater lakes and rivers
description: A bulky sea duck with an unmistakable swollen yellow bill, the male is entirely black while diving for crustaceans and molluscs in coastal waters. Nests later than most North American ducks, with females brooding their young for about 3 weeks before the chicks must fend for themselves.

name: Black Swan
region: Southern Florida, California coast, North Carolina (introduced/escaped populations only)
habitat: Lakes, swamps, and coastal wetlands
description: A striking all-black waterbird with a brilliant red bill and surprisingly long S-curved neck—one of the longest proportionally among all swans. Though native only to Australia, escaped captive birds have established small populations across the globe, with some colonies in North America numbering in the dozens.

name: Black Swift
region: Western North America from British Columbia to Costa Rica, with breeding sites concentrated in Colorado
habitat: High cliff faces near waterfalls and ocean surf
description: A master of aerial hunting, this swift spends nearly its entire life on the wing, foraging for flying insects while resembling a sleek flying cigar with curved wings. Fewer than 150 breeding sites exist in the United States, with most birds mysteriously wintering in the Brazilian rainforest—a journey tracked for the first time in 2012.

name: Black-bellied Whistling-duck
region: Southern US, Mexico, Central and South America; expanding northward to Midwest and Eastern US
habitat: Shallow freshwater ponds, lakes, marshes, and wetlands with abundant vegetation
description: A highly social duck famous for its clear whistling calls and remarkable monogamous bonds that can last for many years—a trait usually seen in geese and swans. This expanding species has recently colonized northern states like Ohio and Wisconsin, defying its tropical origins.

name: Black-billed Cuckoo
region: Eastern North America, breeding east of the Rockies; rare vagrant to western states
habitat: Forest edges, mixed woodlands, wetlands with shrubs and thickets
description: This nomadic insectivore can consume toxic spongy moth caterpillars that most birds cannot eat, shedding its stomach lining to disgorge indigestible hairs like an owl.
