It beats tent caterpillars against branches and can flock to outbreak areas from great distances, increasing local populations during peak pest years.

name: Black-chinned Hummingbird
region: Western US, southwestern Canada to Mexico
habitat: Mountains, woodlands, orchards, chaparral, and riparian areas near water
description: A tiny aerial acrobat that dives at speeds reaching 60 feet while producing an audible trill through its feathers. Despite weighing mere grams, it possesses the smallest genome of all living amniotes at just 910 million base pairs.

name: Blue-breasted Quail
region: Not native to North America; found in Asia, Southeast Asia, and Australia
habitat: Grasslands and open ground in warm regions
description: The smallest true quail species, this ground-dwelling bird can live up to 13 years in captivity despite reaching only 1.5 years in the wild, and is famous among bird enthusiasts for developing over a dozen distinct color mutations including blue, silver, and cinnamon varieties.

name: Blue-throated Mountain-gem
region: Southeastern Arizona, Southern New Mexico, and Northern Mexico
habitat: Riparian canyons, pine-oak forests, and mixed coniferous forests at high elevations
description: The largest hummingbird in the United States, measuring up to 5 inches long with an iridescent cobalt-blue throat patch. Despite weighing less than a penny, it produces ultrasonic vibrations to stun and disorient its insect prey, and can vocalize across an unusually large frequency range of 1.8 to 30 kHz.

name: Blue-winged Teal
region: North America from Alaska to Nova Scotia; winters along coasts and Central America
habitat: Marshes, ponds, and shallow freshwater wetlands with emergent vegetation
description: A diminutive dabbler that completes one of the longest migrations of any duck, traveling from northern prairies to Central and South America. Males depart breeding grounds weeks before females, making fall flocks conspicuously female-heavy by mid-September.

name: Brant
region: Atlantic coast from Maine to Georgia, with smaller populations in the Northeast and upper Midwest during winter
habitat: Coastal tidal estuaries and salt marshes; occasionally inland agricultural areas
description: This diminutive goose dramatically shifted its entire diet in 1931 when eelgrass blight nearly wiped out the population, and has since maintained sea lettuce as a backup food source—a survival strategy still in use nearly a century later. With fewer than 2.2 kg of body mass, it's one of the smallest geese in the world yet undertakes epic Arctic migrations spanning thousands of miles.

name: Bridled Quail-dove
region: Puerto Rico and Lesser Antilles
habitat: Forested mountain areas with dense understory
description: A ground-foraging dove weighing just 7-8 ounces, distinguished by a bold white facial stripe and iridescent green head in males. This rare Caribbean specialist has been documented hunting and consuming small lizards while probing leaf litter on the forest floor.

name: Broad-billed Hummingbird
region: Southwestern US and Mexico
habitat: Desert canyons, oak woodlands, riparian forests, streamside groves
description: A jewel-like hummingbird weighing just 3-4 grams with a brilliant red bill, capable of hovering motionless and performing acrobatic pendulum displays to attract mates. Its long tongue extends deep into flowers to sip nectar while beating its wings up to 80 times per second.

name: Broad-tailed Hummingbird
region: Western US and Canada to Mexico and Guatemala
habitat: Highland pine and oak woodlands, subalpine meadows, montane valleys
description: A tiny aerial acrobat weighing just 3.6 grams that produces a distinctive buzzing wing trill audible up to 75 meters away during courtship dives. Males defend territories fiercely, with those lacking the signature wing trill losing their ground to more aggressive rivals.

name: Buff-bellied Hummingbird
region: Southern Texas, Gulf Coast, Florida panhandle (winter dispersal)
habitat: Semi-open scrubby woodlands, thorn forests, oak woodlands, urban gardens
description: This iridescent jewel weighs less than a penny yet fiercely defends its feeding territory from rivals and insects alike. It hovers while feeding on nectar from dozens of plant species and can disperse hundreds of miles along coastal regions during winter months.

name: Buff-collared Nightjar
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico)
habitat: Arid canyons, ravines, and thorn scrub
description: A nocturnal aerial hunter that forages up to 33 feet in the air, always returning to the same perch between strikes. Males perform elaborate dawn and dusk songs featuring a distinctive "cuk-a-cheea" call that accelerates and drops suddenly.

name: Bufflehead
region: Alaska, Canada, coastal North America, Great Lakes
habitat: Wooded lakes and ponds, coastal waters, boreal forest
description: One of North America's tiniest ducks, weighing just 13 ounces, this hyperactive diver nests exclusively in old woodpecker holes and arrives at wintering grounds with remarkable punctuality year after year. Its bulbous head can swell dramatically larger when males puff out their feathers during displays.

name: Bumblebee Hummingbird
region: Southeastern Arizona (vagrant)
habitat: Mountain forests and cloudforests
description: One of the smallest hummingbirds in existence, weighing merely 2-2.7 grams and measuring just 2.3 to 3.0 inches long. Its wings beat so rapidly they produce an insect-like buzz audible during courtship displays.

name: Cackling Goose
region: Northern Canada, Alaska; winters throughout most of the US
habitat: Arctic and subarctic tundra; near water during breeding season
description: A highly aggressive defender of its territory, this goose can mate for life up to 20 years and weighs as little as 1.4 kg in its smallest subspecies—making it drastically smaller than its Canada goose cousin despite sharing nearly identical black-and-white plumage.

name: California Quail
region: Western North America, from Oregon to southern California
habitat: Shrubby areas and open woodlands
description: California's official state bird, identifiable by its distinctive curved six-feather crest that droops forward. These highly social birds create circular dust bath indentations 2.8–5.9 inches in diameter and explode into rapid flight when startled, a behavior called 'flushing.'

name: Calliope Hummingbird
region: Western US and Canada, from British Columbia to California; winters in Mexico and Central America
habitat: Mountain meadows, open montane forests, and high-altitude shrublands
description: The smallest bird native to North America at just 2.8–3.9 inches long, yet undertakes an exceptional 5,000-mile annual migration—making it the world's smallest long-distance migrant. During courtship, males dive at high speed while their tail feathers vibrate at frequencies that produce sonic buzzes and wing beats reaching 95 flaps per second.

name: Canada Goose
region: Continental US, Canada, Great Lakes region
habitat: Near fresh water, lakes, ponds, marshes, urban parks
description: A massive waterfowl with a distinctive black head and white chinstrap, capable of weighing up to 24 pounds and flying at altitudes exceeding 29,000 feet during migration. Known for forming aggressive V-shaped squadrons overhead and defending territory with brutal precision—one documented case saw a male peck a rival's head into mud until it drowned.

name: Canvasback
region: Continental US, Alaska, and prairie regions; winters mid-Atlantic and California coasts
habitat: Prairie marshes, prairie potholes, and brackish estuarine bays with submerged vegetation
description: North America's largest diving duck, featuring a distinctive wedge-shaped head and canvas-like white back. This adaptable hunter can switch its diet entirely to Baltic clams when preferred vegetation disappears, a survival strategy that helped it recover from a population collapse of 78% between the 1950s and 1980s.

name: Caroline Islands Swiftlet
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Tropical moist lowland forests
description: Endemic to the Caroline Islands, this tiny swift is perfectly adapted for life in the air, spending most of its day catching insects mid-flight with incredible agility and precision.

name: Chestnut-bellied Sandgrouse
region: Not found in North America (introduced to Hawaii, Nevada in 1960s; species native to Africa and Asia)
habitat: Arid and semi-desert plains with sparse vegetation
description: A desert wanderer capable of traveling up to 50 miles in a single day to find water, this bird is so difficult to keep in captivity that it repeatedly crashes into enclosure walls from sheer panic.

name: Chestnut-winged Cuckoo
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Himalayan forests and tropical Southeast Asian woodlands
description: A deceptive brood parasite that lays nearly spherical eggs in the nests of laughingthrush birds, relying on unsuspecting hosts to raise its young. This 47 cm crested cuckoo migrates thousands of miles between the Himalayas and Southeast Asia each year.

name: Chimney Swift
region: Eastern US and southern Canada; rare in western US
habitat: Open country, savannas, wooded slopes, and humid forests; nests in chimneys and hollow trees
description: A cigar-shaped aerial acrobat that never lands, drinking and bathing on the wing while consuming 5,000-6,000 insects per day with a wingspan that extends 1.5 inches beyond its tail when folded. This gregarious insectivore roosts in communal colonies numbering in the thousands and migrates annually to South America—a journey so demanding that its weight gain before departure is minimal, requiring refueling stops along the way.

name: Chuck-will's-widow
region: Southeastern US, with disjunct populations in Long Island NY, Ontario Canada, and Cape Cod MA
habitat: Near swamps, rocky uplands, and pine woods
description: A nocturnal master of camouflage that swallows small birds and bats whole, this largest North American nightjar hunts with silent wings and announces itself with a slow, vibrating call that sounds like its own name.

name: Chukar
region: Rocky Mountains, Great Basin, high desert areas of California
habitat: Rocky open hillsides with sparse grass and scrub
description: A rotund partridge standing 13-14 inches tall with distinctive black and white barred flanks and a striking black necklace marking across its white throat. Young chukars are renowned for their unique wing-assisted incline running, a behavior scientists study as a model for understanding the evolution of bird flight.

name: Cinnamon Hummingbird
region: Northwestern Mexico to Costa Rica
habitat: Deciduous and semi-deciduous forests, thorn forest
description: A tiny jewel of a bird weighing merely 5-5.5 grams, yet fiercely territorial—defending its feeding sites from larger bees and butterflies with aggressive precision. Its metallic bronze-green plumage and cinnamon underparts earned it a scientific name meaning 'golden red' in Latin.

name: Cinnamon Teal
region: Western US and southwestern Canada
habitat: Marshes and ponds
description: Males sport brilliant cinnamon-red plumage and can molt three times in their first year alone. These dabbling ducks migrate between North America and South America, with some high-altitude Andean populations living at elevations of 3,500–4,600 meters.

name: Clapper Rail
region: Eastern US Atlantic coast, Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean
habitat: Saltwater marshes and wetlands
description: A chicken-sized marsh specialist that rarely takes flight, relying instead on its ability to sprint through dense vegetation on the ground. Despite weighing up to 14 ounces, it uses its long, slightly curved bill to probe for crustaceans and small fish in shallow water, sometimes raising clutches of up to 16 eggs in a single breeding season.

name: Clark's Grebe
region: Western North America, British Columbia to Texas; winters on Pacific coast and Mexico
habitat: Large inland lakes and wetlands with nearby tree cover
description: A diving waterbird that closely mimics its western grebe cousin but distinguishes itself with a bright yellow bill and paler plumage extending above the eyes. Known for elaborate courtship displays where pairs perform synchronized rushing and weed-gathering ceremonies to attract mates.

name: Common Cuckoo
region: Vagrant to North America (rare sightings in US, Canada, Greenland)
habitat: Open grasslands and moorlands
description: A cunning brood parasite that lays eggs mimicking those of 100+ host species, with females capable of visiting up to 50 nests in a single breeding season. Hatched chicks possess remarkable strength to eject host eggs from the nest within hours.

name: Common Eider
region: Northern coasts of North America, Alaska, and Canada
habitat: Coastal waters and Arctic breeding grounds near the sea
description: A massive sea-duck capable of flying at speeds up to 113 km/h (70 mph), famous for its incredibly soft down feathers plucked from the female's breast to line nests—the same down that has been harvested for centuries to fill pillows and quilts.

name: Common Gallinule
region: Continental US (excluding Great Plains), southeast Canada, south to Panama
habitat: Marshes, ponds, canals, and well-vegetated wetlands
description: A bold wetland wader with a striking red facial shield and yellow legs, capable of walking across lily pads thanks to its uniquely wide feet and sometimes carrying its threatened chicks away to safety by flying while they cling to the parent's body.

name: Common Goldeneye
region: Canada, northern United States, winters in temperate coastal and inland waters
habitat: Lakes and rivers in boreal forests, taiga regions
description: A diving duck with brilliant golden-yellow eyes that hunts up to 65 feet underwater, consuming a diet that shifts seasonally from insects to crustaceans depending on availability. Males perform elaborate courtship displays and aggressively defend territory despite weighing just 2.2 pounds.

name: Common Ground Dove
region: Southern United States, Mexico, Central America, Caribbean
habitat: Open areas with trees and bushes, farmlands, savannahs
description: North America's tiniest dove, weighing less than 1.5 ounces yet capable of raising 2-3 broods per year. Its chestnut wing feathers only reveal themselves in flight, making this ground-dwelling sprite nearly invisible until it takes to the air.

name: Common Merganser
region: Northern US, Canada, and Pacific coast
habitat: Rivers, lakes, and coastal waters in forested areas
description: A large diving duck with a serrated bill that acts like a saw to grip slippery fish prey. Known to form crèches where single females have been observed caring for over 70 ducklings at once, reaching speeds of up to 60-70 days to fledging.

name: Common Nighthawk
region: Continental North America, from Alaska and Canada to Central America
habitat: Open areas, forests, cities, prairies, and clearings; often on flat rooftops in urban settings
description: An aerial acrobat that hunts flying insects on the wing with a distinctive booming sound produced by diving at speeds up to 23 km/h, then migrating up to 6,800 kilometers between North American breeding grounds and South American wintering ranges. Despite its name containing 'hawk,' this nightjar is completely harmless and distinguished by its tiny beak that conceals a massive mouth capable of scooping insects from the air.

name: Common Pauraque
region: Southern Texas and northeastern Mexico
habitat: Open woodland, grassland, scrubland, and crop fields
description: A nocturnal nightjar that hunts insects in flight and occasionally runs rather than flies when disturbed. Its wailing call inspired its onomatopoetic name, and males perform elaborate courtship flights while producing whip-like sounds around females.

name: Common Pochard
region: Rare vagrant to North America; primarily Eurasian
habitat: Marshes and lakes with deep water; winter wetlands
description: A swift diving duck capable of reaching speeds of 49–54 mph in direct flight, this bird doubles its feeding efficiency by gleaning food items that drift away from swans trampling the lake bottom.

name: Common Poorwill
region: Western North America from British Columbia to northern Mexico
habitat: Dry open areas with grasses, shrubs, and stony desert slopes
description: The only bird known to enter torpor for extended periods lasting weeks to months, allowing it to survive harsh winters in a hibernation-like state while concealed in rock piles. This 7-inch nocturnal insectivore gets its name from its distinctive three-syllable call: 'poor-will-low.'

name: Common Scoter
region: Eastern North America, coastal waters
habitat: Coastal marine waters, temperate zones
description: A bulky sea duck with an all-black male and a distinctive bulbous bill, known for forming massive tightly-packed flocks that dive and take off in perfect synchronization. In 19th-century France, these birds were so abundant on the coasts and caught in such numbers that the Catholic Church exempted them from Friday fasting rules due to their fishy flavor.

name: Common Shelduck
region: Rare visitor to North America; infrequent in US and Canada
habitat: Coastal salt marshes, estuaries, and tidal mudflats
description: A striking Eurasian waterfowl that rarely ventures to North America, recognizable by its reddish-pink bill, white body, chestnut patches, and dark green head. Moulting flocks can gather in massive numbers exceeding 100,000 individuals on coastal mudflats.

name: Common Swift
region: Not found in North America; European and African species
habitat: Urban and suburban areas with buildings; cliffs and tree cavities
description: A tireless aerial acrobat that spends up to 10 months in continuous flight without landing, covering millions of kilometers over its lifetime while hunting insects on the wing at speeds exceeding 69 mph.

name: Corn Crake
region: Vagrant to Canada, US, and Greenland (rare)
habitat: Grasslands and hayfields
description: A master of camouflage that calls out its location over 20,000 times per night during breeding season, with a loud repetitive "krek krek" audible from nearly a mile away. Despite its elusive nature, this secretive rail has inspired countless local names across European folklore.

name: Costa's Hummingbird
region: Southwestern US and Baja California
habitat: Arid brushy deserts and gardens
description: A tiny desert jewel barely 3 inches long, this hummingbird mesmerizes females with high-speed diving displays that showcase its vibrant purple throat, producing a high-pitched vibration with its tail feathers as it swoops past.

name: Crested Bobwhite
region: Southern tip of Central America (Costa Rica)
habitat: Dry shrubland and tropical grasslands
description: A ground-dwelling quail with a distinctive pale crest and marbled black-and-white neck plumage, measuring just 7 to 8.5 inches long. Its loud three-syllable breeding call of 'quoit bob-white' echoes across tropical grasslands where it forages in small flocks for seeds and insects.

name: Crimson-crowned Fruit-dove
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Tropical moist lowland and mangrove forests
description: A solitary fruit-eating dove with a distinctive crimson crown, typically seen alone or in pairs across Pacific island forests where it feeds on figs and tropical fruits.

name: Dark-billed Cuckoo
region: Southern Florida and Texas (vagrant)
habitat: Tropical and gallery forests, mangroves, forest edges
description: A sleek insect-hunter measuring just 25-28 cm with a distinctive black mask and citron-yellow eye-ring, capable of asynchronous hatching that allows larger chicks to dominate smaller siblings in the nest.

name: Diamond Dove
region: Not found in North America; native to Australia only
habitat: Semi-arid and lightly arid areas near water sources
description: One of Australia's smallest pigeons at just 19-21 centimeters long, weighing only 35 grams, yet remarkably tolerant of extreme heat through specialized adaptations. Its wings produce distinctive whistling "frrr" sounds in flight, and it communicates through mournful, soft coos that carry a pleasant falsetto quality.

name: Dusky Grouse
region: Rocky Mountains, from southeastern Alaska and Yukon south to New Mexico
habitat: Conifer and mixed forest edges in mountainous regions
description: A mountain-dwelling grouse with the peculiar habit of climbing higher into forests during winter rather than descending to lower, warmer elevations. Males attract females with deep hooting calls and dramatic short flapping flights across their alpine territories.

name: Eared Grebe
region: Southwestern US, Western US (California, Great Salt Lake region); winters south to Guatemala
habitat: Freshwater lakes during breeding; saline lakes and coastal estuaries during migration and winter
description: A champion long-distance migrant that travels up to 3,700 miles between breeding grounds and wintering areas, then doubles its body weight during a two-month flightless molt before the journey home. One of the world's most numerous grebes, yet one of the least efficient fliers among all birds.

name: Eastern Spot-billed Duck
region: Russian Far East
habitat: Freshwater lakes and marshes
description: A dabbling duck that has expanded its range northward by over 500 km since the early 20th century, possibly in response to global warming. Distinguished by its yellow-tipped black bill and blue-bordered white wing speculum, this species measures 55–63 cm in length and weighs up to 1,500 grams.

name: Eastern Whip-poor-will
region: Eastern and central North America, from Canada to Mexico
habitat: Deciduous and mixed forests
description: A master of camouflage that hunts insects in complete darkness, this bird's distinctive call has inspired centuries of folklore claiming it can sense departing souls. Populations have declined over 60% since 1970, making its haunting nighttime song increasingly rare.

name: Egyptian Goose
region: South-central US (Arkansas, Oklahoma, Texas, Nebraska); locally in California and Florida
habitat: Open water and grasslands near freshwater; parks and river valleys
description: An aggressive African waterfowl now spreading across North America, measuring 25–29 inches long with hidden white wings that flash dramatically during territorial dogfights with rivals. Fiercely protective parents that pair for life and have been observed attacking drones that enter their habitat.

name: Emperor Goose
region: Alaska, Aleutian Islands, rarely continental US
habitat: Arctic tundra, coastal mudflats, marshes, ice-free coasts
description: This heavily-built Arctic goose migrates only a few hundred miles between seasons—far shorter than other geese—and spends winters dining on bivalves and algae, giving its flesh a distinctly strong flavor. Its head turns rusty-brown in summer from iron oxide in coastal tidal pools where it forages.

name: Erckel's Francolin
region: Hawaii (introduced gamebird population)
habitat: High-altitude mountainous scrublands and forest edges
description: Africa's largest spurfowl, standing 15–17 inches tall and renowned for its bizarre territorial call—a rapid, cackling laughter that sounds like a bouncing ball speeding toward a frenzied climax. When threatened, this striped gamebird doesn't flee; instead, it runs uphill to escape predators.

name: Eurasian Collared-dove
region: Nearly every US state, Mexico
habitat: Urban and suburban areas, farms, human habitation
description: An invasive colonizer that spread from fewer than 50 escaped birds in the Bahamas in 1974 to nearly every US state, expanding at over 100 km per year—more than double its European invasion rate. Known to form winter flocks exceeding 10,000 individuals around grain supplies.

name: Eurasian Moorhen
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Marshes, ponds, canals, and well-vegetated wetlands
description: A distinctive rail with jet-black plumage, bright red frontal shield, and yellow legs, capable of carrying its young to safety by having them cling to the parent's body during flight.

name: Eurasian Wigeon
region: Mid-Atlantic and Pacific coasts, rare inland
habitat: Open wetlands, marshes, wet grasslands
description: A highly vocal dabbling duck that migrates between the Arctic and Africa, the male's brilliant white wing patch and chestnut head are unmistakable in flight. Known to hybridize with its American cousin and form massive flocks during winter, reaching weights up to 1,073 grams.

name: Falcated Duck
region: Rare vagrant to western North America and California
habitat: Lowland wetlands, water meadows, and lakes
description: An elegant Asian dabbler with sickle-shaped tertials that hang gracefully from its back, this bird occasionally wanders to North America—though most sightings are escaped captives rather than true vagrants. Ancient hybridization with gadwalls has left its genetic fingerprints in North American populations, even today.

name: Fork-tailed Swift
region: Pribilof Islands, Aleutian Islands (rare vagrant)
habitat: Open air above varied terrain; migrant
description: An almost entirely airborne bird that may even sleep while flying, this swift hunts insects at heights up to 980 feet while circling in flocks of tens of thousands, powered by a 43-to-54-centimeter wingspan.

name: Fulvous Whistling-duck
region: Gulf Coastal Plain (Texas, Louisiana), Southern California, Florida
habitat: Shallow wetlands, marshes, rice fields, and swamps
description: A long-legged whistling duck that feeds by day and night across four continents, with a population estimated between 1.3 to 2.1 million birds worldwide. Known for its distinctive kee-wee-ooo whistle call and ability to walk upright without waddling, it has rapidly expanded its range northward over the past century.

name: Gadwall
region: Northern breeding range from Great Lakes through Alberta and Saskatchewan south to Kansas; winters across much of continental US and Central America
habitat: Open wetlands, prairie lakes, marshes, wet grassland with dense vegetation
description: A dabbling duck that dives more proficiently than its relatives and boldly steals food from diving birds like coots. One of North America's most hunted waterfowl, with approximately 1.7 million shot annually, yet populations continue to grow at 2.5% over nearly 50 years.

name: Gambel's Quail
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, California, Colorado, New Mexico, Nevada, Utah, Texas)
habitat: Desert regions
description: A desert sprinter with a distinctive topknot, this bird can move surprisingly fast through brush on foot and prefers to walk rather than fly. Males sport striking copper crowns and black faces with white eyebrow stripes, making them easy to spot in arid landscapes.

name: Garganey
region: Rare vagrant to North America; primarily Eurasian species
habitat: Shallow marshes and steppe lakes with adjacent grassland
description: A nimble dabbling duck that rises from water with twisting, wader-like flight and migrates across entire continents—traveling from European breeding grounds to Africa, India, and Australasia each winter. Males sport a striking brown head with white eye-crescents and produce a distinctive crackling mating call.

name: Gray Francolin
region: Hawaii, Nevada
habitat: Open scrubland and cultivated grasslands
description: A graceful ground-dwelling bird introduced to the Hawaiian Islands, renowned for its loud, distinctive call that echoes across open country at dawn—so musically valued that Indian lovers compare their sweethearts' running gait to its swift, gliding stride.

name: Gray Nightjar
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Not applicable to US wildlife
description: This species is not found in the United States or North America and cannot be included in a North American wildlife Pokédex.

name: Gray Partridge
region: Northern US and Canada (introduced species)
habitat: Farmland and cereal fields
description: A rotund gamebird capable of laying up to 20 eggs in a single clutch, with chicks that can only digest insects for their first 10 days of life. Known for its harsh kieerr-ik call and explosive flight pattern when flushed from cover.

name: Graylag Goose
region: North America (feral populations only, occasional vagrants)
habitat: Marshes, estuaries, flooded fields, and agricultural areas near water
description: An ancestor of most domestic goose breeds, this large waterfowl can weigh up to 10 pounds and gathers in flocks of thousands, using coordinated group defense to protect their young by mobbing predators together.

name: Greater Ani
region: Not found in the US; tropical South America only
habitat: Mangrove swamps and semi-open woodland near water
description: A gregarious black cuckoo that nests communally with up to five pairs sharing a single nest and incubating eggs together, with some females even parasitically laying eggs in rival nests—around 15% do so when their own clutches are lost to predation.

name: Greater Prairie-chicken
region: Central and northern Great Plains; historically across eastern North America
habitat: Tallgrass prairie and oak savanna
description: Males perform an elaborate two-month mating ritual on booming grounds, inflating orange neck sacs and snapping their tails to compete for dominance—with the top two males claiming 90% of all mating opportunities. Once numbering in the millions across Illinois alone, populations have collapsed to approximately 500,000 individuals today due to the conversion of 95% of tallgrass prairie to cropland.

name: Greater Roadrunner
region: Southwestern US and northern Mexico
habitat: Arid and semiarid scrubland with scattered vegetation
description: This ground-dwelling cuckoo can sprint at speeds up to 26 mph, making it the fastest running bird in existence—yet it still prefers to flee on foot rather than take wing. Armed with a keen eye and lightning reflexes, it hunts venomous rattlesnakes, tarantulas, and scorpions without hesitation.

name: Greater Sage-grouse
region: Western US (sagebrush country), Southern Alberta and Saskatchewan
habitat: Sagebrush grasslands and shrublands
description: North America's largest grouse, males perform elaborate courtship rituals on breeding leks where dominant birds monopolize up to 80% of mating opportunities. Despite weighing up to 7 pounds, these birds lack a muscular gizzard and cannot digest hard seeds—requiring exclusively soft plant matter and insects.

name: Greater Scaup
region: Alaska, northern Canada, Great Lakes, Atlantic and Pacific coasts
habitat: Coastal bays, estuaries, large lakes, tundra
description: A diving duck capable of plunging up to 20 feet underwater and holding its breath for nearly a minute, allowing it to feast on mollusks and aquatic plants unreachable by other ducks. Forms massive 'rafts' numbering in the thousands during winter migration.

name: Greater White-fronted Goose
region: Alaska, Canada, and northern continental US; winters in Gulf of Mexico and California
habitat: Arctic tundra, prairies, and wetlands; staging areas in marshes and agricultural fields
description: A migratory goose that can travel thousands of miles between Arctic breeding grounds and southern wintering areas, identifiable by its distinctive white forehead patch and salt-and-pepper belly markings. Uniquely, these geese may provide parental care for several years, possibly including grandparenting—an unusual trait among waterfowl.

name: Green Mango
region: Puerto Rico
habitat: Mountain forests and plantations, 800-1,200 m elevation
description: A jewel-toned hummingbird weighing merely 7 grams that defends flowering trees with fierce territorial displays. Males feature iridescent metallic blue-green underparts and can hover while feeding on nectar and insects caught mid-flight.

name: Green-breasted Mango
region: Southern Texas (vagrant)
habitat: Semi-open lowland tropics, shrublands, gardens, and urban areas
description: A jewel-like hummingbird weighing less than a quarter ounce, with males sporting an iridescent bronze-green crown and velvety black throat stripe. This diminutive nectar-hunter can hover at all forest levels and occasionally ventures north to Texas, sometimes traveling thousands of miles from its Central American home.

name: Green-throated Carib
region: Puerto Rico and Lesser Antilles
habitat: Wet forests, gardens, and cultivated areas near sea level
description: A iridescent hummingbird with a brilliant green back and gorget, capable of beating its wings up to 80 times per second while defending its flowering feeding territories year-round.

name: Green-winged Teal
region: Northern North America (breeding), continent-wide (winter)
habitat: Shallow wetlands, marshes, mudflats, taiga bogs
description: The smallest North American dabbling duck, capable of the fastest growth rate of all duck species—young fledge in just 34-35 days. Forms massive flocking formations in flight that twist and turn with wader-like precision, making it one of North America's most abundant waterfowl.

name: Groove-billed Ani
region: Southern Texas and northern Mexico (winter); resident throughout Central America and northern South America
habitat: Open and partly open country, pastures, savannas, and orchards
description: A sleek black tropical bird with a massive curved beak carved with distinctive lengthwise grooves, this ani lives in cooperative groups where up to five breeding pairs share a single territory and raise their young communally in one nest.

name: Gunnison Sage-grouse
region: Southwestern Colorado and southeastern Utah
habitat: Sagebrush-dominated areas
description: A third smaller than its greater sage-grouse cousins, this bird was hiding in plain sight until 2000—the first new avian species discovered in the USA since the 1800s. Males gather on leks each spring to perform elaborate strutting displays, but only a handful actually breed, and fewer than 1,800 remain in the wild.

name: Harlequin Duck
region: Northwestern and northeastern North America, Greenland, Iceland
habitat: Cold fast-moving streams and rocky shorelines
description: A brilliantly patterned sea duck named for the colorful Harlequin character, with densely packed feathers that make it bounce like a cork after diving. Males display elaborate slate-blue plumage with white markings and chestnut patches, while their exceptional buoyancy allows them to thrive in the coldest, choppiest waters of North America.

name: Hawaiian Duck
region: Hawaiian Islands
habitat: Wetlands, streams, and mountain valleys near coastal ponds
description: This secretive island duck is 20-30% smaller than its mainland mallard cousins and produces a softer quack, but poses a unique conservation puzzle: it readily interbreeds with feral mallards to create fully fertile hybrids, threatening its genetic survival with only about 2,000 pure individuals remaining on Kauai.

name: Hawaiian Goose
region: Hawaiian Islands
habitat: Shrubland, grassland, coastal dunes, lava plains, and golf courses from sea level to 7,900 feet
description: Hawaii's state bird nearly vanished entirely, plummeting from 25,000 birds to just 30 by 1952 before a remarkable captive breeding program brought it back from the brink of extinction. This lightweight goose—weighing only 3 to 7 pounds—uniquely mates on land and boasts the longest breeding season of any goose species.

name: Himalayan Snowcock
region: Ruby Mountains, Nevada
habitat: Alpine pastures and steep rocky cliffs above treeline
description: An introduced Asian mountain dweller weighing up to 6.8 pounds, it launches itself from clifftops and dives down steep slopes to escape predators. A wild population of 200-500 has thrived in Nevada's high peaks since the 1960s, making it one of America's most successful exotic game bird introductions.

name: Hooded Merganser
region: Eastern US, Pacific Northwest, and southern Canada
habitat: Small ponds, lakes, rivers, and freshwater wetlands with emergent vegetation
description: A sleek diving duck with an iconic raised crest and a specialized serrated bill for hunting fish underwater. Males display striking black and white plumage during breeding season, while both sexes are adept sight-hunters capable of diving to pursue aquatic prey at depths.

name: Horned Grebe
region: Northwestern North America, from Alaska to Minnesota; winters along coasts from Alaska to Florida
habitat: Shallow freshwater ponds and marshes with emergent vegetation; coastal marine environments during winter
description: A master diver equipped with large rear-facing feet for underwater agility, this bird swallows fish whole and has evolved a unique stomach adaptation—a matted plug of feathers that functions as a filter to trap fish bones during digestion. The breeding male's striking red-and-black plumage features prominent erectable "horns" that can be raised and lowered at will.

name: Inca Dove
region: American Southwest to Central America
habitat: Deserts, scrublands, cultivated areas, and urban settings
description: A slender desert dove weighing less than 2 ounces that produces a distinctive rattling noise upon takeoff. During harsh winters, these birds stack into pyramids of 10 or more to share body heat and survive the cold.

name: Indian Peafowl
region: Introduced populations in scattered US locations (California, Florida, Texas); not established in wild
habitat: Open forests, cultivated lands, areas near human habitation
description: India's national bird, males grow ornamental trains of over 200 feathers stretching up to 6 feet long, despite weighing only 4–6 kg—yet remain capable of flight. The iridescent blue plumage and elaborate eyespots result not from pigment but from the feathers' microscopic structure.

name: Japanese Quail
region: Domesticated populations across the United States; not naturally occurring in North America
habitat: Agricultural fields, grasslands, and areas with dense vegetation
description: A prolific egg-layer capable of producing up to 300 eggs annually with remarkable feed efficiency. These tiny birds have been selectively bred since the 12th century and now orbit Earth in space stations, where their eggs have successfully hatched in zero gravity.

name: Kalij Pheasant
region: Hawaii only (introduced species)
habitat: Forests and thickets
description: Males display striking glossy blue-black plumage with dramatic regional variations, ranging from white-crested western subspecies to white-tailed eastern varieties, making them one of Asia's most visually diverse pheasants. Originally native to Himalayan foothills, this species was introduced to Hawaii in 1962 and now thrives as an established gamebird population.

name: Key West Quail-dove
region: Florida Keys and southern Florida (vagrant only)
habitat: Tropical and subtropical dry forests, shrublands, and lowland moist forests
description: A small ground-foraging dove distinguished by its striking rust-colored plumage and bold white facial stripe, with iridescent bronze-green and purplish-red markings on its crown and back. Once bred throughout the Florida Keys but now only appears as an occasional vagrant.

name: King Eider
region: Alaska, Canada, Greenland, northeastern United States
habitat: Arctic coastal waters and tundra lakes
description: A striking Arctic sea duck with a distinctive orange crown-like knob above the male's bill, capable of diving to great depths to hunt benthic invertebrates including sea urchins and starfish. Males sport remarkable multicolored plumage reminiscent of royal robes, while wintering flocks can exceed 100,000 birds.

name: King Rail
region: Eastern North America, southeastern US coasts year-round
habitat: Freshwater and brackish marshes
description: North America's largest rail species, this diurnal marsh dweller can become completely flightless for nearly a month during its post-nesting molt. A master hunter of shallow waters, it probes mud for aquatic insects with its elegant downward-curved bill while sporting a distinctive rusty-brown face and white throat.

name: Labrador Duck
region: Eastern North America (New England, New Jersey coasts; breeding in Labrador and northern Quebec)
habitat: Coastal waters, sandy bays, harbors, and inlets
description: A mysterious sea duck with a uniquely flattened bill adapted for probing shellfish from shallow waters, now extinct since 1878—the first known endemic North American bird species to vanish after European contact. Only 55 museum specimens remain worldwide.

name: Laysan Duck
region: Hawaiian Islands (Northwestern)
habitat: Shallow lakes, mudflats, and coastal vegetation on remote atolls
description: This flightless dabbler nearly vanished entirely—reduced to just 12 individuals in 1912—but has made a remarkable comeback through dedicated conservation efforts. Once widespread across Hawaii, it now survives only on three remote atolls where it hunts brine flies with a distinctive high-speed snapping sprint.

name: Least Grebe
region: Southwestern United States and Mexico
habitat: Freshwater ponds, lakes, marshes, and mangrove swamps with dense vegetation
description: The smallest grebe in the world at just 8 inches long and weighing less than 7 ounces, this aquatic acrobat can dive for up to 12.5 seconds while hunting prey underwater. Its breeding call sounds eerily like a whinnying horse despite its diminutive size.

name: Lesser Nighthawk
region: Southern North America, Central America, northern South America
habitat: Arid deserts and grasslands
description: This aerial insectivore captures prey mid-flight using a deceptively large mouth equipped with fine hairs, consuming swarms of flies and mosquitoes in the darkness. It cools itself in scorching desert heat through rapid throat vibrations called gular fluttering, a crucial survival trait while brooding eggs exposed to the intense sun.

name: Lesser Prairie-chicken
region: Western Great Plains (Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas Panhandle, New Mexico, Colorado)
habitat: Sandhills and prairie grasslands with sagebrush
description: A striped grouse performer that has lost 85% of its habitat and declined by up to 99% in some regions, now surviving in fewer than 0.1% of contiguous patches large enough to sustain a population. Males gather at traditional leks to perform elaborate courtship displays.

name: Lesser Scaup
region: Alaska, western Canada, and northern US; winters throughout Central America
habitat: Inland lakes, marsh ponds, and coastal lagoons
description: A prolific diving duck with a population once numbering 6.9 million that has mysteriously declined by over half since the 1970s, despite remaining North America's most abundant diving duck species. Males sport an iridescent black head with a distinctive small hindcrown tuft and can be identified by their purple-sheened plumage and notably smaller, straighter bill compared to their greater scaup cousins.

name: Lesser White-fronted Goose
region: Rare vagrant to North America; primarily Eurasian
habitat: Arctic tundra breeding grounds; wetlands and grasslands during migration
description: A scarce Arctic breeder no bigger than a mallard, this goose sports a distinctive yellow eye-ring and bright orange legs that set it apart from its larger cousins. The critically endangered Fennoscandian population numbers fewer than 100 individuals, making it one of Europe's most threatened waterfowl.

name: Little Grebe
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Freshwater lakes and open bodies of water with vegetation
description: Europe's tiniest grebe at just 9-11 inches long, this aquatic acrobat pursues fish and invertebrates underwater with remarkable diving ability, covering its eggs with weeds to outsmart predators.

name: Long-tailed Duck
region: Alaska, northern Canada, Great Lakes, coastal Atlantic and Pacific regions
habitat: Tundra pools, coastal waters, and large inland lakes during breeding; open ocean and Great Lakes in winter
description: This arctic sea duck is a master deep diver, capable of plunging to depths of 200 feet using its wings like velvet scoters to reach mollusks far below the surface. Males produce a distinctive musical yodeling call that echoes across frozen northern waters.

name: Long-tailed Koel
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Not applicable
description: This species is endemic to New Zealand and the Pacific Islands, and does not occur in North America.

name: Lucifer Hummingbird
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico, Texas) and northern Mexico
habitat: High-altitude desert canyons and slopes with agave plants and cacti
description: A shimmering desert jewel with a distinctive forked tail and iridescent magenta gorget, males perform elaborate 30-45 second courtship dives that produce sharp snapping sounds from their wings and tail feathers.

name: Mallard
region: Continental US, Alaska, Mexico, Caribbean (winters)
habitat: Wetlands, ponds, rivers, lakes, marshes
description: This dabbling duck can hybridize with over 40 different species in the wild, producing fertile offspring that threaten indigenous waterfowl populations. Capable of flying 50-60 days after hatching, the mallard's ducklings are born ready to swim and can survive in nearly any freshwater habitat across the globe.

name: Mangrove Cuckoo
region: Southern Florida and Caribbean
habitat: Mangrove swamps and hammocks
description: Despite its scientific name meaning "small," this is the largest of North America's three Coccyzus cuckoos, measuring up to 13 inches long with a distinctive black facial mask and buffy underparts. Known for its guttural "gawk gawk gawk" call, it hunts caterpillars and grasshoppers among the mangrove trees where it nests just meters above the water.

name: Many-colored Fruit-dove
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Not applicable
description: This entry is not applicable for a North American wildlife Pokédex, as the Many-colored Fruit-dove is endemic to South Pacific islands including Fiji, Samoa, and Tonga.

name: Mariana Fruit-dove
region: Guam and Northern Mariana Islands (Pacific US territories)
habitat: Tropical forests and fruit-bearing trees
description: This 24 cm emerald-feathered dove is the official bird of the Northern Mariana Islands and once thrived across the Pacific until invasive brown tree snakes decimated its population—now extinct on Guam since 1984 and surviving only through desperate captive breeding efforts.

name: Mariana Swiftlet
region: Hawaiian Islands (Oahu); formerly Guam and Northern Mariana Islands
habitat: Tropical moist lowland forests, mangrove forests, and limestone caves
description: This tiny 4.3-inch swift navigates pitch-black limestone caves using echolocation clicks, hunting aerial insects at dawn and dusk in colonies of up to several hundred birds. Once thriving across the Pacific, populations have plummeted to fewer than 7,000 individuals across all remaining territories.

name: Masked Duck
region: Southern Texas, Mexico, Florida, Caribbean
habitat: Freshwater marshes with vegetation and tree cover, mangrove swamps
description: A secretive diving duck that has remained virtually unchanged for millions of years, serving as a living evolutionary link between primitive and modern stiff-tailed ducks. These tiny waterfowl feed by diving deep to harvest seeds, roots, and aquatic insects from freshwater marshes.

name: Mexican Duck
region: Mexico, southwestern United States, with limited populations in Colorado, Utah, Wyoming, Nebraska, and Montana
habitat: Wetlands including ponds and rivers
description: A dabbling duck nearly indistinguishable from female mallards, but threatened by hybridization with the more adaptable mallard species—a fate that could erase this bird as a distinct species within decades without conservation intervention.

name: Mexican Violetear
region: Southern and central Texas, rare vagrant to extreme southern Canada
habitat: Subtropical and lower temperate mountain forests, cloud forests, and gardens at 1,200-2,300 meters elevation
description: A shimmering metallic green hummingbird with a brilliant violet ear-patch, weighing less than a penny while maintaining a fierce territorial defense of feeding grounds. Males sing the same monotonous call up to 60 times per minute from exposed perches, making them as persistent as they are diminutive.

name: Mexican Whip-poor-will
region: Southwestern US (California to Texas), Mexico, Central America
habitat: Oak and pine forests, semi-arid to moist woodlands at mid to upper elevations
description: A nocturnal insect-hunter heard far more often than seen, this small nightjar weighs just 45-50 grams but fearlessly hunts moths and beetles by sallying through the night air. Its distinctive call—a lazy, lower-pitched version of its eastern cousin's famous 'whip-poor-will'—echoes through southwestern forests and woodlands.

name: Micronesian Scrubfowl
region: Not found in North America (Western Pacific islands only)
habitat: Thick forest, scrublands, and volcanic offshore islets
description: One of the only birds known to incubate eggs using volcanic heat instead of body warmth, with only 2,000-2,500 individuals remaining in the wild. This accomplished runner can escape predators despite being flightless, using its unusually large yellow legs to creep through forest shadows.

name: Montezuma Quail
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico, West Texas) and Mexico
habitat: Oak and pine-oak woodlands on hillsides and canyons with tall grass
description: A stubby, secretive quail that freezes motionless in grass rather than fleeing, sometimes allowing humans to approach within just one meter before exploding into flight with a loud pop. Equipped with unusual sickle-shaped claws, it digs holes up to 8 cm deep to unearth hidden bulbs and tubers that leave telltale signs of its presence.

name: Mottled Duck
region: Gulf Coast and Florida
habitat: Coastal marshes, brackish waters, and wetlands
description: A non-migratory dabbling duck so prized by hunters that approximately 1 in every 20 individuals is banded—making it one of the most frequently banded waterfowl along the Gulf of Mexico coast. Despite its rarity as a distinct species, it remains genetically vulnerable to hybridization with invasive mallards.

name: Mountain Quail
region: Pacific Coast and Sierra Nevada mountains, from British Columbia to Baja California
habitat: Mountainous chaparral and woodlands, up to 9,800 feet elevation
description: This small ground-dweller sports a distinctive topknot that changes color with the seasons and can walk surprisingly quickly through dense brush despite having short, rounded wings. Mountain quail rarely fly, preferring explosive bursts of speed with rapid wingbeats followed by a glide to escape danger.

name: Mourning Dove
region: Continental US, southern Canada, Mexico, Greater Antilles
habitat: Open and semi-open areas including urban zones, farms, prairie, and grassland
description: A prolific breeder capable of raising up to six broods in a single year, with wings that whistle audibly during takeoff and landing. One of North America's most abundant birds, with 20–70 million shot annually by hunters while the population sustains itself.

name: Muscovy Duck
region: Southern US, Florida, Louisiana, Hawaii, scattered populations in North America
habitat: Forested swamps, lakes, streams, grasslands, and agricultural areas
description: A muscular waterfowl with a bare, warty face that can weigh up to 15 pounds—about twice as heavy as a mallard—and possesses a helical penis capable of extending 7 inches in just 0.3 seconds. These aggressive ducks thrash violently during mating and often roost in trees at night, making them surprisingly acrobatic despite their substantial bulk.

name: Mute Swan
region: Eastern United States, Great Lakes, Atlantic coast
habitat: Lakes, ponds, rivers, and coastal waters
description: This massive waterfowl can weigh up to 23 kg (51 lb)—making it one of the heaviest flying birds ever recorded—and produces a distinctive vibrant wing-throbbing sound audible from 1-2 km away. Fiercely territorial and highly aggressive in defense of its cygnets, it can overpower and drown even large dog breeds with powerful strikes from its bony wing spurs.

name: Northern Bobwhite
region: Southeastern US, Great Lakes to New England, extending west to Great Plains
habitat: Agricultural fields, grasslands, open woodlands, roadsides, and wood edges
description: A master of camouflage that has declined by roughly 85% since 1966, this ground-dwelling quail announces itself with a clear, unmistakable whistle that rises a full octave in pitch—giving it its distinctive "bob-WHITE" name.

name: Northern Pintail
region: Canada, Alaska, and northern US; winters across southern US and Central America
habitat: Open wetlands, marshes, shallow lakes, and coastal lagoons
description: A sleek dabbling duck distinguished by its impossibly long neck and pointed tail feathers, capable of reaching food 12 inches deep on the lake bottom where other ducks cannot. Males clock in at speeds exceeding most waterfowl, with a distinctive chocolate-brown head and white breast that makes them unmistakable in flight.

name: Northern Potoo
region: Mexico and Central America
habitat: Lowland woodlands, scrubland, and farmland with scattered trees
description: A master of stillness, this nocturnal hunter perches motionless for hours before sallying out to snatch large insects mid-flight. With a distinctive hoarse call and striking yellow eyes that glow red in the dark, it measures 38-46 centimeters long and lays a single egg directly on a bare branch.

name: Northern Shoveler
region: Northern US and Canada, wintering south to Mexico and Caribbean
habitat: Open wetlands, marshes, and mud-bottomed lakes with emergent vegetation
description: This nimble dabbler uses a specialized spatula-shaped bill equipped with comb-like filters to skim crustaceans and plankton from water surfaces, giving it a competitive advantage over other puddle ducks. Populations have soared to over 5 million birds, trailing only mallards and blue-winged teal in North American duck abundance.

name: Oriental Cuckoo
region: Alaska (vagrant)
habitat: Coniferous and mixed forests
description: A secretive brood parasite that travels thousands of miles from Russia to Australia, laying eggs in the nests of warblers and other small birds while the host species unknowingly raises its young. Males announce their presence with a distinctive paired 'poo-poo' call that mimics the hoopoe.

name: Oriental Turtle-dove
region: Rare vagrant to western Alaska and British Columbia
habitat: Open woodlands and well-wooded areas with good tree cover
description: An Asian dove that rarely ventures to North America, distinguished by its distinctive four-syllable 'her-her-oo-oo' call and black-and-white striped neck patch made of silver-tipped feathers. Multiple broods may be raised in a single season, with both parents sharing incubation duties and feeding altricial chicks with nutritious crop milk.

name: Pacific Black Duck
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Wetlands, lakes, and coastal areas
description: A dabbling duck that feeds by upending in the water to reach aquatic plant seeds, but faces extinction in New Zealand due to hybridization with introduced mallards, which possess dominant plumage genes that mask the grey duck's appearance in offspring.

name: Pacific Imperial-pigeon
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Tropical moist lowland and montane forests on Pacific islands
description: A widespread Pacific fruit-eating pigeon that travels between islands in large flocks to feast on fruiting trees, weighing only 370-420 grams despite its 36-41 cm length. Known to the people of Niue as 'Lupe,' this species was hunted in prehistoric times using elaborate stone platform traps of considerable cultural significance.

name: Paint-billed Crake
region: Rare vagrant to Texas and Virginia
habitat: Marshes, reedbeds, wet pastures, and swampy grasslands
description: A secretive rail with a striking red and yellow bill that can sing up to 36 rapid-fire staccato notes in a single accelerating series. So elusive that its exact range and abundance remain poorly understood despite inhabiting a vast territory across South America.

name: Passenger Pigeon
region: Eastern North America, Great Lakes region
habitat: Deciduous forests, large swamps with alder trees
description: Once numbering around 3 billion, this swift flyer could reach speeds of 100 km/h and darken the sky in massive migratory flocks—until intensive 19th-century hunting drove it to complete extinction by 1914, making it a sobering example of human-caused species loss.

name: Philippine Collared-dove
region: Not found in North America (native to Philippines; introduced to Guam and Northern Mariana Islands)
habitat: Open grassland and agricultural land with scattered trees and scrub
description: A brownish dove with a distinctive short collar of dark scales and a loud, melancholy three-note call that echoes across open fields. Once considered a subspecies, it now competes fiercely with introduced Spotted doves and Red collared doves for survival in its native Philippine range.

name: Pied-billed Grebe
region: Continental US, Canada, Central America, Caribbean
habitat: Freshwater wetlands with emergent vegetation, marshes, ponds
description: A master diver that can submerge for 30 seconds and plunge to depths of 20 feet, this stocky water bird controls its buoyancy by trapping air in its feathers like a living submarine. Known for its reclusive nature and nicknamed the 'hell-diver' for its frequent disappearing acts underwater.

name: Pink-footed Goose
region: Eastern Canada and Northeastern US (rare vagrant)
habitat: Agricultural farmland, wetlands, and coastal areas during winter migration
description: An Arctic goose that rarely ventures to North America, with a distinctive bright pink bill and feet. Flocks produce deafening high-pitched honks that can be heard from remarkable distances during migration.

name: Plain Chachalaca
region: Southern Texas, Gulf Coast Mexico, Central America to Costa Rica
habitat: Dry and moist forests with scrub, savanna, and brushy tangles
description: A loud, gregarious game bird that communicates through raucous choruses that sound like men arguing, capable of swift ground escapes and dramatic leaping glides through dense brush. Weighing up to 28 ounces, this 19–23 inch chachalaca displays a striking deep red throat patch during breeding season and can adapt to cleared rainforest scrubland where other forest birds cannot survive.

name: Plain Pigeon
region: Greater Antilles (Caribbean)
habitat: Forests, woodlands, coastal deserts, mangroves, and swampy areas
description: A large Caribbean pigeon standing 38 cm tall with striking red-wine coloring on its head and breast that contrasts sharply against pale blue-gray plumage. The Puerto Rican subspecies was nearly extinct in the 1970s but was saved through dedicated conservation efforts and now numbers several thousand individuals.

name: Plain-capped Starthroat
region: Southwestern US (Arizona)
habitat: Arid scrublands, thorn forests, and open woodlands
description: A tiny Mexican hummingbird barely larger than your thumb that has colonized Arizona only since 1969, now appearing almost annually. Males sport a brilliant red gorget and defend flower patches with remarkable aggression for a bird weighing just 0.26 ounces.

name: Puerto Rican Emerald
region: Puerto Rico
habitat: Forests, mangroves, plantations, gardens, and urban areas from coastal to montane regions
description: This iridescent jewel weighs barely more than a penny yet possesses remarkable agility, feeding on nectar from a wide variety of flowering plants while also hunting tiny arthropods by gleaning them from leaves and branches. Males dazzle with shimmering bluish-green gorgets and forked steely-blue tails, while their high-pitched trilling song sounds like rapid descending notes followed by lisping calls.

name: Puerto Rican Lizard-cuckoo
region: Puerto Rico and US Virgin Islands
habitat: Montane forests, coastal dry forests, swamp forests, and coffee plantations
description: A patient ambush predator that sits motionless for hours before striking, specializing in hunting lizards with its distinctively decurved bill. Named after its haunting ka-ka-ka call, locals believe its cry predicts rain and sounds eerily like a monkey's screech.

name: Puerto Rican Mango
region: Puerto Rico, US Virgin Islands, British Virgin Islands
habitat: Coastal lowlands, gardens, and forest edges
description: A iridescent bronze-green hummingbird weighing less than a quarter ounce that fiercely defends nectar-rich territories and can forage as high as 66 feet above ground. Males display dark bellies while females sport distinctive white-tipped tail feathers, making this resident Caribbean jewel unmistakable in flight.

name: Puerto Rican Nightjar
region: Puerto Rico
habitat: Coastal dry scrub forests and closed canopy dry limestone forests
description: A ghost-like nocturnal hunter weighing barely 40 grams, this tiny nightjar nearly vanished from existence before being rediscovered in 1961 after presumed extinction. Armed with stiff bristles around its beak, it plucks flying insects from the darkness with surgical precision while camouflaged in cryptic brown and gray plumage.

name: Purple-throated Carib
region: Not found in US/North America (Lesser Antilles only)
habitat: Mountain forests, 2,600-3,900 ft elevation
description: A jewel-toned hummingbird weighing less than half an ounce, this Caribbean resident defends flower-centered territories year-round with strident calls and remarkable aerial agility, constructing delicate cup nests from spider silk and plant fibers suspended 10-16 feet above the ground.

name: Red Junglefowl
region: Not found in wild North America; introduced populations in some southern US states
habitat: Disturbed forest edges, regenerating forests, plantations, areas near human settlements
description: The wild ancestor of all domestic chickens, this iridescent Southeast Asian bird weighs just 1-1.5 kg but males can grow tail feathers up to 28 centimeters long that shimmer with blue, purple, and green in sunlight. Despite being domesticated 8,000 years ago, wild populations still thrive across Asia with distinctive alarm calls for different predator types.

name: Red-billed Pigeon
region: Southern Texas to Central America
habitat: Dry coastal forests and riverside wetlands
description: A robust slate-gray pigeon with a distinctive maroon head and a piercing call that rises in pitch, capable of producing a loud clapping noise with its wings upon takeoff.

name: Red-breasted Merganser
region: Northern North America, coastal areas during migration
habitat: Northern lakes and rivers; coastal waters in winter
description: The fastest duck ever recorded, clocking an airspeed of 100 mph while being chased by an airplane—nearly 40% faster than the previous record holder. Armed with a saw-like serrated bill, this diving specialist hunts slippery fish underwater and is the only merganser to regularly brave saltwater seas.

name: Red-necked Grebe
region: Alaska, western and central Canada, northern US east to Minnesota; winters in Pacific and Atlantic coasts
habitat: Shallow freshwater lakes, marshes, and coastal waters; prefers areas with emergent vegetation
description: A vocal diving specialist that can plunge underwater in mere seconds to escape predators, featuring a brilliant rusty-red neck during breeding season that transforms to drab grey in winter. Its legs are positioned so far back on its body that it cannot walk on land and must launch itself across water to take flight.

name: Redhead
region: North America: breeding across Canada and northern US; wintering in southern US, Mexico, and Caribbean
habitat: Semi-permanent wetlands, lakes, and coastal waters
description: A diving duck with a striking copper head and bright blue bill, capable of switching its entire diet between breeding and wintering seasons—eating mostly insects and mollusks in summer, then switching to aquatic plants in winter. Despite their beauty, redheads are notorious nest parasites, laying eggs in other ducks' nests and reducing hatching success of host species.

name: Ridgway's Rail
region: Pacific coast from San Francisco Bay to southern Baja California
habitat: Brackish tidal marshes with pickleweed and cordgrass
description: A chicken-sized marsh dweller with a distinctively curved bill, this nocturnal forager probes tidal mudflats for mussels and clams while remaining hidden in dense wetland vegetation, with populations in San Francisco Bay numbering around 1,100 individuals.

name: Ring-necked Duck
region: Northern US and Canada (breeding); Southern North America (winter)
habitat: Freshwater ponds and lakes, boreal forests
description: A diving duck deceptively named for a neck-ring so subtle it's rarely visible, earning it the alias "ringbill." Despite weighing less than 2 pounds, these small waterfowl migrate thousands of miles between northern breeding grounds and southern winter territories.

name: Ring-necked Pheasant
region: Continental US (introduced), most common in Midwest and Great Plains
habitat: Farmland, grassland, scrub, and wetlands near water with scattered trees
description: A flashy game bird originally from Asia, males sport iridescent green heads and long streaked tails accounting for nearly 50% of their body length. When startled, they can burst upward at speeds exceeding 90 km/h while emitting distinctive whirring sounds.

name: Rivoli's Hummingbird
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico, Texas), south to Central America
habitat: Pine-oak and cloud forests in mountains, 1,500m+ elevation
description: One of North America's two largest hummingbirds, with iridescent violet crown and brilliant blue-green throat that flash only when caught by sunlight. It feeds on insects far more than other North American hummingbirds, hunting them mid-air with surgical precision.

name: Rock Pigeon
region: Continental US, southern Canada
habitat: Urban and suburban areas, coastal cliffs, agricultural settlements
description: Descended from wild rock doves domesticated up to 5,000 years ago, these common urban birds form the majority prey for peregrine falcons in cities, making up to 80% of their diet. Capable of drinking continuously without tilting their heads back, unlike most other birds.

name: Rock Ptarmigan
region: Arctic and Subarctic North America, Alaska, northern Canada, Greenland
habitat: Rocky mountainsides, tundra, alpine terrain
description: A master of camouflage that molts from pure white in winter to brown in spring, this Arctic grouse survives harsh conditions with minimal fat reserves by foraging constantly rather than hibernating. Males perform acrobatic aerial displays with rasping vocalizations that sound like a stick being dragged across a picket fence.

name: Ross's Goose
region: Arctic Canada and northern North America; winters in western US
habitat: Arctic tundra, shallow lakes, and wetlands; grasslands during migration
description: Once hunted to near extinction with populations of only 2,000-3,000 in the 1950s, this goose has made a remarkable recovery and is now 40% smaller than its snow goose cousin, making it the smallest white goose in North America.

name: Ruby-throated Hummingbird
region: Eastern North America, Canada
habitat: Deciduous and pine forests, forest edges, orchards, gardens
description: A master of aerobatic flight, this tiny bird achieves heart rates up to 1,260 beats per minute and can fly backward, hover in place, and execute wing beats at 80 times per second. Incredibly, it doubles its body fat before embarking on a nonstop 900-mile journey across the Gulf of Mexico during migration.

name: Ruddy Duck
region: North America, coastal and inland waterways
habitat: Marshy lakes, ponds, and coastal bays
description: A compact diving duck with a distinctive stiff, upright tail and bright blue bill in breeding season, capable of raising broods of 5 to 15 ducklings in dense marsh vegetation. Known for aggressive courting displays and an unfortunate tendency to interbreed with endangered European species.

name: Ruddy Ground Dove
region: Southwestern US (southern Texas to southern California), primarily winter visitor
habitat: Open scrub, cultivated land, urban centers
description: A diminutive dove weighing barely 1.7 ounces, this species demonstrates remarkable adaptability by thriving in cities and farmland across the Americas. Males engage in aggressive territorial disputes by striking rivals with their wings while displaying striking cinnamon and black underwings.

name: Ruddy Quail-dove
region: Southern Florida and southern Texas (vagrant)
habitat: Woodland and scrub forest, coffee plantations
description: A rust-colored ground forager measuring just 19–28 cm, this quail-dove's russet plumage and distinctive facial mask make it a striking inhabitant of Central and South American forests. Despite being a skilled seed-eater, it remains sensitive to habitat fragmentation and only occasionally strays north to the southern United States.

name: Ruffed Grouse
region: Appalachian Mountains across Canada to Alaska
habitat: Mixed woodlands rich in aspen and second-growth forests
description: This woodland drummer creates a thunderous wing-beating display that can be heard over a quarter mile away, starting slow and accelerating into a rapid blur of sound. Despite their camouflage and ground-dwelling habits, they'll explode into flight with deafening wing beats when startled, earning the nickname 'thunder-chicken.'

name: Rufous Hummingbird
region: Western North America, from Alaska through British Columbia to California
habitat: Open areas, mountainsides, and forest edges; migrates through Rocky Mountains and nearby lowlands
description: This 3-inch dynamo undertakes a 2,000-mile migratory journey despite weighing only 3-4 grams, and supports itself during hovering with 75% downstroke power while beating its wings at frequencies no other bird can match.

name: Rufous-necked Wood-rail
region: Mexico, southwestern United States (rare vagrant)
habitat: Mangrove forests, coastal wetlands, inland deciduous and humid forests
description: A secretive rail with a distinctive rufous-brown head and neck that hunts primarily for crabs along mudflats and stream banks during twilight hours. Known for its loud, irregularly paced duet calls that echo through mangrove forests at dusk and dawn.

name: Scaled Quail
region: Southwestern US to Central Mexico
habitat: Arid valleys, plains, and foothills with sparse vegetation and scattered brush
description: Named for the scaly appearance of its breast and back feathers, this bluish-gray bird sports a distinctive white crest resembling a tuft of cotton. When threatened, it prefers to run rather than fly, and can be found up to 15 miles from the nearest water source.

name: Scaly-naped Pigeon
region: Caribbean islands (not found in continental US/North America)
habitat: Tropical rainforests and lowland woodlands
description: A large slate-grey pigeon with distinctive maroon plumage and a scaly-textured nape, measuring 14–16 inches and featuring striking red eyes surrounded by bare skin patches that differ in color between males and females.

name: Sharp-tailed Grouse
region: Alaska, Northern and Western Canada, Western and Midwestern US
habitat: Prairie grasslands, shrub steppe, savanna-style ecosystems
description: Males perform an elaborate mating dance on communal breeding grounds, stamping their feet up to 20 times per second while inflating and deflating vibrant violet neck sacs to attract females. The provincial bird of Saskatchewan, this medium-sized grouse weighs only 21-31 ounces yet travels across vast prairie ecosystems.

name: Short-tailed Swift
region: Not found in US/North America
habitat: Not applicable
description: Not applicable - this species is found exclusively in Central and South America, from Panama through the Amazon Basin to northern Bolivia.

name: Shy Ground-dove
region: American Samoa, Fiji, Samoa, Tonga, Wallis and Futuna Islands
habitat: Subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests
description: A shy ground-dwelling dove found exclusively in Pacific island territories, this elusive species has become increasingly threatened by habitat loss and is now classified as Vulnerable across its range.

name: Smew
region: Rare vagrant to North America
habitat: Fish-rich lakes and sheltered coastal waters
description: A striking black-and-white diving duck with a distinctive "cracked ice" pattern, equipped with a hooked, serrated bill that makes it a precision fish-hunter capable of diving to snatch prey underwater. Males are unmistakable with their panda-like appearance, while females wear subtle chestnut crowns.

name: Smooth-billed Ani
region: Southern Florida, Caribbean
habitat: Open and semi-open country, cultivated areas, deforested regions
description: A gregarious black bird that nests communally with up to 29 eggs in a single nest, with young from earlier broods helping to feed their siblings. Despite its weak flight, it excels at foraging for termites, insects, and occasionally ticks from grazing cattle.

name: Snow Goose
region: Northern Canada, Alaska, and northeastern Siberia; winters across continental US to Mexico
habitat: Arctic tundra, coastal marshes, agricultural fields, grasslands
description: A long-distance migration champion that travels over 3,000 miles between Arctic breeding grounds and wintering areas, existing in two striking color morphs—pure white or blue-gray—despite being the same species. Population exploded over 300% since the 1970s, now exceeding 5 million birds and causing severe degradation of tundra habitats across North America.

name: Sooty Grouse
region: Pacific Coast Ranges, from southeastern Alaska and Yukon south to California
habitat: Old-growth conifer and mixed forests in mountainous regions
description: A forest-dwelling grouse with an unusual winter survival strategy—it ascends to higher altitudes when temperatures drop and can survive on fir needles alone. Males attract females with deep hooting calls that sound like someone striking a quiet drum from high in the trees.

name: Sora
region: Continental US, Canada, Central America, Caribbean, northern South America
habitat: Freshwater and brackish marshes with dense emergent vegetation
description: A secretive rail that weighs less than 4 ounces but produces a loud, descending whinny call audible across entire marshes—more often heard than seen despite its remarkable boldness in investigating the source of recorded calls.

name: Spectacled Eider
region: Alaska and northeastern Siberia
habitat: Arctic coastal waters and breeding grounds near ponds
description: A master deep-diver capable of remaining submerged longer than most ducks, identifiable by the striking white circular eye patches that resemble spectacles. Once bred across Alaska from the Nushagak Peninsula to Barrow, the population has plummeted over 96% and now numbers fewer than 4,000 nesting pairs.

name: Spotted Dove
region: Southern California, Hawaii
habitat: Urban areas, gardens, parks, and agricultural lands
description: An introduced Asian dove that has established thriving populations across parts of North America, recognizable by its distinctive black neck collar with white spots and long tail with white-tipped feathers. Despite their peaceful appearance, they're considered a hazard on airfields due to their habit of flushing into the air when disturbed, sometimes colliding with aircraft.

name: Spotted Rail
region: Rare vagrant to southern US (Pennsylvania, Texas)
habitat: Marshes, swamps, and wet grasslands with dense cover
description: This secretive rail makes a loud, rasping territorial screech that echoes through wetlands at dawn and dusk, despite rarely venturing into the open. Weighing less than half a pound, it hunts invertebrates and small fish while staying hidden in dense marsh vegetation across Central and South America.

name: Spruce Grouse
region: Alaska, Northern New England, Adirondacks, Northern Michigan, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Montana, Idaho, Oregon, Washington
habitat: Coniferous boreal forests and taiga with spruce, pine, and fir trees
description: A master of camouflage and deception that lets predators approach within just a few feet before taking flight, relying on immobility rather than speed to survive. Males perform spectacular territorial wing-clap displays loud enough to be heard 150 meters away, producing two sharp cracks just half a second apart.

name: Stejneger's Scoter
region: Western Alaska (rare vagrant to continental US)
habitat: Coastal waters and large freshwater lakes
description: This sea duck sports a distinctive tall knob at the base of its orange-yellow bill and a long, elegant "Roman nose" profile reminiscent of a common eider. Forms massive, tightly-packed flocks on coastal waters that take off together in coordinated waves.

name: Steller's Eider
region: Alaska, Arctic coastal regions
habitat: Coastal tundra, marshy lagoons, and Arctic waters
description: The smallest and fastest-flying of all eider species, this Arctic diving duck can plunge to depths of 30 feet while hunting for mobile prey like crustaceans. Once hunted legally, the Alaska-breeding population has dwindled to less than 1% of the global total, making it one of North America's rarest waterfowl.

name: Surf Scoter
region: Northern Canada and Alaska (breeding); Pacific and Atlantic coasts of North America (wintering)
habitat: Boreal forest lakes and marine coastal waters
description: A diving sea duck that can plunge underwater to feed on mussels and other mollusks, with males displaying striking white patches on their head and a uniquely patterned bill in shades of orange, white, red, and yellow. Despite a 50-70% population decline over the past 40 years, this species maintains a global population between 250,000 and 1.3 million individuals.

name: Taiga Bean-goose
region: Rare winter visitor to northern US and Canada
habitat: Open wetlands, marshes, and agricultural fields
description: A massive migratory waterfowl with a distinctive black-and-orange bill, capable of traveling thousands of miles between Arctic breeding grounds and temperate wintering territories. Weighing up to 8.8 pounds with a wingspan exceeding 5.5 feet, this goose produces a loud honking call that echoes across frozen landscapes.

name: Trumpeter Swan
region: Alaska, Northwestern and Central North America, Pacific Coast, Rocky Mountains, wintering in Southern Canada and Northern US
habitat: Large shallow ponds, pristine lakes, undisturbed wetlands, and slow-moving rivers
description: North America's heaviest native bird and largest waterfowl, with a wingspan reaching over 10 feet and weighing up to 38 pounds—nearly extinct by 1933 with fewer than 70 wild birds remaining, but successfully restored to over 46,000 through dedicated reintroduction efforts. Its loud, trumpet-like call can be heard from impressive distances and serves as both a mating duet and predator deterrent.

name: Tufted Duck
region: Winter visitor along US and Canadian coasts
habitat: Open water, marshes, lakes, and coastal lagoons
description: A diminutive diving duck with a distinctive head tuft and population of nearly one million, capable of diving deep to feed on mollusks and aquatic insects both day and night.

name: Tundra Bean-goose
region: Alaska, occasional winter visitor to northern US
