habitat: Arctic tundra, coastal marshes, open wetlands
description: A migratory arctic goose with a distinctive orange-banded bill, capable of traveling thousands of miles between Siberian breeding grounds and Asian wintering sites. Despite diverging from its taiga cousin 2.5 million years ago, the two species still interbreed, creating a fascinating natural hybrid zone.

name: Tundra Swan
region: Alaska, Canada, and Pacific/Atlantic coasts during migration and winter
habitat: Arctic tundra breeding grounds; grasslands and marshes during winter
description: An arctic migratory swan capable of flying at altitudes exceeding 26,000 feet, with each individual bearing a uniquely patterned bill that scientists use to track and study individual birds across continents.

name: Uniform Swiftlet
region: Rare vagrant to Cape York Peninsula and Torres Strait islands, Australia
habitat: Lowland forests, open areas, and cave systems in limestone regions
description: A master of echolocation, this 13 cm swiftlet navigates pitch-black caves with sonar-like precision to reach its moss-and-saliva nests. Weighing just 11 grams, it hunts flying insects at breakneck speeds across Southeast Asian and Melanesian skies.

name: Vaux's Swift
region: Western Canada to southwestern USA, migratory to Central America
habitat: Old growth coniferous and deciduous forests with large hollow trees
description: A tiny aerial acrobat weighing less than a penny, this swift feeds entirely in flight and can roost on vertical surfaces using specialized claws. Each autumn, up to 35,000 of these birds gather in a single Portland, Oregon chimney in North America's largest concentration of the species.

name: Velvet Scoter
region: Northern coastal waters; rare vagrant to continental US
habitat: Coastal waters, sea, lakes, and rivers in far northern regions
description: A large dark sea duck that dives deep for crustaceans and mollusks, distinguished by the striking white eye-patches and wing patches on males and their bulbous yellow bill. At 51-58 cm, it's the largest scoter species and forms tightly-packed flocks that take off in unison from coastal waters.

name: Vervain Hummingbird
region: Caribbean (Jamaica, Hispaniola); rare vagrant to Puerto Rico
habitat: Gardens, dry forest, desert scrub, gallery forest, and urban areas from sea level to 5,200 ft
description: The second-smallest bird in the world at just 2.4 inches long and weighing as little as a penny, this hummingbird is the only male hummingbird species that lacks any iridescent feathering. Weighing only 2 to 2.4 grams, it lays eggs smaller than a grain of rice and doesn't defend feeding territories like other hummingbirds.

name: Violet-crowned Hummingbird
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, New Mexico) and Mexico
habitat: Riparian corridors, deciduous forests, pine-oak forests, gardens and parks
description: A jewel-like wanderer weighing less than a penny, this hummingbird beats its wings up to 80 times per second and can hover motionless while sipping nectar from flowers with its brilliant red bill.

name: Virginia Rail
region: Continental US, Southern Canada, Central America
habitat: Freshwater and brackish marshes
description: A secretive marsh dweller with the highest leg-muscle-to-flight-muscle ratio of any bird (25% versus 15%), enabling it to run through dense vegetation on long toes rather than fly. More often heard than seen, this elusive rail produces harsh nocturnal calls and can compress its body laterally to slip through reeds like a feathered ghost.

name: West Indian Whistling-duck
region: Caribbean (not found in continental US/North America)
habitat: Wooded swamps, mangroves, and tree cavities
description: A nocturnal tree-dwelling duck that habitually roosts and nests in forest canopies, making it the largest and darkest whistling duck species at up to 23 inches long. Known for its haunting whistle calls and preference for feeding on royal palm fruit under the cover of darkness.

name: Western Grebe
region: Western North America, from Canada to Mexico
habitat: Large inland lakes with marsh vegetation and open water; coastal marshes
description: A swan-necked diving expert that performs one of the most elaborate courtship dances in the waterbird world, with pairs rearing up and pattering across the water's surface in synchronized rushes. This 55–75 cm grebe can weigh up to 2 kg and dives to the lake bottom to hunt fish, impaling smaller prey like a heron.

name: White-cheeked Pintail
region: Southern Florida (vagrant)
habitat: Brackish lakes, estuaries, and mangrove swamps
description: Distinguished by pristine white cheeks contrasting with its brown plumage, this dabbling duck filters aquatic plants and seeds from brackish waters across the Caribbean and Galápagos with surprising grace. A popular aviary escape, the species occasionally appears in semi-wild flocks across Europe.

name: White-collared Swift
region: Southern Mexico, Texas, Florida (vagrant)
habitat: Montane and submontane evergreen forests, caves with streams
description: A master of the skies, this swift reaches speeds of 70-100 km/h while hunting flying ants in flocks of 200 or more, and produces an impressive whooshing sound when rapidly descending through valleys.

name: White-crowned Pigeon
region: Florida Keys, Everglades, and southern mainland Florida
habitat: Coastal mangrove forests and inland hardwood forests
description: A fruit-loving pigeon weighing up to 10.6 ounces with a brilliant white crown that shimmers with iridescent green in sunlight. Despite being depicted by John James Audubon in the 1800s, illegal hunting and mangrove deforestation threaten this Caribbean wanderer so severely that abandoning its nest at the slightest disturbance has become its primary survival strategy.

name: White-eared Hummingbird
region: Southwestern US (Arizona, occasional New Mexico and Texas)
habitat: Montane pine and pine-oak forests, forest edges and clearings
description: A jewel-sized hummingbird weighing less than a penny, with a brilliant violet forehead and emerald throat that defends feeding territories against much larger hummingbird species through aggressive displays and secretive aerial maneuvers.

name: White-faced Whistling-duck
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Freshwater lakes and reservoirs with vegetation
description: Gregarious waterfowl with a distinctive three-note whistling call that can form flocks of over 1,000 birds at dawn. Found across sub-Saharan Africa and South America, these noisy ducks sport a striking black head and neck contrasted by a distinctive white face.

name: White-rumped Swiftlet
region: Not found in North America
habitat: Tropical moist forests and rocky areas
description: A diminutive aerial acrobat native to the South Pacific, this swift spends nearly its entire life in flight, catching insects mid-air with remarkable precision. Its small size belies incredible speed and agility, making it nearly invisible as it darts through tropical forests and rocky outcrops.

name: White-tailed Nightjar
region: Central America and northern South America
habitat: Open grasslands, savannas, and scrubby hillsides
description: A nocturnal hunter weighing less than 1.5 ounces, the White-tailed Nightjar executes acrobatic hunting dives from the ground to snatch insects mid-flight. Males perform a distinctive wing-clapping display and sing throughout the night with a high, piercing call that rises and falls like a drawn-out whistle.

name: White-tailed Ptarmigan
region: Alaska, western Canada, and mountainous western US south to northern New Mexico
habitat: Alpine tundra above treeline; rocky slopes, snowfields, and krummholz
description: The smallest member of the grouse family at just 11-12 inches long, this alpine specialist undergoes a dramatic seasonal plumage transformation—completely white in winter and mottled gray-brown in summer—to remain perfectly camouflaged year-round. It is North America's only bird to permanently inhabit the alpine zone, surviving extreme cold with feathered feet and nostrils.

name: White-throated Ground-dove
region: Northern Mariana Islands, Yap
habitat: Native forests and secondary growth
description: A shy forest dweller weighing less than 5 ounces, the male sports a striking chocolate-brown body with pure white head and breast while females remain cryptically brown. Mates for life and produces only a single egg per breeding season, making this ground dove particularly vulnerable to predation from invasive species.

name: White-throated Swift
region: Western North America from British Columbia to Honduras
habitat: Open areas near cliffs, rock faces, canyons, and man-made structures
description: A blur of black and white that rarely touches ground, this aerial insectivore spends entire days aloft catching flying insects at speeds exceeding 100 mph, bathing and preening mid-flight without ever landing.

name: White-tipped Dove
region: Southernmost Texas
habitat: Scrub, woodland, and forest
description: A territorial dove weighing just 5.5 ounces that announces itself with a distinctive deep hollow call: ooo-wooooo. Despite its small size, it defends its woodland home fiercely and remains a resident year-round, never migrating.

name: White-winged Dove
region: Southwestern US through Texas, expanding northward into Oklahoma, Kansas, and southern Canada
habitat: Desert, scrub, agricultural fields, urban areas, and riparian zones
description: Identifiable by the brilliant white crescent patch on its wings, this adaptable dove can fly 25+ miles to find water but survives solely on moisture from saguaro cactus fruit. The second most hunted game bird in the United States, with over 1.6 million taken annually.

name: White-winged Scoter
region: Alaska, Western Canada, Great Lakes, Northern US coasts
habitat: Coastal waters, large lakes, boreal forests
description: A powerful diving duck with a gizzard comprising 8% of its body mass—hard enough to crush the shells of clams and mollusks. Some females can end up tending to as many as 40 ducklings due to brood mixing on crowded breeding grounds.

name: Whooper Swan
region: Occasional vagrant to western North America
habitat: Large bodies of water, wetlands, and subarctic breeding grounds
description: Among the heaviest flying birds in the world, weighing up to 34 pounds with a wingspan exceeding 9 feet. These powerful fliers communicate through deep honking calls and can migrate thousands of miles between breeding grounds and wintering sites.

name: Wild Turkey
region: Continental US from Maine to California, southern Canada
habitat: Hardwood and mixed conifer-hardwood forests with scattered clearings
description: Despite weighing up to 24 pounds, this forest bird is an agile flier capable of reaching speeds of 55 mph and can be heard gobbling up to a mile away to announce its presence to rivals and mates.

name: Willow Ptarmigan
region: Alaska, Canada (Newfoundland, Labrador, Quebec), northern tundra regions
habitat: Tundra, sparse birch and pine forests, willow thickets, heather moorlands, mountain slopes
description: Alaska's official state bird, this grouse undergoes dramatic seasonal transformations from brown summer plumage to pure white winter coat. With a population of 40 million across the Arctic, it possesses specialized pectoral muscles that allow chicks to maintain body temperature within just two weeks of hatching.

name: Wood Duck
region: Eastern US, West Coast, Southern Canada, Mexico
habitat: Wooded swamps, marshes, ponds, and creeks near water
description: One of the most colorful North American waterfowl, this perching duck is the only duck species capable of producing two broods in a single season and features sharp claws that allow it to roost in trees like no other duck.

name: Xantus's Hummingbird
region: Baja California Peninsula (rare vagrant to California and British Columbia)
habitat: Arid woodlands with scrub, oak, and pine-oak; coastal desert and gardens
description: A jewel-like emerald hummingbird weighing just 3.5 grams with a throat that shimmers iridescent green, capable of defending feeding territories and serving as a major pollinator for desert madrone flowers across the Baja Peninsula.

name: Yellow-billed Cuckoo
region: Southern Canada to Mexico, rare vagrant in western North America
habitat: Deciduous woods and dense shrubs
description: A master of rapid reproduction, this bird can transform from egg to fledgling in as little as 17 days, with chicks able to fly within a week of hatching. Known for calling on hot days to presage approaching thunderstorms, earning it the folk names 'rain crow' and 'storm crow.'

name: Zebra Dove
region: Hawaii (introduced 1922)
habitat: Open scrub, farmland, parks and gardens
description: A diminutive dove measuring just 20-23 centimeters that produces the softest, most pleasant staccato cooing calls in the avian world, inspiring competitive singing contests throughout its range. Its intricate black-and-white barred plumage provides such effective camouflage on the ground that these birds seem to vanish among bare earth and short grass.

name: Zenaida Dove
region: Caribbean, Florida Keys
habitat: Open and semi-open areas, mangroves, grasslands
description: The national bird of Anguilla, this swift-winged dove is distinguished by a white trailing edge on its wings visible only in flight. Capable of raising up to 4 broods per year, it feeds its young with nutrient-rich pigeon milk regurgitated from its crop.
